review: Augmented Reality – Theory, Design & Development by Chetan G  Shetty  :  This book provides not only theoretical aspects of AR, but also math behind AR and sample AR code.  This is the best book, I have seen so far which provides theoretical, mathematical and also covers practical aspects of AR.  Starting from  AR History, this book covers Camera calibration, Computer coordinate system, representation of sequence of transformation using homogeneous matrix representation, Computer Vision, Hardware requirements to setup AR Lab, designing and developing AR applications. Best part of this book is basic concepts required to understand and develop AR applications.  It serves as a ready reckoner for the one who wants to develop AR applications.  It also covers OpenGL, OpenCV & ARprogramming toolkit.  This publication can be recommended as text book for AR.FromPushpa T SAssistant ProfessorDept of Computer ApplicationsBMSCE, Benagaluru-19

This technical book gave me full idea on augmented reality. I was a newbee to this area and had just heard on word.I am really thankful to author Chetan who has articulated book in making it understand for new learners with examples, many use cases, realistic pictures , block diagrams. His efforts are highly commendable in making reader curious about the content as everything is new and reader becomes willing to read as he finds worth to getting the concept. This design can be applied to many technical areas and market take it to automotive, medical , avionics , ecommerce shopping, hotels etc., . Thanks again Chetan and hope to see many more contribution in sharing your knowledgeRegardsVageesh

Chetan is a very enthusiastic learner, an explorer, a blogger, a researcher, an architect, an innovator, a founder and not less than an Entrepreneur. Chetan is also the founder of a research group called MARRG(Mobile Augmented Reality Research Group) for those who would contribute towards open source AR. I know Chetan as an ex-colleague, as a very good friend, as a guide; His energy and enthusiasm always have inspired me in many ways.He started very early in the AR-VR and his contribution to AR-VR world is really commendable, this book stands as an example.The book can be a best reference book for all who are interested in AR-VR for learning, development and experimenting. His explanation is very simple, clear with examples and experimental references make the concept easy to understand and implement. The book covers Augmented Reality, Virtual Reality as well as Mixed Reality concepts very well.Interested in AR-VR? wanna try out..? Grab this book.. :)

Good book,author had contributed extraordinary efforts to explain AR-VR concepts. Therotical and simple example on AR-VR made reader to understand it in very easy way. Book also help the reader who are new to this concepts  with more convincing examples. It enlighten author hard work and passion towards research. Author research will be more helpful in the area of hotel industry,FMCG manufacturing industry, medical, etc where AR is used as new strategy for marketing of products.I congratulate Chetan for his countless contribution in the field of research and hope to see further research in this area.

Excellent book to understand the concepts and use cases of AR. Author has explained the concepts in such a simplistic manner. Hats of to the author for putting this effort to make us understand in a meaningful way.

Gentle introduction to AR. Lots of practical examples with clear and well-written explanations. The case studies are beautifully presented with a smooth transition between topics. I highly recommend this book to anyone wanting to understand the AR applications and  their application to real-life scenarios. Thanks for sharing your knowledge and making things so accessible and pleasant to digest.

This books explains in detail various components of building an AR system. From Computer vision to Sensor fusion, it details a lot of useful information on how to build an AR device. Very useful if you want to get an understanding on a Systems level of how a device is stitched together.

This is a great read for anyone who wishes to understand what Augmented Realty is. The book provides a great insight on the know-hows of AR application development with a good combination of theoretical and practical explanations. All the available AR SDKs and tools have been explained in detail which makes it a good read for all the aspiring as well as experienced developers in this field.

I would strongly recommend this book for any reader from a novice who wants to understand the basics of AR to an expert level who would be interested in various problems and solutions. The book is well written, facts captured in easily understandable and presented in an impressive manner.

This is a good read for all the aspiring developers to understand AR. The pictorial representation of concepts by author makes it even more interesting to read and understand. The Book provides an insights with blend of theory and practical explanations on AR/VR. Overall, Great work by Author.

The language used in this book is unnecessarily complex, sometimes it feels like authors have just copy-pasted sentences from some reference book of statistics. e.g. "Reinforcement learning is an area of machine learning inspired by behaviorist psychology, concerned with how software agents ought to take action in an environment so as to maximize some notion of cumulative reward". In professional life we have no time to interpret or understand words like 'behaviorist', 'software agent' and 'notion of cumulative reward'. This is not a layman's language. Students might mug such sentences and write as is in their university exam answer sheets and secure marks; but such language is not useful for professionals definitely.

This is an hands on book and not a theory book as already mentioned by author.The points that make this book different1. Using comprehensive code with good explanation and all necessary comments2. Not using standard dataset like iris cars etc and utilising bigger Datasets from kaggle3. Touching almost everything that you encounter while building a model. Also adding on touching distributing your model using flask and docker4. Covers NLP too including transformers which many of starting ML books choose to ignore.For me it is a good reference guide if you want to brush up again and again.

After reading couple of chapters and have a look at the rest I feel that if someone wants to know how you can solve a machine learning problem with topics like feature selection, feature engineering, hyperparameter optimization it's always better to code it and learn and see what's happening, and that's exactly what the author did. You will also get an idea about NLP models like BERT and how you can use docker, flask for deploying your ML model. What I miss in this book is, if it has a couple of chapters to show how to solve a particular problem statement/dataset by combining the topics he covered in the book, and from creating a baseline model to a pretty complex one just to show the end-to-end approach he usually takes to solve a machine learning problem. Just to ideate his thoughts and strategy he usually follows to solve when he gets an ML problem.

This book is freely downloadable from the authors website. I still ordered this book from 'saraswati pustakalaya'  at Rs 1700, because I wanted a hard copy. This book is great in terms of highlighting the mathematical prerequisites for Machine Learning. But to assume that this is a sufficient and all encompassing 'go to' book would be naive. The prerequisites of Multivariate Calculus, Probability, Linear Algebra and Statistics (Inferential) are vast bodies of knowledge themselves and all of them cannot just be compressed into this single book. This book identifies the specific topics from the prerequisites that are extensively used in building the foundation for the Machine-Learning theory. This is where it helps. I am not a formal mathematician, but I've studied 'Mathematical Statistics, so have some idea of the concepts.  Every ML enthusiast should have this book (free pdf or hard copy), but should have extra books on the 4 prerequisites. Once you are comfortable with the prerequisites, then this book would be helpful. If you are not comfortable with the prequisites then you should avoid this book. The book can be terse, because it is jamming 3 branches of Mathematics and Staistics into a single book. Hope this feedback helps others who are interested. PS - The hard copy that I got was published in India !! I had thought that it was a US print, but was pissed at seeing the 'Sale for only in India' logo. However, the page quality and print quality is excellent. I was amazed as I know Indian prints are pathetic. And the pages are colored, for an Indian print this is not common.

This book is exactly what it claims . It is approach to almost any kind of machine learning problem . The book has a very practical approach towards problem solving and has tones of code .  The book is intended to people who knows a bit of background and struggles to start problem solving .  The book was and is very helpful for me in day to day life and hence the 5 stars .I want to be clear in the review so that people dont get disappointed after buying the book or refrain from buying the book seeing few negative reviews .The book is  immensely helpful for senior professionals like me who are from other branches of software engineering /domain knowledge and still wants to reduce the entry level barrier to get into machine learning and deep learningThe book is immensely helpful for students from programming/non-programming background looking to learn and solve AI/ML problems and are scared to venture into it .The book is immensely helpful for people with a lot of theoretical knowledge but less programming knowledge to apply the same into some cool project .The book is not helpful for people who has a masters in mathematics and looking for reference in writing phd thesis in Machine Learning methods .

Amazingly written in approaching any machine learning problem. I have seen and read lot of books which talks about all the algorithms (from mathematical to intuition point of view), but no one gave me a clear view on how we can approach any dataset and build good models from the data.  The flow of chapters are perfect and in the end you will learn a lot on building the ML models. I think it is a must book like how Tibshirani and Trevor's book (Introduction to Statistical Learning) is must for every beginner to pro. Thanks to Abhishek for writing this gem of a book. Looking forward for more of his works in the future on Deep learning & NLP.

Bought this book yesterday. Already few pages into the book. Absolutely loving it so far. It's different than other books in the sense that it will be very helpful for budding machine learning enginners. This book helps you create a strong base of most the algorithms and shows how to code them on python. It doesn't have complicated equations of the algorithms, not that you don't need to know them, this book will create a great base for you to understand those complex equations and will clear your concepts on these algorithms. It also helps in understanding the implementation of different algorithms.

I've used the online copy of this book when going through the Math for ML specialisation in Coursera. It's pretty comprehensive in handling the core areas of Math required for ML. I'd also recommend it as a quick refresher in Math if you're preparing for ML/DS interviews. Had to get the physical copy, because it's much easier to navigate, and unlike other tech books this one is not to be obsolete anytime soon.
Given the price of the book, was expecting better paper quality and also colored diagrams. The diagrams are in black ink.
Excellent material
Recommend

I find it strange there are so many positive reviews for this book. Some of the reviewers have only this review to their name, which I always find dodgy. The presentation is turgid, dull and unclear. Not a pedagogical masterpiece by any means - neither fish nor fowl, the terse (as described by the authors themselves) mathematical syntax serves only to obfuscate, without being mathematical rigorous.I've made several attempts to read this (and I know much of the material already) but trying to decipher the unnecessarily quasi-mathematical notation that makes simple concepts unclear got too wearying. I've ordered Aggarwal's "Linear Algebra and Optimization for Machine Learning". I hope that's better.

While the content of the book is very clear and concise (something many maths books tend to struggle with), this text unfortunately falls into the trap of presenting many new ideas with too few exercises to reinforce them (at least in the maths section). This would be fine if the authors' aim was to produce a reference for these topics, but they themselves acknowledge the intended target audience to be "undergraduate students, evening learners and learners participating in online machine learning courses" i.e. those who are being introduced to the subject matter for the first time and who will quickly forget these ideas after having struggled through the terse, potentially unfamiliar, language.

I have just received this book hours ago. It is paperback.  I breezed through book with skimreading at first. Simple illustrations with few colours — VERY HELPFUL. The page layout is perfect, very easy on my eyes! I could read quickly, as the text is not too cluttered. I have learned maths fast. Thank you, authors.Moreover, I absolutely love the 4cm margins at the outer edges of pages, as I like pencilling my notes in blank spaces or place sticky notes there. Helpful footnotes in the margins.
It's a very good (and maybe only) resource for someone who's starting on the field of machine learning and is trying to understand the underlying mathematics.
If you want to start Tensorflow then this best book. Actually this is same as Coursera Tensorflow developer Specialization course. I will highly recommend for Tensorflow introduction

Tonight, I completed reading of Laurence Moroney’s book “AI and Machine Learning for Coders”. I enjoyed this book from cover to cover, and I am especially thankful for a few things.First, this book did a great job of explaining how tensorflow can be used to solve different types of problems, such as computer vision, natural language processing, and time series forecasting. It even went into text generation, which got my creativity going.Second, this book is written for coders, but it does explain how neural networks work at a high level. It doesn’t drop a wall of math on the reader, which I appreciated. I feel much more comfortable now, after reading this.And finally, the book ends by discussing interpretability, bias/fairness, and Google’s AI principles. I found that to be a beautiful ending.I give this five stars. The few issues I had were trivial. This book is outstanding. I’m so much better off for having read it.
Good book but still not study.

I have read theoretical books on AI/ML; they do explain concepts but do not make you get started hands-on. This book does that. It has a few foundational chapters to cover the basics and then applies them either in R or Python. Note that you cannot be too naive in maths or understanding program flows if you intend to work in the area of AI/ML. Hence, it is good to have supplementary books on maths (basic statistics, matrix and probability) and general programming to quickly refer back. When I bought the book, thought that it is good to know two languages as well; but while reading it, felt a bit uncomfortable while switching from one example in one language to the other in another language; however, examples themselves are self-sufficient and comprehensible.

The Book is good for readers who are knowledgeable in AR and also those who are new to the Subject. Topics covered in detail with examples and the usage of graphics has made it easy to visualise. Useful for developers wanting to build AR Apps.

This book is lucid and crisp, its a one-in-all package for conceptual ideas in AR. The images and snapshots provide the readers with whole another level of depth! Value for every dime spent
This clearly a good toolkit for AR. It's very clearly explained. I recommend this book for mobile developers to integrate AR in the mobiles.
As someone who is new to the world ofAugmented Reality, I found the concepts and techniques explained in a clear yet simple method.The practical use cases in th book make it easier to understand.
Very good book for Augmented Reality enthusiasts.Covers all aspects of Augmented Reality. Basics, foundation concepts, trends, programming and all other aspects. It's a mix of theory and Practical
Excellent content!!! Covers a wide range topics which makes it suitable for beginners as well as the advanced ones. Definitely the best choice for understanding AR in depth.

Awesome Book. This should really be the First book you read on Machine Learning. Understanding the Math and associating the tuning parameters to the Math allows you to better tune your models.
This is a very bad textbook. Organization of content is very illogical. There are better books out there.

This book will always be in my shelf. This might not be the most organized book in machine learning but man this book has stuff. It looks like a good book but it is more of reference book and not a text book. Could be a good one for Phd student.

1. It's not for faint hearted people who don't understand the beauty of mathematics.2. It covers almost all the topics of ML and a good handbook which covers Statistical Learning and Patterns Recognition.3. Heavy book both in terms of weight and knowledge too. The book is very poetic for ML.

Don't waste your money on this book. This book is junk. You will never learn anything from this book. Very superficial coverage of the topics and very very confusing. Better to pick up a math book instead.

1 This is the best ML book I can find, though, not very suitable for a beginner. There are many typos in the first 3 printings. The 4th (and later) printing is much better. What I bought (11/24/2017) is the 6th printing (the same as the 4th).2 Please note: The book mainly concentrate on various classic supervised and unsupervised learning methods, and not much on deep neural network (tons of materials online, e.g. youtube or tensorflow’s guide),and reinforcement learning (Sutton’s famous book).3 The following sentences are what I found on Quora, said by the author (2016): “…the current version is admittedly rather hard for beginners. I am actually in the process of writing the second edition, which will ramp up more slowly,  making it more accessible to beginners. (I'm also adding new content on deep learning, reinforcement learning, etc.) But it will take me a while to finish (~2 years?).”Before I bought it, I emailed the author to ask his plan on the 2nd edition. He said: “... I am working on it, but it won't be done till late 2018...”.4 Last but not least, the book binding is firm, and, beautiful :)
It is a good book for beginners which tells what is machine learning and some preliminary methods used in Machine Learning. Solved Numericals help in understanding concepts to the core
Worst book

A very good book, I use it as a reference, it explains briefly most machine learning algorithms clearly  and shows you a simple implementation.  Best to use to compliment a machine learning book of your choice, I’m using this in conjunction with Hands On Machine Learning With Scikit Learn and Tensor Flow.

If you are a practitioner of ML, I'd suggest you to buy this book with eyes closed. The author doesn't go extremely deep into the theory behind most of the algorithms, because well... that's not the primary focus of this book. It's more hands-on, as the title suggests, and I think the contents justify that pretty well. For a more comprehensive treatment to the theory behind the algorithms, I'd suggest to go with 'The Elements of Statistical Learning' or 'Bayesian Reasoning and Machine Learning'. Both are freely available online.I had the 1st edition of this book but still chose to buy this new and improved iteration mostly because of the following reasons.1.  Addition of new materials (e.g. more unsupervised learning, more deep net techniques, new CNN architectures, etc.)2. Migration of codebase to Tensorflow 2.0.3. Discussion on Training and Deployment of Tensorflow models at scale.This is a colored edition, unlike the 1st edition of the book. It helps immensely, especially for the visualizations and graphs. The page quality is very nice too, and they have a glossy finish.
Well written, well structuredGood examples
Loved the book! It was amazing!

This is my absolute favorite Machine Learning book.I might call it a reference book. Chris is not a programmer by heart (just a smart Ph.D.). So he does not try to solve problems with fancy code. I love that. You might not.To get the most of this book, allow me to give you some pointers:- Your favorite ML library is Scikit-Learn (i.e. you solve numerical/categorical problems).- You have some Kaggle experience (nominal, ordinal, categorical problems).- You have a strong foundation in ML, Python, statistics, Pandas you have gained from authors such as Sebastian Raschka, Wes McKinney, Jake VanderPlas, Jason Brownlee…My runner-ups:“Python Machine Learning” by Sebastian RaschkaComment: Anything written by Sebastian is amazing. A must read for Scikit-Learn Ninjas.“Hands on Machine Learning …” by Aurelien GeronComment: One of the most impressive ML books ever. It’s so much though material though. And Geron is beyond super-smart.“Data Science from Scratch” by Joel GrusComment: Intellectually, I love the topics, but don’t like his way of writing code. And, with many Data Science books in general, tries to cover simply too much.Highlights in “Machine Learning with Python Cookbook”:- Page >47: the best Panda tricks in a few pages.- Page 71: A popular Kaggle trick: labeling outliers in a separate column.- Page 77: not many understand how to deal with MCAR and MAR.- Page 78: data imputation. How to do it and when to use mean (normal distribution) and median.- Page >81: dealing with categorical data is hard. Many authors like to avoid it, not Chris.- Page 201: visualizing the effect of training set size. Great working code!Conclusion: a great reference book for us who are into Python, Pandas and Scikit-Learn (traditional Machine Learning algorithms).

I got this book yesterday and I already finished two chapters. Here is a short summary of the content:- This is a very practical introduction to machine learning using Python.- I have some experience with ML concepts. Although the book says it's for beginners, I still find it helpful. The second chapter, end-to-end machine learning projects, helped me to understand a few small yet important steps we tend to miss/ignore when we work on a large scale ML project.- Choose this book if you know Python. Even if you don't have Python experience, with a crash course, you can easily learn Python and the concepts in the book.Now a little bit about the book: The book is of high quality! It is also a bit heavy due to the quality of the paper. All the pages are colored and glossy and attractive enough to make you wanna read the book!I recommend this to anyone with no/beginner/intermediate experience in ML.

I had my eye on this since the author published the latest version earlier this year however I was skeptical regarding Shroff Publishers faithfully reproducing it and that too a full colour edition. Fortunately I was proven wrong as both, the paper quality itself and other aspects like font and coloured images were on point and precise.Regarding the content itself, this revised version of the book has been updated for Tensorflow 2.0 and latest version of the Keras API.As described, the book while ensuring it delivers a brief introduction behind the technical components of a machine learning project lifecycle and ideas; focuses primarily on the working of the tools and their respective capabilities with code snippets for most of the examples present explained throughout the book.Notebooks containing source code for all the described examples and case studies, are present on the authors public Github repository under 'handson-ml2'. Also includes the datasets utilized some of which are modified versions of other publicly available datasets.Do note that environment setup described is as according to a Linux and Mac based terminal. For Windows just like the author himself notes, I would highly suggest installing Anaconda (or Miniconda - lightweight bare bones installation of the same which I personally recommend and use). Once you have made a virtual environment and installed the required packages using conda package manager you can follow all the rest of the instructions in the book.Overall this handbook is highly recommended for anyone who is decently versed with Python and has a rough idea about what Machine Learning actually is because unfortunately there are a lot of buzzwords in the market involving the field of machine learning and data science, the latter of which is a much broader term.So if you are just starting out to explore this area I suggest beginning with some other resources which define and clarify some of the myths as you should know what you are actually getting into before fully investing your time. For learning the basics of Python itself, I personally suggest 'Byte of Python' which is a freely available ebook for a brief introduction to the language.

This is one of the best books I have read in machine learning. With so many years in the Corporate world, I am out of touch with theoretical mathematics.  But reading this book never made me feel that I am out of touch with advanced maths as the explanations are crystal clear without the hassles of too much of mathematical jargons. I will always recommend this book to anyone who wants to start their ML journey.

So Finally I got the book at around 2000Rs. The other one was at 5000. I was confused about what is the difference between both, will this one be with tensorflow2x or it is the old one.This one is genuine and good quality colored printed pages. Covering all the topics and basics for Deep Learning and Machine learning. I have an iPad for reading books but I am more comfortable with folding pages and writing on paper rather than thinking about the battery when I need to study. So bought this one and looking forward to completing it.Costly but yeah worth being an OReilly Book.Thanks for reading.

It's an Excellent Book on ML and that's a well known fact but the package is just pathetic. The first book arrived with corner damage and now the replacement received is an used Book. Please review the table of contents before purchasing this book - Machine Learning chops until after a number of chapters.It does not look as easy as it looks - you will have to practice a ton before you can comfortably use these skills on a regular basis with a reasonable amount of precision - but I thoroughly enjoyed the gentle introduction topics.Overall a definite handbook to have in one's Data Science arsenal.

Maravilhoso. As explicações são muito boas e bem escritas. A proposta de testar o código copiando e colando e depois entender o processo é simples e deixa tudo muito melhor. Vale ressaltar que não é um livro introdutório, mas sim com soluções, como o título já indica.

This book has good amount of information to start of with and do great projects in python. It has python coding in it. Which boosts up this book even more

I found the contents of the book is merely compilation of material available on internet which is created and nicely explained by different experts on different machine learning topics. This book mainly explores features of sklearn library using pandas, seaborn and matplotlib. So, if you need compiled version of supervised and unsupervised algorithms implemented in python, then this book is a good choice. Authors also claims that "All the topics include real-world examples and provide step-by-step approach...". Please visit "Kaggle: Your Home for Data Science", you find everything there. Anyways, it also made me disappointed to see renowned publisher "Wiley" associated with it.

Excellent book for data scientist new to Python. The book provides code examples on a variety of topics starting from probability distribution and many machine learning algorithms. The examples are well choosen and embibes the core concepts of data science and reflects years of teaching experience of both Prof Dinesh and Manaranjan.I highly recommend it as a reference book to look up for codes snippets while working on ML projects.
The book itself is a good introduction for beginners but the plots are not colored and the paper quality is pretty bad.I do not know if this is a fake book or it was actually printed that way.

Great coverage of basic statistics, hypothesis testing, Regression techniques. one of the few books which covers these topics in python, since these were traditionally done in other tools such as SPSS,SAS or R.Has many  solved case studies which makes it easy to understand and apply the ML techniques .Recommend this book for beginners and intermediate data scientists

I wanted to learn Python and amazon suggested me this book, but although it's really useful, this book isn't for beginners who are not aware of the basics of Python. The authors could have done a better job by providing scannable QR codes rather than providing the links for the data or placing all the materials in one folder rather than directing the user to download something from a different website for each exercise. I had a hard time finding IPL .csv file on the internet as even the link was not provided. The publishers should take care of these things from next time!

This book is helpful for those who are new in Machine Learning and are doing self study. But it requires a good knowledge of Python Programming where all the basic concepts are well versed.The main point for this book is exercises which are given after every chapter. I may be challenging for self learners as there are no solutions and one cannot gain confidence whether the solution or the way the solution is done is correct or not.

Don't spend your money on this book. It will not at all talk about basics for which a newbie struggles.It will directly write python code using various libraries without explaining the code. so you are expected to know pandas, matplotlib, seaborn etc. beforehand.I was somewhat fine with this because my main need from this book was to understand the stats involved with machine learning but it fails there as well.It will start talking about examples without explaining what normal distribution is, what is confidence interval and all.TOTAL WASTE OF MONEY, PLEASE SAVE YOUR MONEY AND TIME.

Reviewing a book is always a very subjective matter. I already work on data sc. This book would give help me get quick tips. Like all, even this book is not comprehensive, but it addresses the topics at the basic level. I am very happy with this book, especially the examples used in this.

Este libro sirve como guía o compendio de temas matemáticos que se utilizan en Machine Learning. Es recomendable tener nociones de Álgebra Lineal, Cálculo de varias variables y Estadística para poder leerlo.¿Para quién es este libro? Para aquellos que ya han llevado cursos de las materias antes mencionadas y necesitan saber como aplicar esos conocimientos al Machine Learning.¿Para quién no es este libro?Para quienes apenas se están iniciando en el aprendizaje de las matemáticas superiores. Si buscas un libro introductorio a las matemáticas necesarias para Machine Leaening, no es para tí. En su lugar recomiendo libros como "Linear Algebra" de Friedberg y "Cálculo Avanzado" de Fulks.A mi en lo personal me gustó mucho el libro.Recomiendo buscar el libro en internet (se encuentra gratuito en pdf) y revisarlo, antes de comprarlo. A pesar de tenerlo en PDF, me es más comodo leerlo en físico que en digital.

Das Buch wird leider seinen verheisungsvollen Einleitungen, die Vorfreude auf große Leserfreundlichkeit vermitteln, nicht so richtig gerecht.  Was ich bisher in diesem Buch verstanden habe, sind nur Dinge, die ich schon einigermaßen weiß. Auf manchen Seiten fühle ich mich wie auf Wikipedia, wo immer ganz viele Köche mitkochen, es fehlt ein didaktischer Roter Faden. Es wirkt alles bissel, wie die Abarbeitung eines Standardlehrplans.

I found this book to be incredibly practical, easy-to-approach, and directly applicable to real-world problems that I am trying to solve. I have read quite a few Machine Learning (ML) and AI-type books "for programmers".  This book differs from them in having the sole focus of giving programmers the minimum, pertinent, focused information and context needed to start utilizing TensorFlow (TF) on their own projects, right now. There are enough examples in this book that one of them might directly address a problem you are contemplating using TF for.  If not, reading how to apply TF across these various scenarios is likely to enable you to try TF in your project.  I really like the "results-driven" organization of the chapters. This makes the book both a self-contained class in using TensorFlow as a developer, and a good "cookbook" for both using TensorFlow, and deploying TensorFlow models to alternate/resource-constrained devices (via TensorFlow Lite).  I heartily recommend this book for these purposes!

If you start with this book, watch Laurence's videos on the TensorFlow/ Google Developer youtube channel and work all the examples and exercises, you will have a solid foundation in deep learning. Then you could potentially learn more from the documentation itself or by using Aurélien Géron's book.I feel other Oreilly books should be like this.Although math is almost absent in this book (hence 'for coders'), Laurence does a great job explaining convolutions and maxpooling etc.. I've seen lectures from many sources that misattribute pixel/dimension reduction to the convolution step and not the pooling layer (worse yet, lump both together) but the author clearly explains the concepts.

Laurence is the teacher you always wish you had.  He covers every aspect of TensorFlow with deep yet tangible intelligence.  If you're worried about understanding the practice of machine learning and artificial intelligence, don't worry any longer.  This book guides you through various aspects of the TensorFlow framework, but it also leans into the varying aspects of popular AI problems.You get the full tour in this book, from NLP coding to embedding your models in edge devices.  Each section is overflowing with code samples to help you solidify what you're learning.10 out of 10, a cornerstone of any AI bookshelf.

Laurence Moroney is an extremely gifted teacher with an uncanny ability to make optically complex tasks seem almost trivial.  For example, the chapters on time series analysis and sequencing models using AI are some of the clearest and most applicable examples that I've seen published so far (and forecasting is a very hot topic right now).  This book leverages Keras to demonstrate how some fairly astonishing things (image recognition, NLP, forecasting, etc) can happen with not that much code.  I almost think that this should be required reading for anyone concerned with AI explainability.  Thank you so much, Laurence Moroney.

Laurence explains tough concept in easy way.Code in Github and website of Laurence has good examplesThis is my 3rd book on Machine Learning, and I have seen different approaches to explaining complex concepts like How CNN works? etc. The stye used by Laurence comes with many decades of experience to understand and I guess thats why he can explain so well. I am liking it :).I just finished Chapters 1, 2, and 3 with coding along the way.Will update again as I read and practice further.Thanks Laurence Moroney.Mahtab SyedMelbourne

This little introduction to Machine Learning is a gem. It is for the absolute beginner as it explains in the title. But it acts as an extremely useful helicopter view of the subject, not in journalist style, but actually very true to the mathematics and methodologies underlying the techniques. The book also helps those thinking about a career in machine learning. They will get an overview of what it is about and what types of skills are required.For those with a deeper mathematical maturity, this book could also act as a good reference framework for all the different approaches and techniques covered. For example, to understand what reinforcement learning is (and why it is so difficult) or ensemble learning techniques. The real difference between standard regression and logistic regression. Traditional textbooks and monographs can become overburdened in the technical mathematics and make the reader lost in terms of where they are in the whole overall scheme of machine learning.

The knowledge of this book: Surface! It is, of course, for absolute beginners but I think, even if you are an absolute beginner, you can find other better sources online instead of reading this book. If you are only curious about what is machine learning and you only want to read a book on machine learning one time in life (yes, only one time in life), you can buy it but I believe it wastes your money!

Deep Learning is changing our world. If you want to understand more, this is a great place to start. Andrew Glassner is a talented explainer - I took his short course on Deep Learning and learned so much, but also came away impressed at how well he can make complex material so clear and engaging. And this book is jammed packed with insights, visuals, and clear explanations. The author has a playful, sometimes quirky style that shines through, which gives this tour a lot of personality as well as information. Very enjoyable reading - I felt like he captured all that was good about his course (and then some) and bottled it up in this book. There is a lot more material here than in that course, and it is well laid-out and organized so that it is easy to roam around and come back to review the pieces that matter to you.Even if you plan to go to on to be a world-class Deep Learning engineer or mathematician, you have to start by understanding the concepts. And this book does a great job of presenting all the core ideas in a way that makes them clear and memorable.

Chris Albon has a broad and deep knowledge of data science.  This book is a treasure of hints, explanations, and examples for the use of Python and associated libraries, including Pandas, in machine learning.  It is not a text, but it much more than cheat sheets.Chris begins with common operations with arrays, vectors, and matrices -- loading, sorting, examining, analyzing, combining, modifying, transforming.  Then continues with procedures used to prepare data -- data handling, normalization, standardization, encoding categories, selecting date ranges, dimensionality reduction, feature selection, and cross-validation.  Several chapters review models, including techniques for model selection, hyper-parameter tuning, performance metrics, and discussions of fitting and validation.Each topic is clearly explained and accompanied by a short, self-contained, listing of a Python (Version 3) program as illustration.I highly recommend this book to all of us who need a quick refresher related to a command or procedure.

There are a huge number of machine learning books now available. I own many of them. But I don't think any have had such an impact as Chris Bishop's effort here - I certainly count it as my favourite. The material covered is not exhaustive (although good for 2006), but it's a good springboard to many other advanced texts. (The moniker of ML 'Bible' has apparently been passed to Kevin Murphy's book.) What *is* covered is explained with exceptional clarity with an eye for understanding the intuition as well as the theory.If you are after a practitioners guide, or a first ML book for self study, this probably isn't ideal. It assumes significant familiarity with multivariate calculus, probability and basic stats (identities, moments, regression, MLE etc.). The pitch is probably early post-graduate level, but with a few stretching parts. If this is your background, I think it's a better first ML book than MacKay (Information Theory ...), Murphy (Machine Learning ...), or Hastie et al. (Elements of Statistical Learning), due to its coherence of topics and consistency of depth. But those books are all excellent in their own ways. However, Barber (Bayesian Reasoning ...) is a good alternative.Most chapters are fairly self contained, so once you've worked your way through the first couple of chapters, you can skip around as required. A particular highlight for me were the chapters on EM and variational methods (ch 9 & 10); I think you'd be hard pressed to find a better explanation of either of them. Finally, worth pointing out it's unrepentantly Bayesian, and lacking some subtelty which may be grating for seasoned statisticians. Nevertheless, if the above sounds like what you're looking for, this is probably a good choice.

This may be the most poorly written textbook I’ve ever seen. It’s basically a curriculum of material to study. I couldn’t name a single chapter that I think is particularly well-written. There is a section “Learning to rank”, which is in the GLM chapter, the author even admits that it has nothing to do with GLMs but didn’t have space elsewhere, it speaks volumes...Do yourself a favor and learn the material from other sources (Bishop’s classic; Rasmussen/Williams for GPs; Efron/Hastie “Computer Age Statistical Inference”; Robert/Marin “Bayesian Essentials with R” are very good references).The newer edition, which is expected in early 2022, doesn’t look much better. I have seen the discussion of the drafts on GitHub, and I also reported a bunch of typos as well as serious errors myself. I was astonished by both the incompetence and indifference of Dr Murphy with regard to technicalities and details. The fact that almost all graphics are ‘stolen’ from other sources is also quite telling: The author doesn’t have passion for teaching and he shouldn’t be doing it.

The field now collected beneath the standard of 'Machine Learning' is so vast, and draws from so many different schools of thought, and hence mindsets, notations and assumptions, that it is extremely hard to take your bearings.  Even knowing what exists, and how it relates to the rest of what exists, is extremely difficult. The old school statistics guys speak one language, the machine learners another, and the Bayesian chaps yet a third, and so although there are many unifying ideas, these are hard to identify.  The primary strength of this book is that it allows the reader to see the connections by providing a unifying framework and notation all the way from basic distributions through standard statistical models to machine learning black-boxes and out to applied algorithms.  Many sections end in current academic references, as well as current practical uses thereof.  I have wanted such a text for a very long time, and am thrilled to have found it.Beyond that, the approach that the book takes to maths hits the sweet-spot between the thicket of lemma-lemma-theorem-proof found in 'academic' books, and the hand-wavy elisions found in 'practitioners' book.  That is, important proofs are stated and fully worked, within the context of softer discussion of the concepts presented.  Finally, having the source code for all images in the books allows you to dive in and really understand by doing.  Having this code a gold standard off which to base your own software is fantastic.I have read the other main books in this area (PGM, ESL, PRML etc) and think this is the most broad, thorough and unified presentation available.  It can be used as the foundation for understanding this field.

In college, I was bored out of my mind during Linear Algebra, Multivariable Calculus, and Statistics courses. I wish the concepts would be introduced in the way they are in this book. For example, partial differentiation and gradients are explained in terms of neural network weight optimization / gradient descent. Other than being used as a refresher for those who have seen the material, I wouldn't recommend this book. Cumbersome notation, and below average presentation.

The format - definition, theorem, example - make this book very accessible to all STEM undergraduates. It is a good survey of introductory topics found in a linear algebra and multivariable calculus course. However, if you have already taken these courses or taken much more difficult math, this book is a disappointment -  it references a lot of other texts when the math gets interesting - i.e. instead of covering the approximation of linear equations via Krylov methods, it just reference other texts if you are interested.

This book is excellent for brushing up your mathematics knowledge required for ML. It is very concise while still providing enough details to help readers determine important parts. Especially for the probability section, the concepts will be very hard to grasp without prior knowledge

The topics in this book are interesting, but it is so full of errors, some very material, that it leads one to doubt the conclusions it makes. As one reviewer commented, the first chapter is good, full of interesting insights about applications of ML to asset management. The next eight go off into the weeds of obscure jargon, badly formatted code, graphics and math equations. I am reviewing the Kindle version, it is ironic that another reviewer should complement the print edition formatting. If you live and breathe correlation matrices and hack p-values in your sleep and happen to be an advanced user/developer of ML, then this little text is your cup of tea! For the general reader I would only recommend if they had pretty good mastery of machine learning already.Benjamin Graham's Intelligent Investor by contrast is aimed toward the informed layman and is still one of the top books I would recommend for investment philosophy. I have read about 30 books on investing in the past year and a half with investing philosophies from value oriented to technical analysis to growth oriented and I have gotten valuable, actionable information from all of them to some degree.  This text, not so much! I am a software developer by profession and I have a decent understanding of calculus and basic statistics so I am not put off by books that have a fair amount of quantitative/technical content that I have to stretch to understand like Python for Finance by Hilpisch and A Non-Random Walk down Wall Street by Lo and MacKinlay.  I should have returned it under the 7 day return window for Kindle purchases. The good part is that is was not expensive. I will return to this book when I have taken some ML courses and gotten some practice with toolkits like SciKit-Learn to get ideas on how ML can complement traditional mathematical economic techniques.

Das Buch von Bishop ist ein Lehrbuch wie man es nicht so oft antrifft. Das Ziel, Musterkernnungsalgorithmen ist nur ein Aufhänger um in geschlossener Form alle Grundlagen von Wahrscheinlichkeitsrechnung, Statistik, Regressions und Klassifikationsrechnung und algorithmen Maschinellen Lernens vorzustellen. Dabei bleiben die notwendigen Vorkenntnisse auf basiskenntnisse in Linearer Algebra (Vektor- und Matrizenrechnung) und an wenigen Stellen Differentialrechnung beschränkt.Jede Thematik wird umfassend motiviert, sodass nicht wie in anderen Büchern oft das Ziel einer Rechnung vor lauter geschwurbel untergeht.Bishop ist der Bayesianischen Statistik verpflichtet. Für den Leser ist das ein großer Gewinn, der Bayesianische Ansatz ist in der Darstellung Bishops überaus verständlich  und erleichtert meiner Meinung nach Insbesondere das Verständnis der Ansätze sehr. Als Konsequenz des Bayesianischen Ansatzes sind manche Rechnungen/Herleitungen durchaus etwas länger als in frequentistischer Literatur und auch oft anspruchsvoller. Am Ende bleibt aber das Gefühl die Zusammenhänge besser verstanden zu haben.An dieser Stelle möchte ich auch Hervorheben, dass das Buch viele sehr anschauliche Grafiken und Schaubilder hat. Einfach super verständlich dargestellt und visualisiert.

Comprato per l’università questo libro offre una visione completa sul machine learning ed è consigliato a chiunque sia interessato all argomento. Il libro è molto espansivo. Io L ho acquistato con copertina rigida ed è davvero bello. Inoltre le stampe sono a colori e permettono di comprendere meglio di altri libri i grafici e le immagini proposte.

This book packs a lot of useful knowledge in one place which is convenient for students of machine learning. However Bishop spends an equal amount of time elucidating on side matters which makes it difficult to tell what is important. Bishop also has a nasty habit of doing derivations but skipping past the most complex steps, as if he were too lazy to type them out. While I found the topics interesting, it benefited me much more to use Google to find explanations that were both shorter and less confusing.
I am new to ML and just started reading it. In just few pages i realized it to be really well written book.

If you have seen one of Lopez de Prado's lectures, you will understand immediately that his work offers advances to standard problems in portfolio management. This small book summarizes the main contributions and cannot be recommended strongly enough.The book is comprised of several very dense chapters of all new material in the field. These include advances in covariance estimation based on random matrix theory, optimal clustering, labelling methods for trend tracking, using ML for variable selection for prediction, hierarchical risk parity (instead of Markowitz portfolio optimization) for portfolio selection, and two alternatives to standard sharpe-ratio back testing of strategies. All of these new methodologies address fundamental problems with the standard techniques that have been used for decades in portfolio theory and in sum represent a big step forward in the theory.This book is worth purchasing just to read the introduction. It gives great insight into how to use machine learning for finance that you won't find in any other book.The author devised a machine learning algorithm based on 'theories' of finance 'discovered' from machine learning, not based on back testing. This made all the difference during the flash crash. Unlike many others, his algorithm made lots of money during this period because of the way he designed it.This book will NOT teach you general machine learning techniques. As the author admits in the introduction, you must learn these things from other books. But the techniques here should be acquired by everyone in finance.

"Machine Learning for Asset Managers" is everything I had hoped.In this concise Element, De Prado succinctly distinguishes the practical uses of ML within Portfolio Management from the hype.Concepts are presented with clarity & relevant code is provided for the audiences’ purposes.This work serves as support for the argument that there are better systematic & objective methods for creating investment portfolios than the simplified heuristics of our past.For that, I am thankful.De Prado’s work will be remembered as the 21st Century’s “The Intelligent Investor” (Benjamin Graham).

In his "Advances in Financial Machine Learning" Marcos Lopez de Prado touches on multiple uses for asset managers, my personal favorite one was his asset allocation process where he compensates for what he calls the "Markowitz's curse".This new book though, it just expands on the best concepts of the other one, particularly for anyone interested in asset management. Just wow... An absolute fountain of useful and actionable information for any asset manager.It also happen to me one of the most beautifully printed books I've ever had.

Not very insightful and looks like a data scientist is presenting his/her day job. Good for people completely new to data science. Would be helpful if it could highlight what’s the difference or so special about asset management applications vs others

I am commenting about the hardcover second edition of this book.After lending the first edition from a friend for some time, I enjoyed it so much that though that it was time to get my own copy. I like the algorithmic approach to the methods explained and I think that using Python, a language that was designed to be readable, is a good idea. It covers many of the relevant methods that are actually used in machine learning and it was very useful for me to get an intuition of what is behind an algorithm.However, I am not happy with the quality of the printing. There are a lot of compression artefacts in the images and small black dots all around (you can see them in the pictures). The letters look blurry and are difficult to read. The problem is even worse in the sections with code that have a grey background. It is like the black ink is neither black nor grey, the kind of printing that you get from a inkjet printer in "draft" quality. I do not know if this is a problem with my book or with all the edition but it makes the book very difficult to read sometimes. I do not remember those problems in the first edition. This is not what I expect for this price.

Very good approach, and with Python now becoming so prevalent in research, then to be able to download .py scripts for the examples explained is a massive bonus. I've read many technical books in my time, including quite a few on machine learning (ML), and this is easily the worst I've ever read. There is no way anyone is going to learn ML from this book. There is a lot of irrelevant waffle, like how reading this book isn't going to enable you to recreate the next C3PO (duh, really?), and a whole load of other stuff that's just a waste of space. Even the parts that describe ML do it in such a poor way that you're very unlikely to work out what they are on about. It's all theory, with no practical background, each bit of theory being "explained" (and I use that word with some caution) in isolation, with no reference to how they fit together, how or when you might use them, or indeed anything that might give them some use.However, the worst part is that there is absolutely nothing in the way of practical examples. In most technical subjects, and especially a complex one like ML, the best (possibly only) way to learn is to walk through an example. Every other book I've read on this subject has started with a dataset, described it, done a quick visual examination (which is a good way to introduce some of the basic features of the language(s) and package(s) being used), then described an outline of a ML technique, and then built up a complete example of using that technique to analyse the data, explaining every step as you go along. This book doesn't even contain any significant code samples! The most you get are a few isolated (as in, not connected to any description of a technique, nor connected to any other code) snippets, with zero to little explanation of what the code is doing , or when/where/why you might use it.Given that the book wastes two chapters showing you how to install R and Python in painful detail (like screenshots of the licence screen on the install wizard), and then another two on hopelessly badly explained introductions to the two languages, they don't even use those languages in anything more than small snippets. With nothing other than this book, you would not have the first clue where to start writing even the most basic piece of code, and certainly nothing that even approaches ML.The only notable thing about this book at all is that it's the first time ever that I'm going to return a book to Amazon, based on the poor content. I've got a few books that weren't so great, but I've always kept them, as they've never been quite THAT bad. This one manages to be even worse, and is going back.If it were possible to give this book a zero or negative rating, I would. It really is that bad.

I am reading through rad Kuhns brilliant Applied Predictive Modelling, and various other detailed Machine learning texts. (Gave up on numerous books when the maths got too heavy. ) I bought this as a lighter summer refresher read, and to get into applying R Machine learning.This book is really quite impressive in providing a lot of useful insight and explanation into core machine learning principles and application. So after a rather slow start on justifications of machine learning and the necessary setting up of both Python and R Machine learning, the book eventually gets into the real subject matter at Chapt 9, and goes through basic probabilistic, naïve bayes, before concentrating on Gradient descents , Overfitting, PCA and SVD reduction, k Means clustering and K nearest neighbour classification algorithms are easily explained. Then in to the linear methods, Neural nets, SVMs and Random Forests are well explained. The EigenFaces explanation and execution for Face recognition was new to me, even though I have read a  number of detailed deeper books on Machine learning. Extensive links are provided throughout and within context the text to offer expansions on detail, without detracting from the flow.If you want an easier introduction to Machine Learning, without being exposed to excessive maths to cloud your insights, this is an excellent way to get into the subject and start applying the technology in Python and R from the get go. Don't be a ML snob, get this book if you want to get into ML.

Bei einem Buch über Programmiersprachen stellt sich zwangsläufig immer die Frage: für welches Publikum ist so ein Werk geeignet? In diesem Fall sind das User, die bereits gewisse Grundkenntnisse in Python mitbringen. Auch sollte man nicht ganz unbedarft im Thema Datenauswertung und -visualisierung sein.Tiefgreifende mathematische Erläuterungen zu den einzelnen Methoden würde man in dem Buch vergeblich suchen und das finde ich gut so. Die Autoren beschränken sich auf das Elementare, nämlich welche Vor- und Nachteile die jeweiligen Machine Learning Algorithmen mit sich bringen, für welche Datentypen sie am besten geeignet sind, welche Voraussetzungen der User schaffen kann oder muss um sein eigenes Projekt in diesem Kontext zu bestreiten.Wer immer wieder mal ein paar Dinge über Machine Learning aufgeschnappt hat, oder sogar schon einmal unbedarft etwas in die Richtung programmiert hat, wird eine wahre Serie von "Aha!"-Erlebnissen haben. Anschauliche Beispiele aus der Praxis erhöhen die Nachvollziehbarkeit der Methoden und können einen mitunter an dieses Buch fesseln, wie ein guter Roman.Von mir eine klare Kaufempfehlung für Studenten, Doktoranden, Hobbyprogrammierer und Nicht-Mathematiker, die nach einem Startschuss / Kickoff für ihr persönliches Projekt suchen und bislang von der Fülle an Möglichkeiten in scikit-learn überfordert waren.

Man sollte den Titel wörtlich nehmen, es ist primär eine "Introduction" zum Thema klassisches Machine Learning mit Python. Die Kapitel geben einen guten Überblick über die wichtigsten Methoden bezüglich Preprocessing, (un-)supervised Learning sowie Verification. Man sollte jedoch beachten, dass nicht eingehend auf die dargelegten Funktionen eingagengen wird - eine grobe Beschreibung der Standardfunktionalität sowie eine kurze Anwendung ist alles, was man bekommt. Möchte man die Parameter manueller anpassen, muss man zwangsläufig in die Dokumentation gucken.Das ist insbesondere der Punkt, der mir übel aufstößt bei dem Buch: Die Beispiele sind teilweise 1:1 aus der SciKit Learn Dokumentation übernommen. Ich bin ja einerseits dankbar, dass man mir einen Überblick über interessante Merkmale gibt, andererseits erwarte ich tiefergehende Recherche als nur Absätze aus einer frei verfügbaren Dokumentation zu ziehen.Darüberhinaus sind einige Beispiele wenig eingängig, wie z.B. der kapitellange Abschnitt zur Bilderklassifikation. Da wird schlicht und einfach ein Algorithmus nach dem anderen angewandt und jedes Mal das Resümee gezogen "hiermit hat es besser geklappt". Es fühlt sich schlussendlich nach einem Lückenfüller an, ohne dass es mir essentiellen Mehrwert gegeben hat.Zu den wirklich guten Punkten des Buchs gehört das Kapitel über Supervised Learning. Hier macht das kurze Anreißen durchaus Sinn, wo schnell dargelegt wird, wie der jeweilige Algorithmus "denkt" sowie zwei/drei Parameter, auf die man achten soll. Die Zusammenfassungen am Ende der Kapitel gibt die Informationen nochmals schön gebündelt wieder.Sowieso kann man das Buch sehr gut herunterlesen und hat danach das Gefühl, bereit zu sein, es anzuwenden. Bei mir hat die Umsetzung gut geklappt - jedoch habe ich kaum mehr in das Buch geguckt, weil viel tieferes Verständnis in der Praxis nötig ist.Somit empfehle ich das Buch jedem, der seine erste Gehversuche wagen möchte und eine angenehme, wenngleich nicht tiefergehende Einführung zum Thema Machine Learning mit SciKit-Learn braucht. Es ist einen in den ersten Stunden ein treuer Begleiter, der aber bald durch ausführlichere Literatur ersetzt werden muss.

Had a lot of issues trying to get the coding running. The plot_interactive_tree.py used through out the book used a imread module which no longer exists in its old place, you will get a bitter taste of the "dependency hell" of python out from these code. For me I had to give up after a couple days of trying.

Bisher das beste Buch, dass ich zu diesem Thema finden konnte. Sehr verständlich geschrieben, es werden Schritt für Schritt die wichtigsten Classifier vorgestellt und das Parametertuning erklärt. Die vorgestellten Methoden der Feature extraction und feature engeneering sind optimal ausgewählt und gut erklärt. Das Sahnehäubchen ist das Kapitel über Textverarbeitung, in dem nochmal einige sehr brauchbare Methoden vorgestellt werden.Was über den Umfang des Buches hinausgeht (wzB word2vec, gloves) wird zumindest erwähnt, so dass man leicht weiter recherchieren kann. Ich habe es verschlungen.

For this case, "Intro to ML...", there are pages missing as you can see in the video. Also for another book I got, "Hands-on ML ... TensorFlow", although the book content is complete, some pages are not firmly glued to the book spine and as a result, I have to glue them myself.

Das Buch liefert sowohl das theoretische Hintergrundwissen, sowie die praktische Umsetzung von Machine Learning mit Python. Egal ob supervised oder unsupervised Machine Learning, ist alles gut erklärt und nachvollziehbar. Demnach ist es der perfekte Einstieg für die Umsetzung von Machine Learning.

Il libro è fantastico per chi si sta approcciando al mondo del machine learning. Viene lasciato in secondo piano l'aspetto matematico del tutto però è una guida molto valida per iniziare.Dispiace che i grafici siano in bianco e nero obbligando a plottare i grafici su Jupyter notebook per renderli comprensibili

"Introduction to Machine Learning" comes with an exelent overview over standard techniques of machine learning. It focuses on the techniques and implementation in python using mostly the standard samples. The math side is sufficent for people who want to apply the algorithms and not explore the mechanics of the algorithms itself in depth. The lanuage is easy to follow and to the point. All chapter are nicely  structured, ending with an excellent summary.I can recommend the book not only to people who want to implement the algorithms in Python but to everybody who want an introduction to machine learning.

This book is very helpful to beginners to learn and practice data mining with more focus using RapidMiner visual tool.The book introduces all the concepts of data mining techniques in simple and easy manner.I recommend learning data mining using the book along with RapidMiner tool than learning data mining through R.
grt
Superb easy to read book. Algorithms and rapid miner explained in straight forward fashion. Great book

Dieses Buch verfolgt einen ausgesprochen und wohltuend praxisorientierten Ansatz - es ist auf die konkrete Arbeit mit RapidMinder ausgelegt und es gibt die behandelten Daten und Prozesse auf einer Companion-Website. Die Texte sind leicht verständlich, allerdings fallen selbst mir als Nichtmuttersprachler viele Sprachfehler und sprachliche Unsauberkeiten auf. Ein deutliches Manko der Kindle-Edition: Viele Abbildungen sind zu klein.Insgesamt eine sehr gute Einführung in das Thema.
Aporta la visión de lo que es y será la minería de datos y análisis predictivo para las unidades de negocio en el futuro próximo.
Amazing book, it explaines so complicated subjects in a such easy way. Ideal choice for all beginners in « data mining ».

This book is practical guide to realize data mining processes using rapid tool without programming, only click and drop. This includes a lot of figures and tables to help reader understand the algorithms and processors. On each chapter short column to introduce the key concept and typical algorithms using historical use cases for data miners and machine learning practitioners.This book covers two dozens of typical algorithms, i.e. classification: Decision Tree, Naive Bayes, Artificial Neural Network, Support Vector Machine, regression: Linear & Logistic Regression, association analysis: Frequent Pattern Growth, clustering: k-means, Density Base Spatial Clustering Application with Noise(DBSCAN), Self-Organizing Map, anomaly detection: Distance & Density base, Local Outlier and feature selection: Principal Component Analysis(PCA), Forward selection, Backward Elimination and so forth.This book shows how to implement these algorithms step by step among data mining process such as data handling, transforming, modeling and evaluation using powerful open source under ten thousands data examples: RapidMiner Studio Free version. It is possible to extend big data for millions of examples and multi-processors for rapid execution time to get the Middle and Large commercial version.

This book does a nice job of explaining data mining concepts and predictive analytics. The main tool software tool they use is RapidMiner. Curiously RapidMiner was only introduced in chapter 13, the last chapter, although the authors mention you may want to read this chapter first.Some aspects of this book are done really nicely, like when they explain the Iris data set, which is a famous data set of flowers. There is a diagram (pg. 39) in the book showing the flower, and which labels showing which part of the flower is sepal length and which is petal length. I was familiar with the Iris data set before this book, but the diagram taught me what the sepal length meant exactly.There are lots of diagrams throughout the book which show different ways to visualize data and most concepts have clear explanations. The balance was reasonable between explaining techniques and showing how they are used.I would have liked to see more application of some of the concepts and RapidMiner specifically. Overall, this book does a good job of explaining the concepts and techniques of data mining.

I bought this book after struggling to learn rapidminer on my own and needed something that would work as a manual/tutorial.  The book had more emphasis on Data mining concepts and less on rapidminer than I would have liked, but I was able to successfully create my first production model after reading this book.

This is a great book. You can actually use it to pace your hands-on exercises. Nice structure of chapters, which provide lots of ready-made RapidMiner patterns. What needs strengthening is evaluation of each model type specifically, some information was provided within each chapter, but is rather shallow, the chapter on model evaluation is insufficient. What is missing are some insights on how to interpret the results obtained from each model and what you can do with it.
Inner Pages are good, but cover binding is torn and sticked with tape.If customer pays 2200/- for a book they should get perfect quality product.

I have read the first edition of this book, this edition is even better with a lot of additional concepts and of course the updated code. I would highly recommend it anyone who wants to get into applied deep learning with tensorflow. Even if you prefer pytorch still you should read this book because it has very good intuitive explaination for important concepts.

This is in my eyes a very solid machine learning book. Due to the publication date it is more up to date than TESL by Trevor, Hastie et.al. Awesome Guide too all problems that come while preparing for the MLS -C01 Certification Exam.The topics are clearly explained and practical examples are given.However, a few more could be included.The book gives a feel of what the Exam would look like.The book has 3 sections which give a clear picture of the various major machine learning techniques with step-by-step guidance to:• Introduction to Machine Learning. - Clear comparison between AI, ML and DL along with all the AI/ML offering of AWS.• Data Engineering and Exploratory Data Analysis (EDA) - Explains all the various steps involved right from data preparation & transformation, getting a clear understanding of data and visualizing the same.- Different Tools and offerings of AWS for Data Storage and Data Processing.• Data Modeling. - Applying the different ML Algorithms for either Text analysis or Image processing. - Evaluating and optimizing the models on different parameters - Brief high Level know how of Amazon SageMaker with clarity of the different types of instances to choose from to securing the Notebooks, etc...Overall a great read and would definitely recommend the AWS Certified Machine Learning Specialty: MLS-C01 Certification Guide to all the aspirants who wish to take the MLS-C01 Exam.

I love this book so much I bought two copies, in case one copy is not in convenient reach.  It is beautifully written, and very informative. Regardless of who is reading it, one can deepen and expand one's knowledge.  It is also packed with sterling examples that one can use to explain complicated statistical techniques to those with limited subject matter exposure.  I think this book is one that will help others love machine learning and grasp how it will shape our future.

As a non technical user, I was looking for a book that would give me a solid overview of machine learning so that I could understand it's applications and limitations and whether or not we should consider applying these at work. This Dummies guide is that for about 3 chapters and then quickly becomes a starters guide to running your first machine learning projects using R and Python. For me this was too much detail, but if you have a coding background and want to take your first steps in this new application of algorthims it seemed like a good place to start. Just too in-depth for me!
There is a lot of reading about Machine Learning and concepts. Nothing practical. Just concepts explained in simple language. That get's the dummy part delivered.

I studied computer science in the 1990s, so while I do not know anything about Machine Learning (it did not feature in university classes then!), I would not classify myself as a real dummy either. Still this book baffles me. It has a a LOT of content. Unfortunately it is not organized and explained well. It has three issues:1) Poor ordering of chapters. It requires you to first read chapters on the basics of R and Python programming languages and how to install them on your computer. But then the next chapters go back to theory and do not use the languages at all. The chapters are all over the place and I found myself skipping back and forth often.2) Arbitrary and poor explanations. Basic statistical concepts such as the "median" are for some strange reason explained in a lot of detail, while new machine learning terminology is frequently used before it is explained (in later chapters), causing confusion and making the text extremely hard to read.3) Too much text and not enough visuals and charts to explain. A picture can say more than a 1000 words, yet the book keeps using a vast number of words and you end up not quite getting it.I can tell the authors know a lot about the topic, and there is a lot of stuff in here. But they are not able to teach this to dummies in a clear way. I thought that was what this book series was about.

I used to work for cybersecurity company which prided itself in using machine learning algorithms in its product. Everyone who joined had to read this book to be able to talk to analysts and internal tech. The book does a good job giving a general understanding on the different types of machine learning and how to use different programming languages to facilitate machine learning.Not an easy text to chew through but as far as technical literature goes, this is light reading.I have found some other dummy intro books more helpful though, hence the reduced star.

This isn't bad as an in introduction.  It is quite hard to review though.  For people who are interested in the technical side this might seem a bit basic and for those who just want to know a little bit more about the topic  for work, study or just out of general interest it is too technical.It obviously follows the usual For Dummies format but fortunately it isn't as slow moving or laborious as they often are.Ultimately though you might get quite a lot out of this there are plenty of free courses and resources that are more useful.

If you are looking for an introduction to machine learning without getting overwhelmed with mathematics, then this book is a good option. I found that the author generally does a good job in explaining concepts in a simple way.  The book also avoids the jokey style, that in other Dummies books I find can lead to clutter and soon get irritating.This is not a book that will give you depth, but it does a good job of introducing machine learning concepts and toolsets.

Target audience: Graduate students and researchers relatively new to the field of Bayesian learning.(+)Clearly written.High-quality print (figure quality is much higher than that of your average textbook).Fresh approach to HMMs and the Kalman Filter. Yes, the Kalman filter / smoother equations make much more sense when derived from a graphical model.A quick Google search will yield some accompanying lecture videos from the author (on graphical models and sequential learning).Solutions for the "www"-marked exercises are available from the author's webpage.(neutral)Formula-heavy so not for the faint of heart.(-)Little emphasis on computational / implementation aspects. There is no "official" (author's) code for the algorithms discussed in the book - however, there are some good-quality 3rd party implementations available on the web.Most of the exercises simply fill-in the missing steps in the algebra derivations. There are no coding exercises.Some of the data sets used in the book don't seem to be available anymore (at least not at the URL given in the book).Highly recommended. Best when used in conjunction with the 3rd party (MATLAB /Python) codes available on the web.

A great introduction to machine learning. I work in an analytical team and got this book as an addition to our team bookcase.The book serves as a good first step in understanding what machine learning is and include both R and Python code; this is particularly useful as both codes are open source and free to use.Some have said that the book is too basic but I think there is plenty to get your teeth into here. Once this book has been mastered you might want to buy something not for dummies.

I'm not a full convert to the 'Big Data' religion, but Kotu and Deshpande show how to extract insight and meaning from large data sets, in ways that make sense to me. The book is full of worked examples, is perfect for an novice and math challenged person such as myself. I'm sure experienced data analysts will also appreciate the deep knowledge and experience the authors bring to the subject, and will ;find new, different and better ways to tackle some thorny problems.Also notable are Vijay Kotu's credentials: he does this for a living at Yahoo!, is clearly a master practitioner in this new field.Highly recommended for anyone grappling with ecommerce, wanting to understand why and how to maximize conversions from browsing to buying.5 stars.

It is not for beginners. Read this only if you have sufficient knowledge in ML. Beauty of this book lies in the explaining mathematical nature of the data & algorithms. It has very good recipes to make your knowledge more deeper and it also covers wide variety of topics like Hebbian Learning, Graphical Models, Bayesian Networks etc. Should be an excellent read for experts.

Although the book is pretty short (~120p) it covers all the key areas of graph representation learning in an informative and engaging manner. The algorithmic derivations are always clear and well described, and the book quickly covers off the headlines and gotchas. Highly recommended primer, my only wish is that it had been accompanied by coded examples.
