I've been working in software development for nearly 25 years, having studied engineering at University. My background as an engineer has always left me at a slight disadvantage when talking with colleagues who studied computing, as they seem to have an understanding of all sorts of areas of how a computer actually works that I've never been taught. (I've mostly managed to get by without knowing about them, but I've always felt a bit of a bluffer as a result!)This book, therefore, is an utter godsend to someone like me. It explains, in clear layman's terms, all about the details of how a computer actually works - how the processor works, how memory is accessed, how caching works etc. Even peripheral details - networking, storage media, 3D graphics - all are covered in enough detail to enable a layman (or even an engineer) to gain a good understanding of them. In simple terms, if you read this book, you will know how a computer works.The style is very good - clear and readable, with plenty of diagrams. The only small caution I would give is that the cover and title are slightly misleading - this is not a book about the Raspberry Pi; indeed the Pi is really only relevant to a couple of chapters, but the Pi is a hot topic in computing now, and the inventor of the Pi is one of the authors, so I think that can be forgiven!In terms of audience, this is a serious textbook - I'd say it is aimed at A-level to first-year undergraduate students rather than younger children - but it is nonetheless very approachably written.As the title says, I wish I'd read this at the start of my career rather than half-way through it, but I'm making up for it now. If you have any interest in working in software or computing, this book is a must; I cannot recommend it highly enough.

You really need to know what this book is, and what it isn't.It's not a beginner's manual for the Pi.It's not, in any shape or form, a book of projects for the Pi.It's (arguably) not a book for complete beginners to the subject of Computer Architecture.It's not (even more arguably, I suppose) even REALLY a book about the Pi at all.This is a meaty, detailed look at how the innards of your computer (any computer) work, and a history of how they reached their current state.  While it makes occasional references to the Pi, after the first few chapters these are almost incidental.Personally, I'd say it's pitched ideally at people who know a BIT about how computers work, who are interested in deepening that knowledge and learning some computing history along the way.  It's perfect for this audience, and no, you don't need to have a Pi to read and profit from it.

Although this book goes into detail about how the components of the Raspberry Pi work and interact with each other, computer architecture uses similar components so you also get an understanding how computers work.This is a well written and detailed book. You can tell that the authors know in detail the Raspberry Pi, in fact one of the authors is a co-creator of the Raspberry Pi.Not only does the book give a simple explanation, but it also goes into great detail and includes diagrams and drawings to help explain the processes.This is a book that you can pick up anytime and start reading anywhere. I can remember the old ZX81, ZX Spectrum, Amiga and C64 days and this book bought some of those memories of many hours programming the Spectrum. I did not know how the components interacted, but can still remember the PEEK and POKE commands.If you are interested in the Raspberry Pi or on how computers work, this is a great starting point.I enjoyed reading it even though some of the topics went way over my head.

If you want to learn from someone significant in the industry, then Eben Upton is going to be the figure for telling you about the Raspberry Pi. So, it's off to a great start. This aims to be more than just a completely dry discussion, this outlines a little of how Upton got into the field and what was trying to be achieved with the Pi, and some of the things that can be useful. In terms of the principles of computing, with programs as data, details about the structure of a modern computer, etc, this is reasonably complex and detailed - and certainly at least on a par with the kinds of books that BCS recommends for learning about the structure of computers for their Certificate in IT modules, if not more detailed in some areas (although BCS prefers more discussion about Machine Code). Definitely this puts it at Undergraduate level detail and complexity.If you're wanting to lean a bit about why computers are structured as they are, something about what came before (with the trials of fixed wiring, pre-digital memory, punched tape, etc - all a bit before my time as I started in the magnetic tape era), and then move onto a discussion about how a computer works and specifics about the Raspberry Pi and what you can do it it and how its physically different to larger computers, then this is an interesting, well-written book.If you're only interested in learning how to use a computer and don't want or need the full details, or if you just want to learn to do a bit of scripting on the Pi, then you don't really need this, but if you genuinely want to learn more about Computer Architecture in general and the Raspberry Pi's design decisions in particular, then this is the book - coming from Upton for the Pi at least it's the definitive reference.

Got this book years ago, but life got in the way and didn't use it, but recently found my son tinkering with the Pi I bought, with the help of this book. He's found it to be really intuitive and quick to reference, I was really pleased considering he normally uses Youtube for anything instructional, but he needed to go deeper on this and found this book the ideal aid

It is an interesting book about a good topic but one that I am very ignorant of.I hoped I could absorb knowledge reading this book but to be honest I am not able to do so.It is an entertaining book and I am sure it is very informative but at my level of knowledge it flew straight over my head.It does have a lot to impart on the inner workings of computers and how they have been developed. Just not really right for someone who is advanced in years and zero computing knowledge.If you are into computing and want to broaden and build on what you know then this is a good one to buy.

This is a very good book for learning how computers work.  It explains things very clearly.The title is a bit misleading - it is not a book on the Raspberry Pi.  It does not say that it is but people might get the impression it is.(I uploaded 10 photos.  Sometimes Amazon does not publish all photos, and may publish them in the wrong order.  If that happens, please bear with me - I will try to resolve it).I have photographed the Contents pages so you can see what it covers (photos 2-7).  I have also photographed a few pages from the book to get an idea of what it is like - on decimal, binary and hexadecimal  (photos 8-10) .I must tell you that it is a black & white book, though for what it covers it does not really need colour.  Colour would be good but it increases the cost - I imagine that the writers preferred to keep the cost, and therefore the sale price, down.I found it very informative.Price at time of review: £15.69.
The core ideas and functions well explained. A book to read first and then digging into specialization. Helps to grasp the essentials and to have a base for the next level

The book is short but I think that's it's strong suit.  I suspect it's usefulness will wear off as this information becomes more foundational knowledge through my research into ML but as a beginner in the field, I find that having an easy to navigate reference book for the algorithms I need to learn to become an ML expert is very useful.
This is a fantastic book for the absolute beginner. Although extremely elementary in content, it is very useful for someone with no background
Good easy super intro read
Felicitaciones, muy buen libro. He encontrado todo lo que buscaba y fatos adicionales, muy bien enfocado para quien se quiere iniciar en el tema
Touches all important terminology and explanations are simple so even a firmware engineer like me could follow easily. Easy read. I could finish it in two flights. Now time to practise. Thank you.
Good first read on the subject of Machine Learning.You will want to dig deeper after reading this book.Easy review of basic algorithms too.
Basic but we'll presented. As it says "for the beginners". But a worth taking your time starting point. Recommended to all
The author did a very good job in explaining machine learning principles and tools. This is not the book for you if you are looking for more than the basics or high level overview.
I've been curious about this subject for a while and recently started to do some research.  This book provided a nice high-level understanding of the topic and it's related subject matter.

As an AI enthusiast, I like that this manuscript provides the breadth of knowledge around the emerging field of automated machine learning.  The coverage of multiple clouds in particular helps the reader to understand the state of the eco-system, along with its open source components.  We quickly see AI platforms adopting AutoML, and it is timely that practitioners learn about this technology.  Highly recommended.
This book was a life saver. Easy read, precise, with examples! What more can be asked of a textbook? Buy.
One of the best books on the subject.

It's an amazing book to start learning ML without programming tools, just excel. It's easy to ready and it provides you a complete guide to start from scratch with the subject. It has very good examples and real-life problems to practice
explained important concepts in a lucid manner with the right combination of theory and proofs. necessary first book for grasping concepts of ML

Attention to those who might pick up this book without having a strong background in data science or mathematics--large chunks of this book will probably be a slow slog for you, as it was for me.I am very surprised this book is rated so highly.  There are so many concepts/things thrown out there as if they were common knowledge, when they're not. By the point the book starts diving into coding basics around Chapter 13, I realized I needed to find another, better book. I've found free online resources and an online course that have made Python much more digestible.

I found this book to be a great resource for reference, although I'm not sure it's for people completely lacking statistical or machine learning knowledge.  The author references ML terms quite early on without really explaining what they are.However, in my case, I was using this book to jog my memory of concepts I'd learned but forgotten in college.  I majored in stats, with a focus in ML, then spent 2 years doing front end development.  Now I'm going back to machine learning, and this book is the perfect, short and sweet summary of the terms and concepts needed to understand everything at a high level.It's a great reference to have on your bookshelf - especially to remind yourself quickly or a term, or if you're trying to compare and decide on what algorithm you need to use for a new dataset.

New to ML but have done programming in previous jobs. Found this book extremely helpful. Gives a great introduction while instigating your curiosity to explore and learn more. Love it. Would request the author to write a sequel.

This book was written in plain English and really meant for people without a lot of Math background to understand. Unlike other books such as "the 100 page ML book" which is full of math, this book explains the concepts very well, without using a whole lot of math. This book is NOT for those who are serious about digging into data science or machine learning. But it's good for everyone else who wants to get a high level overview of what ML/Data science is about.

Judging this book by the cover, I had expected a good read. Upon seeing the book and flipping through, I felt a little letdown because I could see that it was written in MS Word, Arial font, and had a few irritating things left at default settings. Once I got into the subject matter, I easily looked past formatting issues and really enjoyed the material. Very interesting work and a great place for someone like me who has little to no clue what machine learning is to start.
Just Google what is machine learning and read the content on the first page of results, you don't even need to go to the second page to find everything covered in this book. You're welcome.

I would like to tell everybody, this two books are really great for who really want to jump in machine learning field. Lots of real world scenario, prefect example is one of the best features of these books.I really enjoy and learn lots of basic things to start my career in Machine Learning.

Just received this book today and saw that there were missing text that make it look like a blank column on the even number pages for all paragraphs from page 2 to page 76.I'm sure this is an Amazon printing issue.This rating is not on the content of the book. I will rate it once I receive a readable replacement.....UPDATE....Recieved replacement book one day early. All of the printing looks great and returning the miss printed book through UPS was seamless. Thanks.
Book is really basic.If you feel like you know what machine learning is then you should already skip this book

I have been reading some ML books. This is one of my favorites. It is clear, concise. A great source for beginners.There are many terms discussed, also, some exercises.I wish there could be more exercises, but it is a nice step to start.There are many recommendations at the end of the book. I recommend that if you want some good base in ML, take a course, and use these books as a reference or to clear some topics. A must read for a beginner!
Received intact
Really amazing, undoubtedly the best.
Incredible way for parents to share with their child a relevant and upcoming topic of machine learning in a a fun way. Thank you Dr. Dhoot.
cover is a slightly worn

One of the best books on probabilistic approaches to machine learning.  I like that the author not only describes various techniques but also takes the time to try to pull out the intuitions behind concepts, compares techniques to help the reader understand what makes a technique special and provides a detailed bibliography so that details can be followed up in the original literature.  The book covers a huge swath of material from basic theory of Bayesian reasoning all the way to recent work in deep learning models. I find I learn something new every time I pick it up.  The first edition had a lot of errors, but there are published errata and I understand that later editions have been fixed.

In my mind, this is the new definitive textbook for anyone in Machine Learning.  It covers a very broad range of topics very well; presenting them clearly but not avoiding necessary details.  While it is not a complete replacement for any specific area or technique, it provides a general background that allows someone within the field who does not specialize in an area to gain a solid understanding of the fundamentals.

This book is well illustrated and easy to follow. The author does a great job of simplifying the concept so a toddler can understand.  I recommend this book if you wish to expose your kids to the top technology of today and the future.
**Spark your baby's love for reading by stocking up on books from the Tinker Toddlers Collection. They are designed to capture little imaginations.  Explore their own curiosities.
Every book is great! The author has done a really good job in helping parents with starting early. My baby enjoys all the colorful images in this book.
Explain ML in a very clear an understanding way! I loved de analogy of supervised, unsupervised learning!Reinforce learning was not as clear.
What a great way to introduce kids to technology!

I hate the way the author represents equations and algorithms in this book. I feel like he just looked at other info and re-packaged it in a way to look novel. Just preview it and you'll understand. Then get on Wikipedia and actually see something you can interpret.

Being a practitioner of math algorithms, I use it as a comprehensive theoretical reference. By far has been the most useful book in my ML collection. One still often needs to dig deeper thru the references to implement an industry strong algorithm, but this is a good initial kick into the methodology area to be used.
Great book for those who are not from the statistics field and want to learn machine learning using a probabilistic approach.

It is an excellent book, ideal for my work and, I imagine, for many others in need of advancement into machine learning from the various fields of statistics.  The only thing is, there is an equation I believe is incorrect, and it turns out to be one I really need to understand.  I have the fifth printing, and it is on page 118, section 4.3.3, equation number (4.91).  I have written to the suggested email for Kevin Murphy a couple of times, asking if the equation says what it means, or if it might be some kind of error.  Have not heard back, but perhaps I will soon.  This is a great book, which may surprise people who are not "just at" the level of training needed to follow the development.  But the target audience is, I think quite large and in need of his guidance.

Background: I am first year master student in Computer Science at Santa Clara University.I am sure this textbook is very readable if you know the math notations, which you can refer them in the reference. The book has all you need to master the most beautiful part of Machine Learning.Try to study this, this book will help you to do a machine learning research and publish articles in academic journals.
A great ML reference.
Very thorough, useful and practical introduction to genetic algorithms. Found it better than almost all similar books. It shows a good way to use deap libraries as well.

Wow this is an awesome GA book which use DEAP to demonstrate how to solve easily various type of problems using GA. This is the best book ever in GA.It comes with complete codes which can used in my projects.  I learnt a lot. Thank you!

仕事関係で購入して独学しています（QSAR分野でfeature selectionなど案外行けそうな感じがするので）。数学の内容を数式など使わずに平易な言語表現で語っており非常にやさしい本です。英語が問題なければ普通に一日1 chapter進められる。完読したら実務的にGAが使えると考えられます。追記：niching & sharingの解説と実装はこの本の肝要と思います。勉強になりました。必要な事前スキル・Pythonの基本作法・最低限の数学知識（高校生ないし学部教養レベル）・Machine learningの概念（ほんとうに概念だけ）

Starts with an overview of genetic algorithms (GA) then introduces the DEAP framework for evolutionary computation, which is used in the book for the various example problems/solutions. All of the code is explained and as you read about the examples and inspect the code, you can get ideas for possible applications of GA to real problems. Very gentle learning curve, but you should know some basic Python before starting this book.

I wanted break into GA and apply it to real-world applications as quickly as possible. This book is the very book I was looking for. It breaks down and explains complicated concepts clearly and concisely. The sample code is easy to follow and understand. There are no difficult maths or even challenging sentences. Unlike many other books on the field, it doesn't try to pile up words with windy content. This book is concise, straightforward, and well written. From an engineer's eyes, it delivered the information in the most efficient way. Also to my pleasant surprise, this book covers related topics like PSO and ALift that I didn't expect. It doesn't talk about these topics extensively but gives me critical pointers for further learning.This book is ideal for someone who is:- new to GA.- already experienced with Python.- constrained by time.- looking for a broad coverage on this topic.It's not a good fit for someone who is:- unfamiliar with Python.- looking for theories or rigorous maths.- looking for in-depth knowledge (although this book links to in-depths materials).

I had no experience in this topic and it took me sometime to find a problem in my field I could apply this to but once I tried it was really good to use this book as a learning platform. Definitely recommended

The book doesn't get to even the first snippet of code until the third chapter. It starts with a pretty thorough introduction to Genetic Algorithms that covers the whole first section. I would expect a "hands-on" book to introduce these topics along side code samples. What samples the book does include are often one or two lines out of context without much explanation for how to use them. The Kindle formatting is also off so each numbered entry in a list of paragraphs is indented. This leads to  pages that look like the attached photo that make reading the book more of a chore than a pleasure.

This was the best Genetic Algorithm book ever in my life. Due to its simplicity and pesudo-code-like nature of the Python language, the example codes does not interfere with the readers’ intellectual engagement into the beauty of evolutionary algorithms.

The code examples were easy to follow. The author did a nice job of explaining a complex concept in understandable terms. I really enjoyed the book. It helped me gain a better understanding of the use of genetic algorithms.

Good book on GANs.Familiarity with tensorflow and keras essential. Working knowledge of python is mandatory.Codes are downloadable.Takes time to understand the details, as the theory is not discussed in detail.I just saw the new price. Rs. 3,500+. The book is really not worth this price. There are many substitutes.

So far I found this to be one of the only books on Generate deep learning. The first two chapters are very well explained, however from chapter 3 on, the book fails. The explanation; only theoretical, is good with simple analogies, but the book in no way educates the reader on how to actually code their way through. The packages that have been imported etc. Only code snippets are presented and the explanation is redenered not so complete when you can't complete the rest of the chapter without writing your code. p.s. the prerequisites for the book is only python with basic linear algebra but you would only be able to get through the the book if your referring for the real content of the book from François Chollets' Deep learning with Keras and Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn, Keras, and TensorFlow, 2nd Edition. Kind of disappointed

before having this book, I was an absolute beginner in generative deep learning. Now, I at least have understood some concepts along with code. not giving 5 stars because this is a black and white print, many concepts mentioned here refer to coloured diagrams, but the diagrams are black and white.

Awesome book !!  The author has very good writing skills. He has explained complex theories by pictorial & diagrammatic way which makes things really cool. Specially GAN, Text generation parts were very good. Some mathematical theories were also well covered.

Book is in the way that it needs some basic introductory knowledge about Machine learning and Deep learning. Even though the book explains it from the beginning, a slight knowledge of ML is good for moving forward..

I have read multiple books on advanced topics of Neural networks like GANs, but no other book comes close to how well the author has explained the concepts. The individual topics covered is very complex but author has done an incredible job of simplifying things and making us understand the core principles in an intuitive way.

Author has beautifully crafted engaging stories behind the intuition of various generative models which are typically dry to read. Completed the book in a day like a story book !  -Each block of code snippets are nicely explained.  -Typos are present here and there. But I hope it will be corrected in the next edition.Hope to see many books like this in the future.

This is a good introductory text to generative models and it is easy to read. The author likes to use lead-in story but some of them are too long-winded and I often had to skim several pages quickly to get to the technical stuff.I was particularly interested in learning GANs to create images but disappointed to find that it uses only simple models with toy datasets. For example, there are many freely available online tutorials on DCGAN and CycleGAN; much of the code in the book were also taken from open-sourced Github repo.Therefore, I went to buy a couple more books and found "Image Generation with TensorFlow" to be the best for my need as it covers not only the basics but also state-of-the-art models like StyleGAN and image transformer.
Very entertaining reading. Print quality could be better, but that's on Amazon, not on the author I guess...

The book is really a good overview of use-cases, has code samples, some overview of the maths and is reasonably up-to-date. I had some knowledge of GANs prior to reading this book but was missing knowledge on actual implementation to get going, this book filled that gap very well and gave a bunch of terms, definitions and references so I could get going and continue on my own after. Top marks.

The first half the book is stuff anyone with experience doing any serious sort of data analysis should already know. This also includes several  chapters on installing R and Python. If the reader needs all those chapters devoted to installing R and Python and the necessary, then there is almost no chance that that same reader will get anything out of this book. The second half of the book appears to cram many different statistical concepts into a few chapters and hope something sticks.
good book. Simple writing, very friendly to read and capture concepts.
very basic book.
A really very awsm book..most recommended if wanna gt insight into machine learning..

This is a good book and covers a lot of the current topics. Probably the best available book if you are looking for the theoretical understanding of ML. Don't expect programming examples. Works best when coupled with some lecture series and outside code. Heavy on content.

Even after working with production pipelines for 2 yrs as a Data Scientist, this book proves it's worth in the Deep Learning space mostly. It also discusses the training and deployment of TF Models at scale. A really good reference for basic ML Algos like SVM and K-Means, talks about in depth application with mathematics included.
Book is very heavy with more than 800 pages but the paper quality and the colour print makes you fall in love with this book. I highly recommend this book.
The best book for beginners into the machine learning !Very nicely explained with beautiful code and images.Go ahead and purchase. Certainly you will love reading this☺️
Very well detailed book on machine learning for students, researchers and market professionals. This book makes machine learning very easy.

good book on data science.

The paper quality, colors and the binding is really top notch! The paper is matte(as it should be) and not glossy as mentioned in previous reviews, which is perfect for reading (Got the 4th Indian Reprint edition : November 2021).No complaints on the book, but a complimentary bookmark would have made it better.

I'm currently on a course learning Machine Learning and family and this book was recommended (well earlier revision), but it explains things well with good examples.I ordered on Kindle as much prefer reading that wayRecommended if new to ML/DL/NN etc

Wow! This is a very specialised book indeed. If you are a wannabe programmer/coder than this book may be out of your league (unless you aim to be in the top team). If you only want to be able to program and run a Raspberry Pi there are better suited books for this specific purpose. However, if you really want to understand the very fine detail as to how computers really work, and the Pi in particular this is the very best book I have seen on the subject for many years (IMHO). Fantastic detail and good explanation. Therefore best suited for trainee uber geeks or those who can spare the time and effort to learn. Wannabe programmers/coders  who do put in the time to read and understand this book will have a huge head start on those who do not. Everything is included especially the kitchen sink.

Way back when the first IBM PCs became available I had an excellent book called "Inside the IBM PC" by Peter Norton, in many ways this book is an update of that. It explains the constituent parts and software of a microcomputer in a comprehensive, down to earth way.  It is just packed full of useful information on how things work, essential to know when things don't. I found the chapter on WiFi really useful as it comprehensibly covered some of the problem areas; my house is built with foil-backed plasterboard, common in the 1970s, and is a nightmare for wireless and we have to use repeaters. Overall an essential book for anyone interested in microcomputers, not just the Raspberry Pi.
OK

Really nicely put together covering virtually everything you might want to know about the history leading up to the Raspberry Pi. The book is clean, clear and no-nonsense in it's approach. Great style and easy to read. I have to say that the font is really clear too although it's small, it's still easy to read (which is very unusual). This is a really great book - I love it!HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!! AAA+++

There are very few aspects of computers generally that are not covered by this book. Although it is aimed at the Raspberry Pi computer, it can help anybody involved with computing to get a handle on pretty much all aspects of computing.  The book has 480 pages of content plus 26 pages just indexing the content. I have been working in the computer industry over 30 years, and I studied computing at University, this book is teaching me new stuff, and explaining stuff in a clear straight forward way. The six authors have an extremely wide range of experience in the field of computing generally, and the Raspberry Pi specifically. It is hard to review this book without going into extreme generalisations, but you REALLY, REALLY have to get this if you have any interest in computing at all. It is a joy to read.As other reviews have said, I wish I had this book when I started out on my computing journey. If you are looking to get a book for someone for Christmas, get this for them, you can't go wrong, otherwise, get this book for yourself!

This book was clearly written by authors who wished to convey their love of the details of how computers work from software down to the hardware level.  It was obviously not written for profit, but to support the education goals of the Raspberry Pi Foundation.Ever since my first involvement with programming machine language on an IBM 1620 in 1962, I have been fascinated with the interface between software and computer hardware.  Each chapter starts out gently with a historical narrative about how that chapter's topic evolved from the early days of computing and proceeds right up to the very sophisticated techniques used in modern computers.  It provides the details of processor pipelining, memory caching strategies, graphic acceleration, video compression, how Ethernet and wifi networking challenges are resolved,  methods of digital storage, and much more.  All this explained with great care providing an emphasis on details that are often ignored in other computer books.  The only thing missing was a discussion of the Bluetooth interface of the Raspberry Pi 3.There were times when I failed to understand a sentence only to re-read it and find that in my haste I overlooked or misread a key word.  Every word, sentence, and paragraph is important.  Computer architecture has numerous acronyms and with very few exceptions, each is introduced properly and referenced in the book's detailed index.  This book has been proof-read with extreme care and its content written with true expert knowledge.  It is a masterpiece with 500 carefully-written pages, numerous enlightening diagrams, and costing only about $20.

I'm a software engineer at one of the big tech companies, so I'm not a complete beginner but I've still learned a huge amount from this book (and I've only got as far as the chapter operating systems).  It's a bit of an odd book in that it spends some time explaining binary (which is essential to understand for the rest of the book), but it seems hard to believe that anyone not already knowing how binary numbers work would want to go deep into exactly how magnetic signals are stored on a hard drive (several chapters later).  Still, there's plenty in here I didn't know already so I shouldn't make assumptions I suppose.  If you work with or are interested in computers and want to really understand how they work down to the physics then this is a good book for you.

I wish I could give it 4.8 stars. This is a great book. Too many computer architecture books are unapproachable (half the book is mathematical notation). This book is nothing like that. It explains things very simply and is very approachable. My only complaint is that they sometimes use acronyms without explicitly defining them and perhaps assume you'll infer the meaning from the context (an example is "LPDDR2", the "LP" is nowhere defined - I assume from context it stands for "Low Power" but that was never clarified in the book, the acronym is simply introduced with no definition). Even so, I highly recommend this book for the motivated reader - just know you'll have to Google some things on occasion.

This book has very thorough explanation for anyone who wants to learn computer architecture beyond the basics. The author gets into many details of how a machine works from hardware to software. It doesn't get too deep into some details which you will learn in the computer architecture and engineering textbooks, but gives you some intro into how things work and provide direction on where to look for further study.

Excellent overview of state of the art computing including instruction sets, buses, memory architecture, compiler technology and so on.  The Raspberry Pi is described in some detail but other architectures are mentioned as well.  The authors have also included historical notes which help the reader understand just how we got where we are.Experience programming and interfacing microcontrollers is helpful but not required.  The material is authoritative without being overly formal.  Anyone interested in understanding modern micro technology will find this a worthwhile read.

I think this is a great text considering the vast array of topics covered by Bishop in this book. The best thing I liked about the book are the fantastic insights the author has provided on various methods and their usage limitations, sometimes in very easy to understand language and studded with some real practical experience going behind it. One thing which I found rather missing was the excessive use of equations without much dwell into their derivations, which can sometimes confuse the first time reader, but when worked diligently by hand, would make the stuff clearer. Said that, the book is a great text for someone to gain latest perspectives on the field from the author's rich research experience. I would definitely recommend someone who wants a fairly broad and usable knowledge about this field.

I was surprised to see that this book received only four stars, seeing as how useful this book is to me on a day-to-day basis, yet after some thought I think I agree. There are some fantastic chapters in this book. Chapter 3 on linear regression and its Bayesian variants in particular is beautiful and deep. Other chapters falter, like chapter 8 on Bayesian networks which is maddening. The book has an emphasis on deriving formulas as opposed to showing practical examples; those looking for more practical matters should read   The Elements of Statistical Learning by Trevor Hastie           instead. I find the book is very useful as a reference when elaborating non-standard machine learning methods. The appendices on probability distributions and matrix properties are indispensable, in particular. Some widely used methods are glossed over (boosting for example), while others, like the relevance vector machine, are described in detail despite not being well-represented in the literature. That being said, the breadth of methods presented in the book is much greater than in other similar books, and I frequently reread it when I get stumped on a machine learning problem.
The Elements of Statistical Learning by Trevor Hastie
written succinctly and clearly for understanding machine learning, probability and statistics
If you work on or are a grad student in related area, this is highly recommended. very comprehensive.
I received the book earlier than expected, and the quality of book is super! Thanks, I will buy books from seller again.

This book is quite good in the material it covers. However, other aspects, for example, decision trees, are only briefly covered. I think this is because this book provides a NIPS (Neural Information Processing Systems conference) view of the world, where only certain aspects of the Machine Learning world are accepted.This book, together with Duda, Hart, and Stork's book   Pattern Classification (2nd Edition)           make an excellent pair.
Pattern Classification (2nd Edition)
Although parts of the book are written a little elementary for someone with mathematical training it's a good comprehensive introduction to the subject
it's a nice book but I just don't like the writing style.
Learnt everything there is to know about Recommender Systems with the help of this book!

I often feel that machine learning books are either too high-level and do not have any benefit for someone with some fundamental understanding of the topic, or they are so technical / mathematical that you would need to be an expert on the topic. The author strikes a very good balance, providing more technical background for readers with a basic grasp of the subject, and offering potentially new perspectives for readers with a higher level of technical expertise. As a plus, the author’s tongue-in-cheek style of writing makes it an enjoyable read.
Sehr gute praktische Beispiele sowie sind die mathematischen Formeln sehr verständlich erklärt.

This book is outstanding, it provides enough theory mixed with real-world examples and code to learn what is necessary to build and curate recommender systems. If you are a beginner, the book will help you learn. If you are an old dog, you can learn new tricks.

I like this book because of the practicality. I bought this book because it teaches you the whole flow of gathering data  to all the way to recommending items to users. I wanted a book that paints this picture and it does it for me in a very simple and approachable way.
This books give you a complete sense of how design a recommender system. It breaks down the steps and digs into details supported with figures and code! Great job Kim Falk!
This is a very good book, and is easy to follow. Especially with the code samples, it really makes the algorithm clear to understand.
Worst book ever, even if they give me this book for free, i will throw it
I will need a second pass on the book but I think it gave a great introduction to the world of machine learning. Not boring at all!

Very disappointing book. It’s almost unreadable at times because the author tries to explain the most basic concepts - it’s as if he’s written it for people who haven’t visited planet earth before, let alone those who haven’t visited machine learning. Digression after digression - like Tolkien, but less fun - he seems to take the longest route possible to explain a concept. Succinct and clear it isn’t.It isn’t a long book, and consider these digressions, it feels too lightweight. The author tries to marry all of the terminologies and ideas from various fields - like statistics, mathematics, probability etc - but in doing so, it reads like a dictionary of terms at times, losing the overall flow of the idea.If the author had treated the reader with a bit more intelligence, we may have had a better read. It’s a shame because I have quite a few of the “MIT Essential Knowledge” books, this is the poorest I’ve read. As other reviewers have noted, it feels rushed, and the writing style is yawn-worthy.Hey, I know, this is machine learning, it’s hardly going to win any literary prizes, but I’d recommend looking elsewhere for a primer on the subject.

If you are looking for a brief overview of what Machine Learning is all about and a beginners level explanation of a number of the most common algorithms used, then this book is for you; it assisted in me getting a basic understanding of the subject, before I started a Machine Learning module. This book just introduces the discipline, it is not aimed at ML practitioners.A good introduction to a complicated, but essential, subject.

I would highly recommend this book if you like to conceptually understand the different topics and models of Machine Learning as it exists today. Ethem does a great job at explaining the big picture through common real-life examples, using relatively standard math. It's a great book for those who don't want to learn how to program Machine Learning but would rather understand how Machine Learning might influence design, strategy, and culture.
The book is too hard to follow. Explanations provided ramble on and on. I think the author wants to show how clever they are rather thn share knowedge.

The first book on a challenging topic that I’ve been able to fully understand all the way through the end of the book. Oliver does a fantastic job translating the difference between the most popular machine learning algorithms and the ways in which each one of them works. I did have to read each section multiple times until I fully grasped the concept, if you do the same you will have a solid starter foundation upon which to build upon to start your own research.
I am an experienced professional but a novice in ML. This book is awesome, and provides the fundamentals to build upon, for grasping the topics easily in future readings of more dense books. Read it!

I knew next to nothing about machine learning and artificial intelligence. I am a now-retired physician wanting to have hans-on knowledge on these subjects. Very readable book! Easy to follow and to test yourself on your own computer.

The book it's a pretty good introduction to the machine learning field as the name suggests. It's enough to give you a quick grasp of some of the most used concepts in the ML/deep learning field. Nevertheless, the author also explains the pros and cons of both methodologies and when they are useful or a complete waste of time/money.
Really good overview of AI andML. Content covers most of the major areas. Examples are a little week, I would have preferred an example that is used through the entire process.

This book covers the basics through implementation of simple machine learning. It was entertaining and highly educational. I especially appreciated the effort made by the author to walk a newbie through installation of a new programming environment and then using it to produce something useful. After reading this book, I'm ready to start my first ML experiment.
This wasn't exactly what I was thinking it was, but it turned out to be something that I feel I needed. Happy that I bought it anyway.

For a beginner like me, this was a very good introduction. Would have loved a bit more detail in each section, and the python appendix at the end is a waste of space, but other than that it was good.Also, on Kindle it had a bunch of random highlighted paragraphs.

I'm an R user and so the Python code sections weren't of much interest to me; but those sections are small. Most of the book deals with description of machine learning techniques rather than examples. I think this is a great quick read to introduce machine learning, and that it could serve as a good reference book, or as a springboard for more in depth reading.
A very readable introduction.

Like a review article in a good science magazine. A pretty sound collection of recent trends and technology developments. For the ones to go for more well curated citations lead to further more in-depth (scientific) articles. It takes a quite american view as AI in China is touched upon an Europe and India goes unmentioned. Yet Machine Learning is worth time, effort and money to read.
An "easy" read and a good introduction into the topic of Machine Learning. Gives a good overview on the various models and approaches to ML
It felt a bit self-indulgent, not clearly written. The content is great and the authors are knowledgeable but this isn’t accessible entry-level information. YouTube videos were much more helpful.

Un breve excursus sulle varie strategie dell' Intelligenza artificiale per mettere in grado le macchine di imparare dai dati (invece di essere programmate riga per riga di codice dall'uomo). Interessante e aggiornato.
Great for beginner.You can find your way~This book contains ML theory summary andAbility for ML work.Go next detailed book after read this book.
I'm hooked just a beginner but can't stop reading, transferable gave me a little edge on a few things I learned years back.
Gives details of photon programming but also a great overall review of the AI field
This is a book for absolute begginers. To get basic understanding you can read this book.  It gives 360 degrees view
Good read
Great book to get basic understanding of importance and actuality of Machine Learning. It's easy to read and understand provided concepts.
Best introduction for ML,
Great book. It is very detailed, but is still written in a comprehensible way. I look forward to reading more of Theobald's work.
Easy read
Felt like I got through the first 2 weeks or so of university lectures for ML 101 in just a few hours of input and for next to no cost. Thanks!
It’s a good book for beginners to start with. It’s pretty understandable and easily illustrated by samples, and examples .
Alles ist anhand von sehr anschaulichen Beispielen und Code erklärt, die theoretischen Grundlagen sind für meinen Geschmack aber manchmal etwas zu kurz.
Very good for beginners.

I was interested in a book which approached the topic using python. this book does it very well with examples. Although I am from ML major many moons ago, it use to be C or C++ during my college years. thus I found that the author did a great job introducing ML and how it was executed in Python.
This book told nuts and bolts of creating machine learning models. I would recommend this to people who already  understand a moderately in depth overview of machine learning.
Examples were easy to follow and help understand the concepts.

Book contained good information and covered the a range of methods. Unfortunately the content isn’t any different from what can easily be found and radier learned from a YouTube video. Overall, good content but nothing special.
Easy read. Recommend the author.
Great book with full support for Matlab library.

The book is an overview of the many statistical methods which are associated with Machine Learning.  Unfortunately the chapter on each subject was very thin and cannot be applied without already be an expert in that area.  A good reference book, but a poor learning book.

Decent reference book but not the best for actually learning. This book reads like a collection of Wikipedia articles. It covers many topics and can be useful as a refresher. But if you're actually trying to learn something, look elsewhere. This book simply lays out all the formulas without much explanation.

The detail content of this book has already been written well by the other reviewers.I agree this may be currently the best textbook on machine learning.And I would need to refer this book too for understanding or relative works.But the way this book explains would be boring as encyclopedia does, enormous collections or groups of concept, less organized fashion to make a story for the subject.Before buying this book, it could be helpful to think of the trait first.

This is not a book that you can read chapter after chapter. That was not my expectation. But given its 1000+ pages, I was hoping it would be a good reference. Unfortunately, I did not find this book to be useful and promptly returned it. It comes across as if the author is summarizing his knowledge, irrespective of whether that material is obsolete or not, and whether it is relevant to the latest thinking. Very little on deep learning, recursive networks, reinforcement learning etc. Similarly, very little on applications such as natural language processing.

Complet and technically deep enough to undertake many ML projects. My AI class is based on that book and recommend it to anyone who want to learn ML with the probabilistic approach. Knowing Matlab helps as a complement to this book so you can transpose more easily the concept into code.

The book is written as if it were a reference volume for a Professional already very familiar with the field. Entire subjects are simply glossed over with a reference to the journal paper  that originated the idea. Almost no background is provided for the necessary probability or conceptual background. I can't recommend this for students looking for an introduction to the field. I wish I knew of a better alternative though.

This book does a good job of motivating modern ML theory (and the intuition behind it) and I would have given it a higher rating had it not been for the large number of typos and outright mistakes in fleshing out the details (the technical aspect). The publisher has clearly not done a good job and I would hope that buyers of this edition are provided with the option to exchange this book for a later (and hopefully) corrected edition.

A fantastic book with subtitle, "Everything you ever wanted to know, but you were afraid to ask."If you are serious about Machine learning and you are not satisfied with user-only approach, you will find explanations, examples and reasoning right here.I found the only flaw, the book should have twice as many pages to fit more information in.

This book is a comprehensive reference on statistical inference and estimation and definitely a must buy. Some of the important methods used in these areas are explained and references are given for further reading. The author did a great job in collecting so many methods. My only complaint is that method explanations are not enough which may be justified for a reference book. I would recommend it for having the whole picture of methods not as a sole book for mastering a topic.
Explanations are terrible.

The contents of the book are interesting, but I really really dislike the issues with the code. You see, the author uses a set of python modules that he wrote, and these are hiding the usage of some TF APIs that you will definitely need to learn.. elsewhere.Yes, this is not a book about Tensorflow, but at least for me, if I want to follow the examples, I'd like to learn at the same time about the different options to generate a dataset of images. Instead of just jumping into the examples, I see myself navigating through Tensorflow guides to learn how to use ImageDataGenerator to generate the dataset for an autoencoder.You can clone the code from the git repository for the book, but be aware that it has 0 comments. For example. the "loaders.py" that has functions used in the book to load different datasets doesn't have a single comment.Because of this annoyance, I'm dropping this to 3 stars

I have only read the first two chapters (got it only yesterday) but find it superb.  Chapter 2 sums up my own slow progress for the last 10  months on my own, where I've gradually settled on TensorFlow and Keras, and the model described in the book, by observing their use in random papers and Stackoverflow discussions.  I can hardly imagine a more concise, yet sufficiently informative, description of what I have found out over these past months ... I wish I'd seen this book earlier!If the rest of the book, describing material I don't know, is as good as the part I do know, then I'm in for a real treat.

Wow! I had a lot of fun reading this book and now I am working with that. I am an expert in AI and a creative person. Truth be told, in the 1990s I began my IT career because I was fascinated by what programming can do when it comes to art.Now I have David Foster's book here and it told me that Deep Neural Networks are perfectly capable of generating artificial content by training on the real ones. A good example is definitely generating music based on what a Neural Network learned from works of Johann Sebastian Bach. You just come up with a fitting network architecture and train it.The good thing is: The book is not restricted to just music. Music is just one use-case. Natural Language Processing for generating texts, GANs and Autoencoders for Images, you name it.And the best thing: I have to admit that the content of the book is complete and a good state of the art. There is no dust on the pages. Everything you learn is relevant today and will be for a while.
El libro tenía un poco de suciedad y polvo.
Well explained, plenty of examples & engaging. What more can you ask for?
Bien
Livre agréable à lire avec une belle iconographie.
とてもわかりやすく、具体例も多い。名著だと思う。

The book starts great. Fantastic examples. It appeals to the reader's intuition and imagination. I loved the beginning and it was very easy working side by side with Jupyter Notebook. The examples are easy to follow and the code is pure Python with Keras. At that point I was going to give the book five stars. However, I was stuck at Autoencoders when the author suddenly started using his own code shortcuts, which was completely unexpected. It took me a while to figure it out that the code was no longer Keras but the functions and objects developed by the author, and imported from the local python files. The book does not explain any of this and the code becomes very obscure. The author's "models" and "utilities" were clearly meant to simplify development of complex neural networks by the reader. Unfortunately, the code is no longer intelligible as it hides the true Keras APIs. These shortcuts are not really necessary and the code they replace would not add much to the size of the book. In those circumstances, if you move away from the book and the author's Github repository, you will no longer be able to reproduce the models and their tests easily. While it is expected of any practitioner to develop his or her own helper library, this is not suitable for the book which needs simplicity and clarity. In all honesty, the book does not claim to train the reader in Keras at all, however, it uses Keras and asks the reader to install the software, and then explains the basics of model creation with Keras, only to leave it behind. I'd recommend to replace all obscure code with the simplest model creation, which can be found in any Keras example on the web. As the author is quite responsive to the reviews and open for comments, I have increased my rating.
Sem atrasos. Espero que as próximas compras sejam semelhantes a esta. Com certeza a Amazon tem trabalho com qualidade excepcional.

Un ouvrage de référence qui rentre dans le détail de toutes les techniques et développe certains paramètres d'optimisation des différents modèles. Un livre a lire ... lentement pour suivre les recommandations et options possibles. En fait, on se rend compte à la lecture de cet ouvrage des possibilités de modélisation rien qu'en modifiant un calcul de distance (Mahalanobis par exemple) ou une normalisation Le livre est ardu avec de nombreuses démonstrations mathématiques et des exercices à la fin de chaque chapitre. A la fin de chaque chapitre une revue plus que complète de la littérature. Par contre pas un livre pour débuter
Muito bom
Thx
un bon livre et un bon service merci beaucoup
I'm not an expert in machine learning, and I bought this book in the hope of grasping some basic concepts. Honestly, I did not like the book, the structure is confusing for me.

If you would like to have a decent Machine Learning Text for reference - this book may suffice. If your interest is in learning the techniques and apply them to real life examples - this book will most likely not meet the expectation.

This is the WORST book I've EVER seen for Kindle. It's so bad it gives Kindle a bad name, and shouldn't be allowed to be sold here. The diagrams are scaled improperly: it is literally impossible to see all of any single diagram. They are cropped.

This is an excellent intro to machine learning. It is well illustrated and takes you through the essential concepts like linear classifiers, kernels, Bayesian inference, etc.The math is one of the more clear I’ve used.
though the book covers a lot of topics , which is good, a lot of the discussion is a little too abstract, it would help if there were more examples to demonstrate how the various algorithms work.
i was expecting to see examples of preprocessing in training and realtme prediction using tensorflow.this book pays attention to builtin algos of sagemaker.
nice
Great book for those who want to quickly get started with SageMakers AutoML capabilities.Easy to understand and interesting examples.

An broad, deep overview of the many ways Amazon SageMaker can you with your machine learning experiments and applications. Covering all the stages, from labeling and preprocessing your datasets, to training at scale, and deploying models in production. Rich of experiments in areas such as computer vision and NLP. A definite guide.

The kindle version of the book is full of errors. The table of contents is difficult to read (14 pages of sections, chapters and paragraphs in the same underlined, bold fontsize), hyperlinks are not underlined correctly and sometimes don't work (and you cannot copy the hyperlinks!), and the most annoying error is that the python code fragments are pretty much unreadable: often there are no line breaks, so all the code is a single blob of text (really not pythonic :(. So this makes the book unreadable for me, and I'm returning the kindle book.
Pas encore termine la lecture, mais la bonne structure rends le livre facile a lire et appréhender.

I usually avoid books on AWS I have been burned too many times. They usually read like press releases for AWS (for instance, regurgitating the "Six Advantages of Cloud Computing" from the AWS documentation), are not practical, or are out-of-date by the time ink hits paper.This book is a refreshing exception, providing a clear beginner-friendly overview of using the Sagemaker tools for machine learning at AWS. It has up-to-date references on all steps of the pipeline from annotating data to deploying a trained model to production. It includes coverage of boto3 (Python SDK), the Sagemaker SDK, and how to set these up on your local machine. It includes discussion of running your code online in notebook instances or in Sagemaker Studio.I recommend knowing the basics of AWS before reading this book. E.g., the kind of thing you would learn in an 'AWS Practitioner' course online: what is S3, how do you manage your account, what is an IAM role, that kind of thing. However, one thing that is nice is that for every new AWS concept it requires as background, it provides a link so you can learn about it or refresh your memory.This is the first AWS book that I've really liked -- well done!

Si usas Amazon SageMaker, debes saber quién es Julien SImon.Por lo tanto..... Debes de comprar el libro, tú sabes a lo que me refiero.Si no sabes quién es es el Autor y quieres usar SageMaker.¡Con más razón debes de comprar el libro!
Outdated.  Too basic.  Does not include latest features.
Great book to start your ML journey on AWS
Sad to see this delivery. Immediately decided to return.
Book received quickly and is in great shape.About the book : A stepping stone to understanding machine learning and more.
Good
Best book for AI
Language is a little difficult to understand,
The contents which i need is not mentioned in this book
Book is totally worth the money.
Book is great! Great start for beginners and its AI, you got to expect some math right !
Clearly explained of AI, must read book for AI professionals.
Excellent book ... simple and structured introduction to python and data science using python ... plus well worked out examples ... one of the few self-learning books available on the market
Not a good book for beginners.Not explained code in details we will get lot of confusions.
Good one. Not for begineers. It does not teach ml it teaches the programming.

Machine learning is an intricate philosophy and it involves lot of mathematical complexities to bring it into a practice of data analysis. This book simply eradicate those intricacies of programming and implementation of machine learning algorithms. In all, it makes machine learning code pretty simple. Understanding "WHAT" is machine learning is not the purpose of this book. However, this book is designed around the concept "HOW" to implement machine learning algorithms. I would like to add here that it is not only explain you "HOW" to program the algorithms but it also helps you to think "HOW BEST" we can program it. Let me start with some + and few - of the books. But before that remember, as title clarifies, this book is all around (hovers around) Python implementation of machine learning i.e. SCIKIT-LEARN libraries, Scipy and NUMPy. That's the boundary.+1. Very clear and precise declaration from Author that this book is more about implementation of ML than Concept.2. It starts with teaching very basic of data analysis of preprocessing and cleaning up the data along with implementation of Array, indexes, Vector and Matrices using python libraries. This helps reader to make aware about WHAT basics they should build before getting into more complex problems of machine learning. I really liked the "tiny" machine learning program. It's like writing "Hello Word" in any other programming book.3. Beauty is that it takes you slowly into the implementation of classification problem, Text data processing, Clustering, Regression and sentiment analysis.4. Though the breadth of topics is vast but it touches every small corner of related topic. For example: When explaining text comparison method it explains how STOP WORD can be done? how to implement TF-IDF for meaningful text comparison? etc.5. I had big time difficulties in understanding correlation and regression. but explanations of supported SCIKIT libraries made it pretty simple.6. I really enjoyed the chapter for implementation of text (post) data comparison and clustering.7. Big data analysis using JUG came as surprise to me when i was about to complete the reading. It is really interesting to compare this topic with Map reduce implementation.  My work is still in progress on this...8. overall this book covers almost everything that PYTHON can cover for you in data analysis and machine learning.-1. You should know ML concepts in advance. This is not the book to start ML learning. Obviously, It's already proclaim that it is programming ML in python.2. Don't expect in details explanation of any algorithm. Like, when it says "TF-IDF" it just explain in a paragraph what TF-IDF is. And, it implementation in Scikit-learn libraries.3. You mush have moderate level of understanding on python. If you are not at all familiar with PYTHON then spend some time on python primitive data types and programmability before you start this book.4..... yeah that's it. I don't have any more points to mention as negative.Overall, very good book when you have some knowledge on ML (and its algorithms) and Python. But you don't know how to implement these concept in data analysis. Then this is the book.  Go get it!
ok
awesome book
Not recommended. Better books are available now.

I can not understand how so many people have given this book a 4 or 5 rating. 3 is the max that can be given.This book has a hands on approach to ML using python. Which is great. But thats where the greatness ends.1. The explanations in the book in general are sketchy and not thorough.2. They use code snippets in the book. Complete code has to be downloaded. However the way the code snippets are explaineddoes little to help understand the complete code. It's better to read the complete code directly.3. The code is not portable. I had to make some modifications to make some of the routines work.4. In some cases I just could not make the code work.5. They do not explain the scikit and numpy routines at a decent level of detail. So you are often left wondering how the code works,and then you have to read the scikit or numpy routine to figure this out.6. There are several perl files for a given chapter. I have no idea in which sequence to go through them.If you are a decent python programmer, and you have decent knowledge of numpy and scikits, then you will probably not find the book very frustrating. Otherwise, be ready to be frustrated.I think the reason this book is still selling is its cheap, and i think there is nothing better available.There a few books which directly discus scikits-learn. Maybe people should look at them.

Unfortunately this book is basically a non-starter. I can't seem to get through any of it as the code doesn't work in most cases. I agree with a previous reviewer -- I could spend my time debugging and making it work, but that's not why I bought the book. I shouldn't have to jump through hurdles to read this.I wish I could get a refund.

The Pi is the great-granddaughter of the early integrated-circuit computers (the best of them, we conjecture) which in turn had a distinguished ancestry.  The pi has most of the same architecture that more extensive modern machines have nowadays, so learning that architecture is very useful for those who want to go into either computer design or program creation.  This book is one of the best I've seen to explain the evolution and the end product.

I've been doing "computer stuff" for a very long time with embedded computers.  I wish I could have started with this book 30 years ago. It is a good introduction to what computers can do, and how people can get them to do it.  It is not a deep dive, but a good general discussion.  The breadth is really quite wide, from processor and instruction set internals, to memory, input/output, sound, and graphics.  These are the many things that a Raspberry Pi does.  If you are a newbie that has been blinking lights and printing "Hello, world" to the Pi console, this is a good next book to see the whole world under the hood of the machine.
This book was written by the people that invented the Raspberry Pi ...enough said.

An excellent book that in one volume encompasses the basics of an entire computer science and engineering education. It covers everything from how wifi and magnetic recording works to the basics of writing software. It's much more broad than just a discussion of how the RPi works, which is both a pro and a con - I don't need to know how to program, but I am curious about things like how the Raspberry Pi boot process works, and it doesn't go into much detail there.Still, there's no way I could give this book anything but five stars. It's an amazing work that should be required reading for every CSE major.
Great book, really covers the bases of components you'd expect to see in a modern computer and teaches a lot about the RPi in the process.
I'm getting mine later today---I "Looked Inside" ... this is what I always wanted for my birthday---since 1995!!
This is an excellent computer architecture book for beginners.

Well-written, covers a lot of ground, and it's based on a computer you can hold in your hands. The nice thing about the Pi is, of course, that when you understand it, you understand computers in general. Recommended.
Gives a good overview of the workings of a computer.

I scanned the entire book. If you have a computer sci degree this is not for you, but it is great for self study. It covers more than I expected. But, I first order in when it was announced in MagPi in 2014. Check the 'Table of Contents' to see what is covered. I will be using "Raspberry Pi Assembly Language" by Bruce Smith in addition to other books before I am done.JWH

The book is very good as far as theory is concerned. But when I ran the chapter 2 end to end example on Google colab, I got the following error: AttributeError: module 'urllib' has no attribute 'request'. Moreover, "urllib" has been superseded by "urllib3".

This book came highly recommended from a number of online sources and has definitely not disappointed.  I have a paper back and a kindle copy for reference and learning on the move.  Really well written and I’d recommend you set up an env and code along from the book in small Jupiter notebooks to build a code library to call upon as you move forward with ML…
Great read.

As other people have already pointed out, the kindle math typesetting is really bad. For a book that has such a heavy emphasis on math, that's a bit of a dealbreaker for me so I returned it. Shame, because the book looked pretty good.I read a sample chapter in PDF and the math typesetting was perfect. Come on Amazon... either have a working format or just use PDFs like the rest of the world...

In some moments the book is very didactic, in other moments it is very heavy, both in terms of statistical theory and mainly in terms of the algebra discipline. A big problem is that the book's Github is not complete: there are several practical exercises whose solution is not available.

Testo di riferimento per il machine learning. Espone con chiarezza tutti e tre i metodi fondamentali di apprendimento supervisionato non supervisionato per rinforzo. Passa in rassegna tutti i principali classificatori, I metodi di regressione finì alle reti neurali sia con le librerie keras sia con tensorflow.

After studing the theory of deep learning (DL) and had implemented some experiments by scratch is time to start solving complex problems. This book, in my opinion, is a great reference for who has an intermediate experience (or maybe advanced) on DL. Focoused in Keras (TensorFlow backend ), this book goes beyond a practioner book, balancing theory and practice. Excellent reference.
I am reading this book, and I would like to say.wow! That's book sumarize the mininum and the moust important steps of ML, and its background math by pratical approach.

Would have liked to be able to scroll up and down continuously instead of going by one page at a time. Except this, the book is easy to read and to be understood with many examples and colored graphs.
Wirklich ein tolles Buch! Sehr empfehlenswert!! Viele praktische Beispiele und leichte Erklärungen.

This book offers something different from most ML books I've seen; it focuses on understanding the benefits and limitations of each model. It presents the reader with assumptions that will lead to a successful project.The second part covers practical aspects of implementing ML solutions in the cloud and essential data privacy best practices.
It is a medium-advanced level book with a lot of theory very difficult to find in other books of this style.

This is one of the most poorly edited books I've ever read. Mistakes range from pronoun agreement (minor) to poor sentence construction (including two candidates of a phrase, one of which was clearly meant to be deleted). This happens a lot. Sometimes there are multiple examples of the latter, more egregious error, in a single page. It's still worth reading, but seriously, was there an editor (looking at you Gabrielle Vincent)?
Looking forward to reading this book.

Gran libro, la verdad te introduce a todo este mundo de la tecnología y machine learning, aborda temas como reconocimiento de patrones, deep learning y algunos mas muy interesantes, sin duda de las mejores series del MIT.

Constituye una excelente introducción al tema de machine learning e Inteligencia Artificial para aquellas personas que no tengan conocimientos previos y busquen obtener una visión de conjunto completa y con el nivel de profundidad adecuado.

Muy buen libro para entender muchos conceptos clave del Machine Learning, sirve mucho como libro de consulta. Incluye temas como Redes Neuronales, Deep Learning, Natural Language Processing, Reinforcement Learning.. y muchos más. Lo recomiendo para iniciarse en el tema.
Excelente libro, inclusive compre otro para regalar
Todo llego bien y a tiempo.
For understanding of machine learning even to a common person.
Sólo explica el contexto para gente que no sabe del tema. Yo buscaba un libro más técnico. Está bien para que no sabe nada y se quiere involucrar con el tema
Somewhat interesting but extremely basic. Full of style mistakes, like repeating the exact wording of a quote in the following paragraph.
Great introduction to the subject.

Das Buch bietet auf seinen wenigen Seiten einen Überblick über den Bereich des maschinellen Lernens. Es wird über die verschiedenen Techniken berichtet und Beispiele zu deren Anwendung beschrieben. Dabei wird nicht auf Implemetierungsdetails eingegangen, dass hält das Buch recht verständlich. Ich kann es allen empfehlen die sich einen schnellen Überblick über die Anwendungsgebiete von "machine learning" verschafften möchten.

None expertise more than O'Reilly in exploiting the trending terms and so the business...No matter if the book covers almost nothing and looks written just to make quick buck during euphoria. This book is just another such outcome from this publishers. It was supposed to be a book on unsupervised learning, something which is huge in itself...And this books spends almost 1/3 or more explaining supervised learning. They have put chapters like Auto encoders and DeepNets for unsupervised learning where either they end the chapter in just 6 pages or just loath with haphazard poorey explained codes pasted from somewhere.Just not recommended. Better read some data mining book and clustering book and online tutorials which also give you very nicely explained codes.

Read few reviews before that this book is hurried to the market.. After buying and reading it through I agree with that review.Not an exciting read. Some topics can be explained better. Expected better content going by the title of the book.

Compared to hands-on machine learning with scikit learn & tensorflow this is relatively poor.A lot of explanations don't have graphics to help explain things - I already know the basics of some unsupervised learning but the RBM description was not helpful in chapter 1.Not sure how much proof reading went on as in chapter two the recall and precision formulas both equate to the same things.Finally I found the important bit of code snippets not explained and continually had to look at the respective packages API to see what it did. Also loads of unnecessary imports were given that were not necessary eg time series chapter and all the tf and keras ones - this really obscured understanding.

Based on the title, I was hoping for a book of the same quality as Geron's "Hands‑On Machine Learning with Scikit‑Learn and TensorFlow". Unfortunately this is not the case and many important aspects and issues are not explained.Hardly any illustrations are helpful for the understanding of the topic. In total, the book seems like a trial to copy the concept of Geron, but without putting any effort into it. Unfortunately it's not worth the money.

Print Book Not in Color for plots and graphs, No PDF, code snippet based book, if that's your style of learning. I prefer a more visually illustrative book with some math to back the theory up. Then go into code. Since I apply myself in more robust Java over slow scriptic Python this book is not very useful to me. I was hoping for better theoretical and conceptual understand from the book. Not a code Junky anyways.

It is good on the unsupervised learning but the issue is the book is printed black and white. There are many plots and there is no point understanding them where all look the same. The colored codes are difficult to read in many places. I returned the book and bought the electronic version.

If you are expecting this to be the equivalent of "Hands-On Machine Learning with Scitkit-Learn, Keras & TensorFlow" for unsupervised methods, you will be very disappointed! Hands-On Machine Learning has a very good balance between concepts, math and code. This book (Hands-On unsupervised learning), on the other hand, lacked concepts or math completely. Just having code is not useful since I expected the book to walk through what the code does.
O conteúdo é relevante, porém não é bem detalhado. Ele apresenta os códigos mas os explica muito pouco. Além disso, foi impresso em preto e branco prejudicando o estudo dos gráficos.
This book is exceptionally well written and very complete. It’s definitely in my top ten picks on data science.
Muito bom!

This is the best machine learning book I have ever read!!! The author breaks things done into simple easy to understand components. I now have a better understanding of what the ML engineers are discussing.
This book is a good introduction to machine learning. Indeed it explains basic concepts for beginners plus has some nice intro to writing code with python

This book provides very good overview of ML to beginners and touch base on majority of the key ML algorithms and concepts. Code sample towards the end gives a basic hands-on experience and understanding of the model, fit and test methodology. Highly recommended.
Excellent book for an absolute beginner who wants to understand the terms and get introduced to the subject. Would definitely recommend to all beginners.
This book gives a fantastic overview and helps while studying a related book on python.

This is not so much a product review as a complaint.  Several attempts to download to my Kindle failed, although Amazon claims it was delivered. I asked for a refend, etc. If I order again will the same happen?
Explained in language that makes it easy to grasp the content. I now have a much better understanding of machine learning than I had before, and I thought I was pretty good :-)

There were few places where it was not easy to understand for personally as having 0 experience in ML. But in general really good book to start diving in the field or to have basic understanding and be able to talk with coworkers who work with ML.

I chose 5 stars because this book is clear and concise. I would highly recommend this book for people who know a little about AI, but want to have a slightly more detailed overview.
Beginner friendly.

Although this book is an easy read, I do not recommend it. It contains errors which may lead to misconception by novices in the field of data science. I bought this book to get some low level examples to present to my colleagues and can use the examples with some tweaks to correct the errors. One clear error is the picture on low accuracy and high variance. That picture does not have a bias, the average is very close to the bulls eye. Please edit the book, it is on its own a very easy read but needs editing.
