This book has been an absolute magic and I’ve recommended it to all the people in my network.

I got this book about 10 days ago and I am over half way gone already, even in the midst of my full time work. I couldn't go a day without reading this book. The style in which the explanations are delivered is next to none. What a great book.It is definitely worth reading for anyone trying to understand the concept of Deep Learning. The fact that the underlying Calculus is almost non-existent, but uses simple explanations and forces one to get their hands dirty with code, is just the perfect way to learn. One thing I found really good was that, every time a new  concept was introduced,  it almost always felt like the authors anticipated my next questions, and always provided the answers. It was so so easy to read and follow along, without having to google for better understanding.Overall, I highly recommend this book if you are looking for somewhere to start.

From Neocognitron back in 1970 to the complex GAN’s models, this book has everything: the history, the context, the applicability and a comprehensive presentation of each step of Deep Learning development.Easy to read and very engaging. Overall, I would say the book is really good and I would recommend it as reading material for machine learning degree courses; as it would have been more helpful than some of the materials I had to read on my course.

Don’t buy this book. The content is super light, dangerously so. I love Manning Publications, but this book was a huge disappointment. Instead buy “Practical Data Science with R” 2nd ed. for guidance on AI techniques and “R for Data Science” for tidyverse guidance.

This is the book for which I was finding from the last six months.It expertly introduces transformers and mentors the reader for building innovative deep neural network architectures for NLP.The book covers almost all game-changing applications for natural language processing (NLP), natural language understanting (NLU), and natural laguage generation (NLG).The book is very useful even for beginners in the domain as the questions of each chapter are answered in the Appendix.

This is a wonderful, plain-English discussion of the mechanics that go on under the hood of neural networks - from data flow to updating of weights. Specifically written without a slant on normally-wonky math, the concepts are presented and then advanced at a digestable pace for anyone. It makes for a wonderful textbook for a course, and should be required reading for product managers or marketing people getting into deep learning, alike.
It has nothing but some different flavors of "hello world" transformer codes. Not good for beginners or experts.  Writing is pathetic.

The book is well written, between the code examples, and the graphics. I appreciated the various applications and variations of the original Transformers presented in the book. I found that dedicating, quite quickly, only the first chapter to the building blocks theory may be too little, and the theory is a bit too rushed. While I understand the goal is indeed to stay "Applied" early-on, theory is still important to nail down the understanding correctly. I'd have appreciated one more chapter on the theory (not necessarily more math/theory, but rather taking it slower) and one less chapter on yet another variant of BERT.Overall, great book to have in your bookshelf if you're into ML and NLP.

This book is a comprehensive reference on Transformers, the new technologies used in natural language processing. The book covers all the mathematics and architectures. It goes in details over HuggingFaces, Bert,  Roberta, GPT2 , GPT3, T5, and many more. It is recommended if you want to have an handson understanding on the technologies that took natural language processing by Storm and made things like CNN and ever Menon absolute obsolete. Very much liked chapter 4 with the challenges observed in modern nlp. definitely recommend the book. 5 Stars, also because updated to 2021.

A well intended hands-on book for NLP enthusiasts; however, when it comes to explaining the core concepts the language barrier is quite evident and the explanations are brief. For example, the author mentions about paying extra focus on the chapter about transformers, which ironically is brief and difficult to digest without referring to the nice free-of-cost references listed at the end of the chapter and in the github notebooks. This holds for the following chapters as well. Additionally, there are quite a few errors in the text. A bit more proofreading is what one could expect for the price you pay.All in all a decent attempt with an overview of transformers, transformer-based architectures and its applications. However, if you are looking for step-by-step conceptual explanations about transformers and their variations this is NOT your go to reference. Personally, I would recommend Getting started with Google BERT by Sudharsan Ravichandiran. On the other hand, if you are is looking for clear steps to set up your first transformers notebook project, this could be a resource to refer to.On a totally different note, if still interested in the book, the publisher offers, both, print + ebook (immediate access) for a lower price of about 29 euros.
El autor, muy reputado, explica de forma muy sencilla las bases y aplicaciones de Transformers

This is unacceptable. Did an editor even look at this book? Bad sentences (talking about NLP), long explanations for trivial things, terrible explanations for key concepts, horrible ambiguous typesetting of formulas (ever heard of Latex, perhaps?). A total slob-job, not recommended.

This book, as many others about the "NLP transformers revolution", has almost no interest. It is just a collection of verbiage made upon easy notebooks reimplementing the typical Python snippets available freely on the HF and AllenNLP websites. It is almost a shame to see so many editors publishing such works which do not bring anything new about the subjects and at best reproduce the knowledge proposed for FREE on HF or AllenNLP websites. Let's take the example of Chapter 10 about QA. The author proposes to generate questions to be asked to the QA pretrained model. He is proposing to use NER for identifying entities in the text context and then writes a snippet to hardcode questions based on the entity categories.... OMG, it is not at all how we do such questions generation process with Transformers... If you want to start discussing how to generate questions from a context (and honestly I do not see the point here), at least use a Transformer model in an inverse close tasks manner. You will teach something new to your readers and keep credibility at the same time.So to summarize, do not waste your money with this kind of books pretending to teach you how to do NLP with Transformers. Plan 2 months of homework studying HF, Stanza and AllenNLP repo and watch the Stanford YouTube videos from Manning. Free and much much better.

This is a great book for anyone new to the subject of deep learning applied to AI. The author goes to great lengths to explain each topic in sufficient detail to understand it. He then follows it up with a python program to illustrate the key aspect of the topic. The Transformers model is explained in detail with the simplified attention getting as their key to encoding  and decoding. BERT is then one of the metric programs often used for measuring the performance of the particular NLP app, Transformers in this case. The author goes further in explaining how Bert does it. This opens the door to using it for other mappings. Thus the book handles roBERTa, GLUE, SuperGlue and etc.The chapters on translations and generation are particularly interesting because it leads to a discussion of generation and GPT-2 and GPT-3. This is a topic that requires massive computing because of the number of words involved in their data, (540 M) and (1.75 Billions, 8 10000 PCs) respectively. Three of the later chapters are devoted to word extraction. The final three chapters are devoted to Language understanding.I have no hesitation in recommending this book to any student of modern AI.

The methodology for developing the deep networks and understanding them are there, but I hate that he uses a baseball team and figures out their chances of success by how many toes they have. It's ridiculous. I would rather see examples that make sense like the age of the players or something. The MIT course online uses the amount of time spent on a test, and number of lectures attended to figure out likely final test scores. So if you're the author, and you read my review. Please use less made up examples or examples that at least seem less made up. Thanks.

I'm going to be brief and list the good and the bad.* Good:1- Easy to read (one of the best books to get you started)2- Hands on approach to implementing Neural networks3- Some introduction to popular AI libraries such as Numpy4- Good guidance on next steps* Bad:1- Syntax and coding problems that are easy to detect by a trained eye but not as easy for a novice learner2- Some typographical errors throughout the bookI have to clarify that book on its own is good. I think there are probably some items that could have been taken care of (I mentioned above) through the editing process but hopefully the next versions of the books can take care of these issues.

I rarely write reviews, but I have to here. This is an excellent book. It's concise, clear, and does an excellent job of conveying understanding and intuition. Having read bits and pieces about neutral networks over the years, I'm glad I picked up this book and gained conceptual understanding.

Ottimo punto di riferimento per chiunque voglia approfondire il tema dell'intelligenza artificiale. L'esposizione è molto chiara e didattica; i fondamenti dell'AI sono affrontati con grande dettaglio, senza però indugiare su aspetti più "pratici" come l'implementazione effettiva degli algoritmi illustrati. Per questi motivi è un testo che consiglio assolutamente a chi vuole acquisire un ampio background teorico sull'intelligenza artificiale. Decisamente stimolante.

This books gives vast vision of a difficult subject.  At many places it is superb.  Unfortunately there are a few plays that could use another rewrite.  Still, if you are going to study just one book, this would likely be the best choice.  However, be prepared to work hard as it is written at an advanced level.

This book covers a thorough reasoning of the start of the A.I Industry, and it's evolution and then immediately starts into some of the unique problems that only A.I can reason through in reasonable time. The content and the delivery in this book make it genuinely easy to understand and reason through whilst also giving a strong background in theory.I recommend this to any interested in studying the fields of A.I. and Data-mining as a good source of relevant information to build a strong foundation from... The Algorithms and Theories discussed within give a strong relational background from which to branch from... Chapters:1. Exploring the landscape of artificial intelligence.2. What’s in the picture: image classification with Keras.3. Cats versus dogs: transfer learning in 30 lines with Keras.4. Building a reverse image search engine: understanding embeddings.5. From novice to master predictor: maximising convolutional neural network accuracy.6. Maximising  speed and performance of TensoFlow: a handy checklist.7. Practical tools, tips and tricks.8. Cloud APIs for computer vision: up and running in 15 minutes.9. Scalable inference serving on cloud with TensorFlow serving and KubeFlow.10. AI in the browser with TensorFlow.js and ml5.js11. Real-time object classification on iOS with CoreML and CreateML.13. Shazam for food: developing Android apps with TensorFlow lite and MLKit.14. Building the purrfect cat locator app eith TensoFlow object detection API.15. Becoming a maker: exploring embedded AI at the edge.16. Simulating a self-driving car using end-to-end deep learning with Keras.17. Building an autonomous car in under an hour: reinforcement learning with AWS DeepRacer.Appendix:A crash course in convolutional neural networks.This is a large book covering a wide range of both well developed and emergent forms of machine learning approaches  to a wide range of applications. Its a big ask tackled well by the three authors and various additional contributors, all of whom are vastly experienced and respected in their fields of interest. The book offers a fascinating and engaging read for those who are seeking rather more than a basic introduction to machine learning and applied data science whether from the point of view of a lay person, or like the reviewer, someone wishes to gain more than an appreciation of the field – an exposure to the actual nuts and bolts. This book succeeds from both approaches. For the first a wideranging account of existing and emerging techniques and tools available for various deep learning frameworks. For the second a closely integrated set of Jupyter Notebooks is made freely available. These notebooks, offer anyone with access to a web browser, the ability to carry out many of the examples written in Python with the libraries of the deep learning frameworks – such as TensorFlow and Keras. In a simple and straightforward way readers are enabled to carry out their own experimentation with the data made accessible by the authors. In other words the reader is able to DO machine learning, not just read about it!The authors have provided a good service to the public. The book is an authoritative introduction to the constituent fields of machine learning and provides an online experience for a number of recognisable groups: the software developer who might seek to develop skills applicable in the field of AI; the data scientist  to enrich their skill set and deepen knowledge of the field in order to build real projects; the student to assist in the aspiration to a career in AI through developing a portfolio of interesting projects and to help unleash creativity; the teacher since this book can supplement course work with fun real-world projects. Each of the projects presented in this book can make for great collaborative or individual work in the classroom; the robotics enthusias for here is a survey of actual projects using emerging hardware such as Raspberry Pi, NVIDIA Jetson Nano, Google Coral and others.
interesting reading, bridges the gap between implementation and ideas
Where is the 2nd edition of this book?

If you are looking to learn practical application of deep learning, then this is "THE"  book. The secret sauce is the GIT repo that contains Jupyter notebooks that you can run on Google Colab for free. The authors did phenomenal job in explaining difficult ML topic in simple manner. The readers can choose to either dig deeper or experiment with book provided example.The concept of machine learning does not need to be intimidating. It can be fun, rewarding and motivating. And, this book just does the job right!

Having no prior machine learning/AI experience, I found this book to be a great guide for those looking to explore and start their journey in artificial intelligence. The book started with introducing readers to practical examples of how far Artificial Intelligence has come today, and then over the 600 pages recreated those examples in great detail. The authors have done a fantastic job explaining concepts in a fun way which are backed by real world scenarios and code (GIT repo) which readers can run themselves. That effectively meant just pressing the run button on Colab notebooks for TensorFlow and Keras code, instead of having to make any installations on my machine. This book is well structured, practical, easy to follow and makes a good attempt to keep the reader motivated from one chapter to the next. I can strongly recommend grabbing a copy today if you have any interest in learning how computer vision & deep learning projects are built at top companies.

MUY DECEPCIONADO CON LA COMPRA!Es el tercer libro de esta compañía (O'REILLY) que compro, y el segundo que me sale mal.La calidad de impresión es muy mala, acartonada y el papel parece que se va a rasgar en cualquier momento, pero eso no es lo peor, sino que está impreso en blanco y negro, lo cual dificulta mucho entender ciertas imágenes. Esto, para un libro enfocado en redes neuronales, y más en concreto aplicadas a vision artificial, es algo pésimo, ya que se pierde muchísima información al no poder ver el color en las imágenes y los gráficos.Adjunto imágenes donde pueda apreciarse la razón de mi queja.Una pena...

I would summarize this book as targeted "guidance/help" to speed up learning AI with heavy hands-on practical experience.My background is in the world of network engineering. I have previously attempted to pick deep learning with coursera courses but abandoned early when the calculus portion started. This text in contrast kept me far more engaged due to its approach. After reading the first three chapters, I could grasp the art of training convolutional neural networks for my own dataset - the inner workings of the layers, how to fine tune these layers and how to interpret results, find errors and improve. Transfer learning, Data Augmentation and many other topics are very well explained with proper examples in code related to the topic.  Similarly, instead of searching and reading hundreds of pages of documentation to understand - "how to maximize the speed/performance" - 40 pages of chapter-6 were more than enough to achieve this. Chapter-12 onwards gave a real deep dive into many interesting AI projects (including apps, robotics and even autonomous cars) - a real practical thrill for all levels of AI engineers.The practical approach really helped me to build a good understanding of the concepts of deep learning while coding in python using Keras and TensorFlow. At least now when I see a company release an AI product, I can make a decent guess about how I could go about building the same myself.
Uses simple language to explain hard concepts in deep learning.Practical examples, latest frameworks, supported by GitHub code snippets/examples.
Die Bilder sind ohne Farbe. Nicht so gut wie digitale Version.

This book gave words to my rage; a coherent argument to my thoughts; a spark to the fire within me that suffocates every day under the unyeilding breath of unpaid work.The chapter 'the drugs don't work' which details how the gender data gap is quite literally costing women their lives, is particularly galling, depressing and enraging.Every woman should read this book. Every man should read this book. I feel to carry it with me so that the next time a man manspains feminism to me or tries to tell me that true gender inequality exists only in other countries I can quote some statustics. Or, failing that I can throw the book at them. And after reading this, I really do feel like throwing something at someone.

This book is so important, everyone should read it! Not every woman, everyone! The books looks at the data gap relating to women (ie men make decisions and implement rules based on research made for/by men and that totally ignore the slightly different circumstances women may have, from public transport to safety, childcare needs to public toilets... you name it).The statistics and data the author has collected is simply shocking. Everything she quotes is referenced, you can look up every study she mentions. A warning though, if you're a woman, this book will most likely make your blood boil (I felt so cross with myself for not even questioning some of these things, for accepting what is clearly a design flaw as unavoidalble). I could only read a few pages at a time, which I then needed to digest, eg the fact that female police officers don't have stab vests that are designed for their bodies, the fact that the author received death and rape threats when she campaigned to have a woman featured on bank notes (perspective people? ), the fact that women do the bulk of caring for their children or eldery relatives but nothing is designed to help them (from public transport, to the order in which roads are cleared when there's snow...).This book is an eye opener and made me realise that the only way things can change is by women being more involved  (accepted? ) in the decision making and by studies being gender specific. But as women get death/rape threats when they raise their voices over something as trivial as a woman on a bank note, it's understandable that they're reluctant to do so.

I genuinely feel like this should be a book I would love. We unarguably live in a world dominated by men. And I don't mean that in the sense of a criticism, necessarily, but rather that fundamentally the design of our world centres around men in some part, from seat-belt safety to the way in which computer generated data analysis even works. Caroline Perez highlights some of the foundations of our society, some of the data bias but most importantly just some of the design flaws with society which are archaic and didn't, at the time of their design  and still don't, reflect a woman.If I think about even the language we use, we use terms such as "mankind" and "man-made" without even a nod to the women involved. Only recently did an emoji appear feminine, and actually when I think about it, most of the time when you look at a "thing" it has to have overtly feminine qualities or we just assume the thing is a man. How bizarre, but totally true.Nevertheless, I don't think that this book prompted me to think about these things. I think it certainly highlights a huge gap in our thinking, an entirely unfair and dated approach to a large number of life's routine components. But I don't think it challenges it, although of course that's what the book is for, but rather it feels like a commentary on stats and numbers and facts without really having a dialogue with the reader. I don't know, just something felt very "textbook" about it, whereas a lot of non-fiction with such incredible content feels much more accessible.  It's easy enough to read, but you notice the info-dump whereas in better delivered novels you don't notice.I completely appreciate what this novel is about and how important some of the information within it is. I would challenge anyone to read this and claim they came away having learned nothing. But the approach is a little heavy handed for me and I just didn't enjoy it; in fact, I preferred my time thinking about it myself far more.

The content of the book is great and the research is extensive. My main problem is the erasure and negation of non-binary and non-cis experiences.The book takes a binary view of gender (starting with the title) and does not acknowledge non-binary identities (e.g., refers toMoreover, statements like "By ‘sex’, I mean the biological characteristics that determine whether an individual is male or female. XX and XY." does not acknowledge that even sex (let alone gender) is much more complex in reality (see https://gimletmedia.com/shows/science-vs/j4hl23 for a different point of view on the topic).Consciously or unconsciously, statements like "The result is that when ‘brilliance’ is considered a requirement for a job, what is really meant is ‘a penis’" erase the struggles that transgender women face.I really liked the data that the book provides, but I find it hard to recommend reading this book without having to caution about the erasure of people lived experiences and struggles this book reinforces.I wish the author had incorporated caveats throughout the book to the fact that sex and gender are not a simple binary and that people that do not fit into the binary norm are suffering an even worse fate and that, in that regard, cis women hold a humongous amount of privilege compared to non-binary and trans people.That does not mean that a book like this should not be written, and, for the sake of making progress on these topics, it should be written, and I thank the author for that! We cannot solve all problems at once. But instead of erasing other underprivileged groups, the book could have acknowledged them and moved on while setting the scope of the book.

A thought provoking book that opened my eyes to some unexpected ways in which women are often unthinkingly discriminated against due to long accepted male norms in research and data gathering across a broad spectrum of life experiences.I do wish she’d given a shout out to Maya Dusenberry’s earlier book Doing Harm (on the narrower field of US medicine) as she seems to use a lot of the same examples here. It would also have been helpful to have a glossary of the numerous acronyms that pop up and sometimes a brief explanation of them e.g. AWS, rather than assuming the reader knows how they work. Some of the areas covered seemed a little trivial (I know lots of men who prefer the smaller iPhone se for example) whilst larger issues like women’s pension poverty and the recent addition of a year to their state pension age within 5 years of retirement in the UK were barely mentioned. This gender data gap is clearly meant to read as a universal problem but that also meant that the book spread itself a little thin at times using many US examples especially in medicine. On the whole good and highlighted areas I wouldn’t have thought of as impacting on women before; even though the final sections seemed to get a bit bogged down to me.

This has to be a book everyone reads and is aware of. Really important information regarding the absence of women in so many realms of society. From using 'male' designed dummies when testing how the body reacts to ergonomics of a car when it crashes (more women die or are seriously injured) to drugs being tested on only men and as men and women's bodies are made very differently, sometimes these drugs either do not work on women or they have worrying effects. It shows how little effect the 'equality act' which I campaigned for in the 70's has had for women. Read ....and become aware.

I loved this book from start to finish - page after page of 'Oh, yes I'd noticed that, but didn't think to mention it to anyone, it's a man's world after all' to believing that finally folk have taken the time and trouble to research this stuff and then for the author to capture it all (well, a LOT of it) and present it in a totally accessible way. I work at Birmingham University (UK), and this will now be stocked in the main library. I have recommended it to EVERYONE, academics, friends,people on the bus, a friend who's recently become an MP (in the hope it might influence him some), since beginning to read it as I feel everyone SHOULD read it.A great book - enlightening, revealing, thought provoking - I'm not a feminist, but am seriously considering becoming one....fab read, can't recommend it highly enough - most enjoyable, wonderful....

Whether you agree or not with her style, delivery or strong feminist outlook this book exposes very important facts we’ve overlooked before, in some cases life threatening, in other cases financially Unsubstantiated and yet it seems we’re missing a trick to solve so many world problems by overlooking 50% of humans. Amazing, eye opening and a must-read for all, especially if you can convince a man to read it, in particular men of influence.  She should have put it out in two versions, one as it is, another by a Pseudo male author with a title like ‘Are all humans male?’, then we might see some shifts in policy.

In the final section of this book, Caroline Criado Perez notes that conflict, natural disasters and, yes pandemics exacerbate existing inequalities. It's something I thought about a lot as I read her well-argued (and extensively sourced) thesis, particularly its sections on work and the unpaid "second shift" in the home: how would the 2020-21 update of Invisible Women read? To what extent could we have avoided some of what we are facing now had we disaster planned around traditionally female jobs, caring responsibilities, education? Had we only collected the data?The one-word summary: this book is informative. At times it veers into into-dump territory - the Kindle edition is 55% text; 45% endnotes and indices. But what a worthwhile project. What a piece of work.
TERF book, would give 0 stars if I could.

This is a fantastic book which explains how to implement various ML algorithms using. Every script in the book works like charm and it helped me understand some concepts of ML. I would have been very happy if it had covered artificial neural networks in slightly more detail (how these networks are implemented) explaining the pseudo code. This book isn't really about machine learning. There is relatively little in the book about the machine learning algorithms themselves. Most of it is plumbing: how to munge the data in using R. And there are some nice motivating examples on using the ggplot2 library in R to visualise the results. (However, on the downside, plots which require colour to be understood are presented in black and white, which doesn't help! The R code mostly works, so usually it is possible to produce your own, but it seems a waste of paper to output plots that show male vs female dots, say, in different shades of grey on the same graph.)Also, when the algorithms are presented there are sometimes some serious errors (see the review on amazon's US site "Erroneous but entertaining" for more details). The single most shocking example was when a series of numbers was said to show the percentages of variation explained by an analysis, but the series added up to much than 100%. This was by no means the only error, however. The cumulative effect for me was that as I got further and further through the book, I began to have less and less trust in what was being presented to me.I would characterise the book as being for hackers in the sense that you are encouraged to try a technique and see if it works. One good point is that the book emphasises having a separate test set from your training set.Trying techniques until you find one that works is probably a good place to start, especially if your interest is in starting to learn the broader field of data science -- getting the data in, analysing it, visualising it -- rather than specialising in the selection and choice of machine learning algorithms themselves (for which Andrew Ng's coursera online course is a far better choice).
Un buon libro per chi si vuole avvicinare al Machine Learning, il taglio della spiegazione è americano quindi con esempi significativi.

El libro es una muy buena introducción al Machine Learning y los conceptos en los que se basa. Lo recomiendo para todo aquel desarrollador que quiera introducirse en ese mundo.

Kann ich nur dringend von abraten. Klare vorsätzliche Täuschung der Titel. Es wir einem nicht erklärt was Machine Learning ist, es wird nur R benutzt die Algorithmen zu berechnen oder zu visualisieren und es wird weder R noch maschinelles Lernen erklärt.

Not recommended.

Il libro è una chiave di volta per gli studi sul l'intelligenza artificiale moderna. Il formato Kindle di questo tipo non è molto funzionale sul mio Mac ma in Italia non è facilissimo avere il formato cartaceo del libro. Con la nuova versione di Kindle di Luglio 2017 i problemi sono stati risolti.

An excellent exploration on theories and implementations of statistical machine learning and neural networks. Does an excellent job introducing relevant and complex math topics (calculus, set theory, etc) early on, as they will be required to understand the rest of the book. I found the formula sheets for matrix derivatives incredibly helpful, so that I wouldn't have to memorize them.All in all, a must-have manual for anyone wanting to dive deep under the hood of how many modern machine learning algorithms work.

The book was printed in black and white, a shame for a book dealing with computed vision. Comparing two pictures that look the same in black and white does not help understanding the concepts. Content seems pretty interesting so far though.

I have stepped into a new role at work with the need to become a practitioner of deep learning. I purchased this book to help me optimize some of the machine learning models I've been working with and to help drive knowledge with examples. This book has helped me accelerate this process in many ways. It teaches well with examples that play directly into my scenarios on iOS and Android. It has been useful already in several ways -- in particular, it has helped me to understand how to deal with an overfitting problem I have been dealing with. Thanks Anirudh and Meher!EDIT: Having spent a bit more time with the book, I can update the review with a bit more detail. This book is quite witty with many funny examples. Kudos to the authors for taking the time to be so inventive with their practical deep learning examples. This book has mentions of many interesting applications of machine learning on mobile and in other places. Some nice CoreML and python examples which came in quite handy.

As someone with prior theoritical knowledge of basics of Machine Learning techniques, I was looking for something that focuses on application and that I can readily use for my work. I recently had the need to add client side model for mobile app, and this book was right on the point for what I was seeking. I dived right into chapters 11 and after. The book adopts a very hands-on approach, and saved a lot of time for me. I eventually ended up reading most of the other chapters too as they were such a good refresher. I especially liked chapters on performance tuning for deep learning and the scalability aspects. Overall, I found this book a great read and would recommend for both new ML enthusiasts as well as other ML engineers.

Right from the outset, the friendly tone of this book yields a free flowing, friendly funnel to the advanced concepts the reader is trying to learn. With this friendly approach, the intimidation factor of difficult concepts like Deep Neural Networks become a little bit more human. It also helps that the examples they have selected, from the references to the HBO series 'Silicon Valley' and trying out 'Shazam' for food create a fun learning experience while diving in sufficient depth for any new ML engineer. I learnt a lot from this book, and intend to use this knowledge in my day-to-day. It also helps that some of the authors have done this in practice in the real world with groundbreaking apps like Seeing AI. Great writing and strongly recommended!

I am a recent high school graduate, going into my freshmen year of college, who is interested in getting into the field of Deep Learning and AI. I found this book to be an incredible resource for accelerating my progress in these fields.Going in with absolutely no prior experience, I read this book and was astounded by how much it taught me in just a couple of days / weeks. The clear syntax, understandable language, and engaging examples support an excellent entrance into fields of Deep Learning, Computer Vision, and AI by not only providing easily accessible opportunities for hands-on learning, but also explaining the importance of the book's content. This was incredibly important to me as someone who did not know much about Deep Learning prior to reading this book: the way Koul, Ganju, and Kasam wrote this book goes beyond informative - they inspire creativity and practicality in the future of what Deep Learning, etc. can do.Further, Practical Deep Learning also provides an excellent transition from "I don't know anything" to "Wow! I am creating my own project... and understanding it!" Thus, the detail and content of this book make it suitable for all levels. It's a truly fantastic buy for anyone interested in Deep Learning - especially for those on the outside who are intimidated, like I was, by the concept of this field!

I recently needed to brush up on machine learning for a new project at work (for background, I have been in the industry for close to 10 years writing software). I studied ML in school. but deep learning, which is the buzzword now, was new to me and I was looking for a book that's less focused on the mathematics, and more on the practical side. I was also looking for example code that's ready to use. Fortunately, I found this book which met both of my requirements.The authors did a great job explaining the important concepts of deep learning. I remembered it took me a while to understand and remember the concept of backpropagation when I first learned NN at school. The way they explained it, particularly the diagrams, was so clear and spot-on. Wish I had this book when I was a student.After reading the first four chapters, I was able to follow the simple steps and make an image classifier with high accuracy, which was what I needed for the project at work. I went a step further and also tried out the image recommendation system from chapter 4, which helped me in understanding image features in greater detail and how to scale it up for large datasets.I used to think it would take a long time for me to be able to apply deep learning at work because I was overwhelmed by questions like the framework I should use, the programming language, and where I can start collecting training data.. This book answered all my questions and provided just what I needed for me to get my work done. I highly recommend this book to anyone who wants to be familiarized with deep learning and be able to start coding and shipping production-ready machine learning projects.

The book gives a very good overview of machine learning and AI and how the revolution started! The comparison of different deep learning frameworks has been super helpful in making a decision on which one to pick based on the requirements. It is quite hands-on with code snippets being provided along with the theory. The book does a good job of explaining the tradeoffs between running the model on the cloud vs the mobile, which is very critical to understand while deciding model deployment strategies. I love the style in which it is written. The core concepts are introduced in a clear fashion, with witty jokes positioned appropriately.  This is a very useful book for someone not only starting in the field of AI but also someone who is actively developing AI-related products in big companies or startups. I have enjoyed reading it and it is a worthy purchase!

I bought this book to supplement my studies in machine learning in college. Although I have only been studying ML for a semester, I thoroughly enjoyed this book, which is a modern take on deep learning & artificial intelligence with lots of case studies and practical examples, along with a dash of humor on each page. Each chapter starts with a fun story and presents 3-4 ways of solving the same problem, along with pros/cons of each (like time to implement, scale, and performance) and software/hardware requirements. These solutions grow in the range of complexity gradually,  from more novice ‘student’ solutions to ‘industry’ solutions. Sometimes I could find my answer for my needs in the first few pages, but in other cases I read further to find a more efficient solution. Some tools even removed the need to code a solution, making it as easy as a mouse click, especially since all the code for each model is easily accessible online. The chapter ends usually feature performance benchmarks on different hardware as a ready reference (e.g. running 5 AI models on 6 years worth of iPhones), and case studies from different companies making the concepts taught very relatable. Good chunk of the chapters I read were implemented with Keras and TensorFlow for training, though it does go over nitty gritties of CoreML and TensorFlow Lite  Overall, this book was refreshing because it approached familiar problems from many different perspectives. I learned how to approach solving new problems in the most time and performance efficient way, and enjoyed widening my ML toolkit along the way.

This book is an excellent introduction to Deep Learning for those who want to start building effective Al systems immediately. At a time with many introductory books about deep learning, most texts only cover the theoretical background of neural networks. Instead, this book fills the gap between theory and practice with valuable information about the specific tools and techniques needed to develop a deep learning system.The book describes several software tools that are essential to get maximum accuracy from a machine learning pipeline such as Tensorboard, What-If tool, Keras Tuner, AutoAugment, AutoKeras. Subsequently, most chapters stress on concepts like latency, speed, battery life, scalability, resource utilization, etc., important concepts for most engineers in industry. Experiment after experiment helps develop intuition on why a particular method is fast, accurate, or cheaper. Practitioners inevitably learn these concepts over time, so becoming familiar with them early on, and having an available reference, will accelerate the development of your first few projects. Furthermore, even advanced techniques such as generative adversarial networks and reinforcement learning for autonomous cars are introduced in a very accessible manner. Understanding how they can be used will quickly advance the reader from a beginner to a practitioner.The book is quite large, with almost 600 pages of content, giving the reader much information to learn through multiple reads, and then later on the shelf for future reference. The reader will gain tons of value from having bookmarks throughout this book as they journey through building out real-world deep learning systems.

I read this book after taking a basic Machine learning course in my school. The book was easy to follow and a natural next step for me. It covers both theoretical and practical Deep Learning and enable you to work on real-world problems which gets really exciting as you learn more concepts and gain experience with the tools. I highly recommend it for anyone who wants to do hands on work with tensorflow and keras which is really the showstopper here. I don't own a gpu so training is sometimes difficult but this book had a solution to that too, they have the notebooks on google colab and github. I liked how francois chollet, jeremy howard etc shared their experiences, its unusual, but i’ll take it. The book also points to other resources like how to visualize a neural network which is a good guideline for future learning, and I plan to look into these later.

This book will make you look at the world entirely differently. We hear “it’s a man’s world” but the irony is, it really is! Every single aspect of this world we women merely survive in rather than thrive in is designed and built by men for men. From small insignificant things to huge game-changers, women’s lives, from conception to grave, are made harder and therefore much worse than they should be for 51% of the world’s population.  This book opens your eyes to all this and more.  I really enjoyed it because it taught me that it was never me being weak, unfit or just abnormal when I struggled in life, but the fact that I have been fighting a losing battle trying to get along in a man’s world. So it made perfect sense to me and made me breathe a sigh of relief. But then I also got angry at the injustice of it all. All the lost potential to a world that actively excludes women from practically all walks or life. Men will benefit from reading this book too to understand women’s difficulties and how they can help be a voice for us to help level the playing field as rejoice in our differences not to simply ignore it as medicine, science, tech, the military and politics seems to do.
A barrage of facts and insights on the “gender data gap” and the harmful effects of treating males - often 20-something 70 kilo white American males - as the default human.Well researched and cited.

Life-changing. It’s so good to have affirmed with hard facts what women around the world have known for years and live with daily. Women don’t factor in much of the decision-making that takes place in most industries and offices, including medicine, policing, public services and yet they account for half the population, pay taxes, vote.Caroline Criado Perez offers startling facts, cross-referenced to the hilt and it would be interesting to address now that Pandora’s box has been opened, what are the next steps to address imbalances on this scale?

Wow this book is frustrating!  Oh, don’t get me wrong it’s mind-blowing, incredibly well-researched and brilliantly written. The frustrating aspect is how women are quite evidently seen as ‘niche’ and ‘atypical’ versus men despite being 50% of the population! The book tackles a myriad of subjects and expertly unpicks the dismissive thinking behind the ‘pink it and shrink it’ approach of catering to women. Highly recommended but don’t read it before bed as your heart rate will rocket and you’ll struggle to sleep!

I've read a few books recently which should be made space for in the 16-18 curriculum. This is a fascinating multi-disciplinary view of why women don't fit in the world and how we should change to make sure that they do.So many examples of discrimination, thoughtlessness, lack of intellectual rigour, unscientific approaches, etc. There is some irritating repetition - I did occasionally say "I get it!" and want to move on.An education programme built around this book could open the eyes of so many young people, particularly making young men understand better the reason that many women feel that the world often isn't a comfortable place for them.

I had high hopes for this book when I bought it, however I found I couldn’t get through it. The writing style was dense with statistics and information which was a little boring - I would have preferred it to have been broken up with some of the author’s opinions/stories. I ended up stopping reading about a third of the way through. However if you don’t mind a lot of facts, it definitely is an interesting read. Of course I didn’t finish it, but of what I read I felt it could have provided more of an analysis around transgender women as the author seemed to completely equate sex with gender. Overall, though, I don’t doubt it was a good book - just not the right style for me.

The book provides examples in a wide range of circumstances where decisions are taken or conclusions drawn on the basis of inadequate information because data is inadequate, based as it is on only masculine views and perceptions. Caroline Criado Perez makes her points forcibly and tellingly. It is impossible to disagree with the conclusion that far more must be done to disaggregate data, and to get away from the male-dominated views of the world. The book is a somewhat dense and demanding read, but one can only admire the tenacity of the author in pursuing her case over such a wide range.

Absolutely amazing. I’d read lots of good things about this book so borrowed using the library ebook service. Was so good I’ve had to buy a copy as I can imagine I’ll re-read it. I’ve already recommended it to others and lent it to a friend. I’m not a non-fiction fan but it’s easy to read. It really makes you think and while it’s obviously feminist, it’s not man-hating. It’s very objective. My father was really interested in the bits I read to him. More men need to read it to have their eyes opened. A must read for all girls/women even if just to educate you in looking out for your health. (As well as loads more) Caroline Criado Perez also does a regular newsletter via email which is brilliant too.

I'm someone who agrees that men and women should be equal and I really dislike books on feminism that are written to put men down or blame them for current sexism. I'm also a data nerd, I love books that can back up their theories or opinions with stats and make some assumptions about what these stats are saying by looking elsewhere or using previously found knowledge.Caroline absolutely smashes this book, she makes it clear to start that whilst she's pointing out clear discrimination against women using stats, a lot of this has been done unconsciously and because of culture norms (i.e. an office environment is very different for a women in 2021 than in 1970). However, what she does point out is that by using the data we have and challenging norms we can have some incredible positive impacts on women's lives. The biggest issue is that a lot of companies and organisations don't collect data nor split it by sex which ends up meaning that we continuously accidentally discriminate against women. BUT if we become aware we may be doing this we can do something about it.The examples brought up in the book are extremely well thought through. The only issue is that, because there's a lack of data in some places, she jumps from different regions to use the available data. Sometimes this can be a tenuous link with the point she's trying to make. Having said that, an absolutely incredible book that every senior leader at every single company should be reading.

Absolutely one of the best books I have read in a long time. I am not sure why some are saying it comes across as aggressive. I didnt find that myself at all, I think the aggressive perception has more to do with the reader than the style the book is written in. The chapters on medical bias are extremely good and something I have a long personal experience off. I have recommended this to every man and woman I know. Women don't always believe or really understand the bias we face because it is our normal and we just accept it as how it is. If men approach this with an open mind and not from defensive position I think they would get alot out of reading it.
Started reading it and I'm already awed at the detail author have put to create this wonderful book.

This is my initial report from spending one full day with a single chapter of the softcover version of the book. In my daily job, I am a manager who decided to enter the field and understand better the scientists I am hiring and thos who are working for me. I actually wanted to start with the Mock exam which strangely enough appears at the end of the book and not at the start, but maybe the intention was to do the mock exam after a reader finished the book?!  Eventually, I jumped to the chapter on Bayesian Machine learning. Yes, as the author describes, some of the questions are VERY difficult (at least for me), BUT the fact that he carefully clarifies with the solutions-manual and illustrations extensively helped my understanding. I think, the author also managed to cover a wide variety of topics while still connecting them to one another and giving interesting real-life examples and implementations in PyTorch and CPP. The fact that the index is very extensive and easy to use is just the cherry on the top!I promise to update my review again when I finish the chapter.
The preview shows color and it's not a cheap book. How are the graphs going to make sense without the color. Also, the printing is light.

the biggest problem i have with this book is that it is not practical. twice in my life i have been in a stage wherein i needed to interview extensively i.e., hundreds of technical ml/dl interviews (many research based as well) but i have never seen the types of questions this book contains. quite simply no one asks these sorts of questions in interviews in my experience. i  was honestly excited about this book and how it was marketed as the panacea for ml/dl technical interviews but was disappointed. sure the book contains many novel application based questions from physics/medicine/diseases which you have not seen earlier but is that what the point of learning should be. i thought this book had lots of potential to incorporate questions about the latest ml/dl architectures/frameworks and why they work so well but the book did not explore this. so that it where it stands - a well intentioned book with lots of potential but eventually not very useful.

This book is more than a collection of notes and codes.The data is extremely well organized.The first chapters address core subjects in the field such as information theory (that other books forget/ignore).The author addresses good coding conduct using PyTorch / Python /CPP.Many theoretical questions are provided with relevant code answers.The section on MLP's is thoroughly explained.The questions in the Bayesian deep learning chapter are very advanced and force the reader to really understand the subject. This is the book best chapter.Excellent resourceDr. Golan

I spent $50 on this book. Content seems great but the copy I got was black and white. Others seem to have got the colored copy. This is just a steal. Get the e-book instead and study the soft copy. Disappointed.
Very clear solutions and explanations. You can learn something new from every exercise in this book, some of them really hard. Great book to practice with and learn Deep Learning.

This was a present to my son in law who has a masters in Math. 5 star because he wanted this book and loves it!

It's hard to figure out who would actually benefit from this book - it amounts to seven hundred pages of equations interrupted by blocks of text that fail to provide any intuition whatever for the techniques they are describing, and the occasional graph which is remarkable in the universe of graphs as being scarcely more informative than the equations it is meant to illustrate.Seriously, you have to wonder wtf Bishop thought he was doing here.  As a catalog of equations for people who already thoroughly understand the learning algorithms I suppose the book can be considered adequate.  For any didactic purpose you're wasting your time - you can find dense, technically correct but incomprehensible descriptions for any of these methods online, for free.  A textbook ought to aspire to more - should bring some order to the chaos, re-tell a technical story in a new light to make it more sensible and intuitive.  This book is so bad in these regards that it makes me angry.On a related note, I can't believe that Duda and Hart is still the best machine learning / pattern rec. book on the market after thirty years or whatever.  This field is dying for a book by someone with even an INKLING of how to teach, or at least willing to make an effort to try.
