What an amazing book, I got it about a month ago for a self-study routine and every page of this book has been a joy. I am an undergraduate CS major with a decent amount of math experience, and for me this book is a tough but rewarding read. I constantly find myself reading the same section 2 or 3 times in a row, restling with the concepts until I can grasp some intuition of the topics bring discussed. The author is very thorough in their writing, making sure to fill in the details so you dont get left behind in the mathematical notation. The book is filled with beautiful graphs and other figures to further help the reader along in their understanding of machine learning.As a heads up, this book is heavy on the theory and light on the application, so keep that in mind when considering this book for purchase. It isn't going to give you a simple recipe to plug into R. It did however, lay out the intricacies of machine learning in a very abstract and methodical fashion, allowing the reader to gain a much deeper insight into the mechanics of the popular ML techniques than a more practical book would.

This is a fascinating and infuriating book which details the many, many ways that the world we live in is subtly (and not so subtly) biased to favour men. Anyone who thinks feminists are "whinging about nothing" and that it's "all in women's heads" should read this book which gives quantitative, data-based confirmation of what women have long known: it's a man's world.

powerful and extremely well documented account of the gender data gap. An absolute eye opener for everyone, but especially daming and painful for a man. Still, an essential read (yes, even for men) to better understand the warped and biased world we are forced to live in.

This is superb. It gives the evidence for how women are not considered in so many areas of public policy and decision making. It really should be compulsory for all legislators to read. It is the book we have needed for a long time. Delightfully it is a very good read and not at all dreary. A real game changer.

I did not consciously know about the gender data gap in research and how much it affects our daily life. As an independent and semi-confident woman and self-proclaimed feminist I found the statistics presented in this book utterly shocking.This should be a must-read for everyone so that we all know about gender-bias, gender-discrimination, gender data gaps and all the background info that leads to women still being treated as if they are a minority on this planet.

Where to start? The information in this book will be a revelation to many. Even if you have an understanding of how men are used as the default setting, the scope and depth will horrify you. Then it will almost certainly make you very angry  - especially if you are a woman.In my opinion this should be required reading for everyone.I had to read in chunks, not because it wasn't interesting, but because I kept getting angry about the facts and statistics contained in this excellent book. The research is phenomenal and it's dreadful that it has never been done before.

This book is incredible. The author has managed to pull together lots of research and present a compelling argument whilst still managing to make the book accessible to everyone. There is heaps of data but it does not feel dense or difficult to understand. Some of the facts will shock you. I like to think I'm pretty well-versed on the topic, but it was an eye opener to me. I have recommended it to everyone that will listen. Definitely not just a book for women either. I implore you to buy/recommend this for your son, father, partner... everyone!The only qualm I have is the binary approach to gender. The author does point out that they are referring to sex and when you get into the stats it is clear to see why they have to take a binary approach.PS dont be put off by its length - I promise it is not as long as it seems. A big chunk at the end if all the references and citations (which make for interesting secondary reading)

This book shines a light on undeniable facts. If you're unsure about buying it, I would highly recommend having a quick listen to the 'Invisible Women' episode of podcast 99% Invisible, where Perez discusses a few points from the book with podcast host Roman Mars. It blew my mind and it was what led me to buy the book.Contrary to some of the claims in the 1-star reviews below, this is not a sexist book. It just highlights the (sometimes unintentional) sexism of our society that has taken place over god knows how long.

I rarely write reviews but, honestly, I found this book brilliant!  It is easy to read (despite its volume), has some remarkable, eye-opening commentary and makes you stop and think every other page.  As an added bonus, some of the stories provide sound bites that are very useful when chatting to others and getting them to stop and think too about the bias against women in everyday life.  I would say that I already know a fair amount on this subject but the books broad-ranging content has expanded my thinking (and everyone around me as I keep talking about it!).  Thoroughly recommend.

Oh my goodness, what a book! It is meticulously researched, carefully explained to cover both professional and lay people and is very enlightening and somewhat depressing by turns. I want to make it compulsory reading for every University student and politician across the planet. There are so many Eureka moments, I bet it has women sighing deeply at every page saying to themselves, 'Well, of course!' An extraordinary read, I'm so pleased I heard about it on Radio Four programme some years ago.

As a woman, this book makes so much sense to me, and I have a list of people I am either telling to read it, or want to borrow it. I am riveted. I hope it leads to changes for the betterment of humanity. This book needed to be written. Excellent. A serious subject, gripping stuff.

I am not a computer science engineer and did not know anything about ML. However, after reading this book, I can run and train my own customized models to solve problems related to my field (management). The book is much fun to read and the examples used help the user connect things to the real world and not just computer geekery. I would recommend this book to anyone irrespective of their experience with Machine Learning. It is interesting, informative, insightful, and encouraging for anyone to tackle this interesting field.

This book gives a framework for a complete 360 view of how to be a Machine Learning Engineer who can not only solve applied research problems but can also encourage thinking through product angle and eventually productionizing these models and scale them. Given my background in applied research, this was part of the reason for me to pick this book based on the table of contents and it surely hit the mark.  It not only covers theoretical concepts for beginners but also the process of building practical applications widely used across the industry, with the help of checklists, QnA, insights from teams who developed the products.  One of the great part of the book is - all the best practices summarized, well documented for anyone starting new or experienced folks, plus the case studies showing how they were used in actual products. The content covers a range of in-depth details for TensorFlow, Keras, CoreML all the way to cloud concepts for Google Cloud, AWS, Azure. Overall this was a different take on AI than most other online courses I have seen so far, and hence would highly recommend this.

The authors did an excellent job in explaining complex DL topics in a manner in which anyone could easily pick up. Furthermore, the Github repo with sample code allows readers to follow along example training pipelines, which makes everything all the more friendly for beginners. The book uses simple language which effectively guides readers to creating deep learning pipelines on their own. The content of the book is very thorough and covers a variety of different topics, leaving readers ready to create their own practical applications.

This is a great book that gives a practical overview of the AI and ML space. It is project focused, but in a way that is not limiting in scope. While there are many sources and options for learning about ML, this book stands out as being well worth the time and money.

At a time when AI has become such a hot topic for everyone from industry bosses to bloggers and my eighty year old neighbour, it's truly a gift to have encountered a book that doesn't just explain you what it is but teaches you how to do it as well. It's simply your trustful guide through all the other material out there. As a project manager and consultant, I finally managed to make sense of what kind of businesses one can develop from a bottom-up approach to AI. As a teacher in writing and design, the book has allowed me to give my students fun exercises to start having fun with Machine Learning.If AI is a forest, this book is your lamp. Get it now and start building for yourself!

My team at work needed help with practical applications of Machine Learning techniques. We work very closely with our data science team and this book was useful in helping bridge the gap between their theoretical strengths and our practical needs. This book has helped us accelerate this process by examples and other hands-on activities. It has helped accelerate solutions for our customers would recommend for any ML team, engineer, or consumer.

The media could not be loaded.                                                                                   This book (plus the Github resources that come along with it) and some patience is all you need to get started with Deep Learning. I loved the analogies in the book, and the fine balance between theory and practical. I was able to build my own cool things - graphs, search, and videos (see attached) within a few hours. I would recommend this everyone! Can't wait to start working on my pet project now.

As a Networking Engineer, one fine day I decided to pick up this book as I wanted to understand concepts of Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning ; as the next big thing is Intelligent Networks! Honestly I did not have high expectations as my experience tells me that most technical books are heavy and monotonous. But this book was a gush of fresh air. Now before I go into the details , I must mention that only a minimal knowledge of Python and associated libraries like Keras and TensorFlow is a pre-requisite here. Rest assured , the book will take care good care of you and you will end up learning a lot of Python as well , if you already don't know ! Coming back to the meaty stuff .. The writing style is humorous and interactive. It keeps you motivated to read one chapter after the other. Every chapter is followed by a case study that solidifies your understanding and helps you gauge some serious practical applications. In my opinion the writing style makes this text a technical "fairy tale" , if you will. The other point worth mentioning is that you do not need to read sequentially. Once you go past Chapter 3 you can pick up chapters as per your interest/requirements - Mobile Applications , Cloud etc. You can , therefore fine tune your reading as per YOUR requirements. Finally this book has a lot of code . Not only can you run and see the results for yourself, you can also optimize the algorithms for faster execution. Everything is available on the git hub. I highly recommend this book for AI enthusiasts as well as working professionals.
i have the ebook copy, just getting paperback for handy ref

I just finished the amazing book.Here are some of my observations —As an ML practitioner, I can attest that this book serves an equivalent of quick reference of instant tips and tricks that I can use to tune my models. “Lrfinder” trick is a good example with easy to understand python implementation.Most of the ML engineers are tied to one sub domain of machine learning such as text or vision or say recommendations. This book is well written that easy for engineers to get aspirations / ideas from the other domains that they can apply to their problemsI would definitely recommend this book for daily AI practitioners using tensorflow
Will not purchase again, basically just an overview.
This book explains the difficult concepts in very easy and clear ways.

Machine Learning In Computational Finance: Practical algorithms for building artificial intelligence applications          A lot of math - minimum of practical algorithms !I regret buying the book, but could not "Search inside this book"
Machine Learning In Computational Finance: Practical algorithms for building artificial intelligence applications

This book has the simple math represented so complexly with annoying notations!!. It has lot of Bayesian and Gaussian math rather than the concepts of PR. It is hard to read and understand. It is a better text book for Statics Dept than CS dept.
Not nearly enough theoretical justification.

I strongly recommend Bishop's Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning as a textbook. I think it's the best introductory book on this topic. However if you need something advanced, this may not be it. Good luck!
This is a well written text.
It arrived a little bit later than expected, but in perfect condition. I Love it so much <3. It's worth waiting anyway.

I can appreciate others who might think that this is a great book.... but I am a student using it and I have some very different opinions of it.First, although Mr. Bishop is clearly an expert in Machine Learning, he is also obviously a HUGE fan of Bayesian Statistics. The title of the book is misleading as it makes no mention of Bayes at all but EVERY CHAPTER ends with how all of the chapter's contents are combined in a Bayes method.  That's not bad it's just not clear from the title.  The title should be appended with "... using Bayesian Methods"Second, while it is certainly a textbook, the author clearly has an understanding of the material that seems to undermine his ability to explain it.  Though there are mentions of examples there are, in fact, none.  There are many graphics and tiny, trivial indicators, but I can't help to think that every single one of the concepts in the book would have benefited from even a single application.  There aren't any.  I am lead to believe that if you are already aware of many of the methods and techniques that this would be an excellent reference or refresher.  As a student starting out I almost always have no idea what his intentions are.To make matter worse, he occasionally uses symbols that are flat-out confusing.  Why would you use PI for anything other than Pi or Product? He does.  Why use little k, Capital K, and Greek Letter Kappa (a K!) in a series of explanations. He does.  He even references articles that he has written... in 2008!!Every chapter seems to be an exercise to see how many equations he can stuff in it.  There are 300 in Chapter 2 alone.  Over and over and over again I have the feeling that he is trying to TELL me how to ride a bicycle when it would have been so much easier to at least let me see the view from behind the handle bars with my feet on the pedals.  Chapter five on Neural Nets, for example, is abysmally over-complicated.  Would you hand someone a dictionary and ask them to write a poem?  ("Hey, all the words you need are in here!") Of course not.Third, the book mentions that there is a lot of information available on the web site.  The only info available on his website is a brief overview of the text, a detailed overview of the text (that's not a typo.... he has both), an example chapter, links to where the book can be purchased, and (actually, quite useful for creating slides) an archive of all of the figures available in the book.  There are no answers to problems or explorations of any part of the material.  The upcoming book might be amazing and exactly what I am looking for but it could be months away and another $50 or so to purchase it.  Hardly ideal. How about putting some of that MatLab code on your site?  *Something* to crystalize the concepts!Finally, while the intro indicates this might be a good book for Computer Scientists it would actually make more sense to call it a Math book.  More specifically a Statistics book.  There are no methods, no algorithms, no bits of pseudo-code, and (again) no applications are in the text.  Even examples that actually used hard numbers and/or elements from a real problem and explained would be much appreciated.Maybe I am being a little critical and perhaps I want for too much but in my mind if you are writing a book with the goal of TEACHING a subject, it would be in your interest to make things clear and illustrative.  Instead, the book feels more like a combination of "I am smart. Just read this!" and a reference text.

I need a good book about the fundamentals of pattern recognition for my master thesis. Based on the comments here I thought the book would be great in order to understand the concepts of pattern recognition. Furthermore, I hoped to find some useful real life examples in it and some hints about important pre conditions and steps required (e.g. data preparation) before using clustering and classification algorithms. However, the book did not help me at all. I would say that I am not a complete idiot who can't read formulas, but I hoped to learn about the concepts in a more understandable way (something similar to "An Introduction to Statistical Learning").Furthermore, the author's initial statement "I have tried to keep the mathematical content of the book to the minimum necessary to achieve a proper understanding of the field" seems to be a joke for me, e.g. Chapter 4 has 40 pages with about 150 formulas/mathematical equitations.

I was expecting that 700+ book will be scientific monograph. Disappointment: this is a textbook, American style textbook, with wide margins to make notes, color text, color frames, color pictures explaining what is linear regression, gaussian distribution and such.Just to be clear, as a textbook, this is very good text, and deserves 5 starts. But I am giving just one because of disappointment. Sending back to Amazon. This is not what I was looking for

Strikes the right balance between being practical for a (relatively) broad audience, and having enough depth to teach the reader techniques beyond the basics (and pointing the way to further reading).There is a focus on the subset of data science that overlaps with (or is adjacent to) Econometrics, in case that is/isn't what you're looking for

This book is definitely one of must-have in your bookshelf if you want to keep a board horizon about the application of machine learning in economics question or want to find a decent solution for the business problem you ran into.
Do not hesitate. This book open and explain a lot of info
...if what you have been waiting for is an approachable volume on the tools raising the bar for business decision-making.

I am a current student at Booth who didn't get a chance to take Prof. Taddy's course, so I was very excited to dig into this book.  It was mostly what I was hoping for, with a few omissions.First, this is essentially a book on applied statistics from a business perspective, so exactly what you'd be hoping for if you're looking to utilize data science principles in real-world scenarios.  The complexity level of the book is absolutely beyond that of a complete beginner, however.  Familiarity with certain basic mathematical concepts is assumed, as well as a degree of proficiency with R.  I have definitely seen more approachable texts,so if you're a complete novice you may want to start elsewhere.  On the other hand, I don't think this is a book for 'experts' (at least based on some of the physics texts I've worked with in the past).  As the intro says, this is based on a curriculum for MBA students (I'd argue its really for more quantitatively-inclined MBA students), and I think it does a good job balancing on that fine line between novice and expert.However, once you get into it the book is really very detailed, with a lot of good examples.  I've only started my journey through the book, but so far I haven't noticed any glaring issues (nor would I expect to see any, to be honest).The reason I'm deducting a star is the machine learning section - I was really hoping for some useful practical examples of machine learning, convolutional neural nets, and similar.  However the chapter is more of a summarization of some of the research out there and gives a high-level overview of the terminology and actual applictions of AI.  Given that Coursera offers a really approachable course on this whole topic, I was expecting more out of what is essentially a textbook (especially one that advertises machine learning on the cover).If you're looking for a good mid-level work on big data concepts and applied statistics I think this is a great book to pick up (especially as its not priced like a textbook).  On the other hand, if you're looking for depth on ML, CNNs, AI, and similar then you'll want to look elsewhere.  The concepts this book covers are important theoretical background for ML/CNNs/AI, however if you're not a researcher/expert you can certainly get into that space without the depth presented in this book.

Overall, this book is really well done. I definitely recommend it, and certainly recommend it over other, lighter-weight intro to data science books.The author includes the (important) mathematics behind a lot of the statistical intuition and machine learning that's vital to data science, and does so without producing a dry textbook.I also liked how the author included caveats about the shortcomings of the various approaches as well as suggestions and solutions for how to best accommodate the issues that they might introduce.My one (minor) complaint is that the sample code in the book is in the R language. That's fine -- R is still a very common language in data science, and if you work in this field you'll certainly encounter it -- but I would have preferred Python, both for ease of reading and because Python is fast emerging as the dominant language.

Back in my days as an Analyst at a huge corporation in the 90's and early 2000's, I spent my 9 hour days making endless spreadsheets and doing pivot tables a billion different ways to deliver accurate reports for our Senior Executives on a daily, weekly, monthly, etc. basis. One report took so long to filter through the data, I began calling it my "8 hour report" because it literally took me all day to create that particular one each week, between pulling and analyzing all the data in that manual manner. At the time, that was the best we could do. Those days are long gone, and a LOT has changed since then - and most things like that are automated by software these days. I was really curious what businesses are up to these days in terms of data science, and was familiar with the concepts of this book - even though vaguely in some areas - and this really filled in a lot of blanks for me.My oldest son is a computer whiz who is ahead of his time, so I mainly got this book for him - even though it is over both of our heads in many parts. That said, this has invaluable information for anyone looking into Business Data Science, as it combines the best of science and engineering concepts to merge into a business context to take it to the next level - and THIS is what is in demand these days, and on the cutting edge of successful businesses.I like how it outlines the primary parts that make ML work, and how it shows where AI can also come in to help your business. I also like that it shows real world examples on how these things can be applied, especially with A/B experiments and applications of text analysis.There's a lot in here regarding scripting in R, frameworks for cloud computing, and a lot more to help you improve how you use your business data effectively for the best success. It's like a great mash-up of economics, computer science, statistics, etc. that balances well, and it gives you a leg up in your business decisions. While I don't pretend to know everything in this book, it really has a wealth of info and direction for me to dive more thoroughly into, and I think my son will greatly benefit from this book, as well. It certainly gets two thumbs up from us!

For a stat rat (like myself) that was searching for a way to bridge my existing education with an updated primer in machine learning, Matt Taddy's Business Data Science: Combining Machine Learning and Economics to Optimize, Automate, and Accelerate Business Decisions (1st Edition) looked like a promising first step.Unfortunately, my issue is that I didn't really find the AI/ML content to really be all that useful.  I mean, the book does touch on some of the theoretical benefits of using AI/ML, but there's nothing really of any significant depth.  If you're looking to put any of this into practice, than this will not be the only book you need.That aside, the book IS really strong from the standpoint of applied analysis.  The writing is approachable, especially from the perspective of a non-post doc like myself.  The assumed knowledge base is actually on the low side, giving the book a wider audience still, without really killing the usefulness for those with broader data science knowledge in the first place.  Recommended

He has many examples of code at work so you can catch a glimpse of what it's capable of.  Leafing through the book, it looked overwhelming and unusable.  Putting time into it, it starts to make sense.  It helps if you've meddled in R or Python.He goes into great detail about how information can be deceiving and making a solution that can accommodate changing and unknown inputs is rewarding.This book took me a long time to get through, but I'm sure it pales in comparison to the amount of time it took to write.  Nearly every page has algorithms that all would take time to be constructed and tested for accuracy, then explained for their uses.  It's worth every penny.Highly recomennded

As a grad student in business analytics, I'm always on the lookout for a great reference book to keep handy. This is a very comprehensive guide - I would imagine it could be used as a textbook in a broad survey course. If you do not have a background in statistics, linear algebra, and/or computer programming, it would be better to start with an introductory text. This book provides excellent practical examples of how to use data science tools in the real-world. It is easy to get bogged down in theory and miss the (random) forest for the (decision) trees (...that was an attempt a joke, ha...). The examples in the book are in R.

In the chapter of the introduction, the author says the book is primarily about asset pricing. The “asset pricing” here refers to complicated and abstract mathematical models used in academicians. These models plainly complicate the concepts that are already known to us. For practitioners, the models will not give them an insightful idea and an intuitive understanding of how the modern financial market works.The book also does not have program codes, the necessary materials that a modern learning book should have. If you really want to efficiently study how machine learning can be used in finance, I suggest you buy the books written by real experts (say those published by O'Reilly or Springers)

This is one of the best books on ML in Finance, specifically in Asset Pricing. It goes over several models, methodologies, and applications of ML in Asset Pricing. There are no codes or programs that the book provides, but it is clearly not written to serve that purpose anyway. As an academician, I greatly enjoyed reading it and found it extremely useful for my research. I would also definitely use it for a graduate-level ML course in Finance.

If you need a proper introduction to Machine Learning for professional reasons or even just for your own edification, do yourself a favor and pick up this gem of text.Make sure you are 'language agnostic' before you begin. Let me explain, right now the python libraries are all the rage: Pytorch, Keras, TensorFlow, ScikitLearn, etc... Thus, you might be tempted to believe that in getting yourself acquainted with ML in R you are putting yourself at a disadvantage. You'd be wrong.Truth it, you should be approaching the subject with the idea of learning from a conceptual and practical standpoint, albeit at a high level. The language you use will make little difference at the beginning. This was my main concern as I needed to learn "python ML" for professional reasons. Make no mistake, this book along with the available code up on the author's GitHub will guide you through the language, the hard to grasp concepts, and the terminology in a way that is pedagogically so effective that you'd be left wondering how it is that most technical books never reach this level of clarity. You'll be carrying conversations with experienced ML practitioners in no time, without embarrassing yourself (too much).Take it for what it is though, an introduction. If you need to know every pedantic detail about how neural networks learn, the heavy mathematical proofs behind the algorithms, etc., then you'd be much better served looking elsewhere.Once you go through this text, you'll be able to jump on the Python bandwagon all while avoiding the risk of having the language's technicalities distract you from the core concepts.Go for it, happy learning.

I bought this book with some prior knowledge on Machine Learning. I would say that I am very pleased with my purchase. The only weakness of this book is that it mostly offers an intuitive explanation behind the algorithms, without going into much depth. Therefore, the book works extremely well for algorithms that make very small assumptions or whose procedures are simple: Naive Bayes, k-Nearest Neighbors, K-Means, Market Basket Analysis, etc. On the other hand, for more mathematically complicated procedures, like OLS Regression, Support Vector Machines, Neural Networks the explanation is poor because without some math it is really hard to perfectly convey what the model is doing.The examples are well thought and I like how the book works the examples from questions previously posed in the chapter.On the code front, the accompanying code is simple and the book works with datasets that are almost complete, clean, and without entry mistakes (something that NEVER happens in real life). Nevertheless, I believe that the code provided can be translated to real-world situations (I have done it myself for Naive Bayes and K-means, at least.).Things that could improve the book:1 - A mathematical appendix that fleshes out some more complicated algorithms.2 - Exercises at the end of each chapter.3 - More examples.Overall, I think the book is pretty good and enjoyable.

I use this book as a go-to manual that guides me step-by-step in implementing different machine learning techniques. It has a ton of ready code you can use in R. The author explains very well the logic of each technique and this is very helpful to decide what technique to use depending on the nature of the problem you explore.  The book is non-mathematical but it contains references if you want to dig into the math behind the algorithms which I do every now and then even though I come from the humanities (sociology) and business (MBA). I think it is a great book, easy to understand and teaches a lot of very practical skills. I hope the author updates regularly the book with new editions as the techniques and the algorithms evolve over time.

I'm torn. There are some useful gems in this book, and for the most part, the presentation is simple, albeit a bit pedantic and cartoonish at times. If I was trying to get up to snuff on a new machine learning method, I might start here, since it *does* provide starter code for a variety of problems. That's quite handy. It doesn't, however, go into much depth at all on any one topic. You can't read this book and expect to know how to do any one of these methods well. Certainly, it's a tall order to ask any one book to cover all ML topics in depth, but any potential reader should be aware that this just skims the surface of a whole bunch of topics.On top of this, who in the world edited this book? Every other page has horrible typos, missing words, repeated sentences. These are not trivial errors either. This is a book about data analysis and yet the reported data are clearly wrong in places, e.g., a result is listed as .06 percent in one spot and then .0006 in another (p. 271). Basic subject-verb agreement errors riddle the text, e.g. "These output is shown as follows". Sometimes these are trivial errors, but other times you have absolutely no idea what the intended meaning is. I have about 100 pages more to read but I'm starting to wonder if I'm just wasting my time.
Overall liked this book a lot, and can quickly read through. Wish there would be a chapter talking about random forest.

Written in simple language that is easy to understand.For each algorithm, it demonstrates the ideas with a simple example andit explains the basic mathematics used in the algorithm.Of course if you want to get a Ph.D in machine learning, this is not the book for you.However, if you have good technical background in computer science and math,you will learn a lot on the modern machine algorithms.

Amazing book. I can't recommend it enough. Within a day or so, you can be running a Machine Learning algorithm on some data. Lantz provides examples of several different approaches in ML (KNN, SVM, RNN, etc). And then depending on your problem, you can start playing around with the packages.
well written, even novice can use. glad I bought it.  had good recommendations in the internet. explains various algorithms

I really liked this book, I've read about 70% and I feel that it is very well organized. I first tried reading Applied Predictive Modeling, but couldn't grasp the concepts, then I tried this book, and it made learning the concepts waaay more effective because of Lantz writing style and nice illustrations. Its given me a good high level understanding of the various machine learning algorithms and it has some good basic intro to R such as vectors, dataframes, and lists. The hands on exercises were super helpful in learning the concepts also.

If one already knew most of the data mining basics, the correlation, association rules, the basic outline of the algorithms, do not bother with this book. Get documents of the R data mining package to read instead. The book spent large portion discussing entry level concepts of conditional probability, Bayes theorem, etc., then went on illustrate free R package function calls, developed by other contributors, never went in depth or illustrated any interesting and complex problems. Very casual and shallow. The whole book can be shrank to a primer of 10 pages or less. Not recommended.

This book is a great starting point for machine learning. It's not directed towards application, it's more theory driven. If you're uncomfortable with symbolic logic you will struggle with this book. If you don't know symbolic logic I'd suggest a textbook in discrete mathematics before diving into this book. It would also help to know some linear algebra or set theory. If you have at least a Bachelors in Mathematics you'll be able to follow this book easily. That said, this book will help you become a producer of machine learning rather than a consumer of some out-of-the-box ML package.

El libro es un excelente material para comprender las bases del aprendizaje automático, muy recomendable el autor y sin duda un excelente libro de consulta para todos aquellos que se inician en el estudio del aprendizaje automático.Se narra en un estilo muy casual(sin perder formalidad), con una buena cantidad de ejemplos. El libro es un poco viejo pero ayuda a entender las bases de los desarrollos modernos.

Beware, the quality of the paper is as low as it gets. It is extremely thin, and on one side you see the text that is printed on the other side of the paper.Apparently, this print is for Indian market (at least that is what is says on the book).
The packaging was bad, there's crease at the bottom of the book. Book content though is good. I guess that is what I have paid for.
Met all expectations like previously advised...
most of pages are NOT separate!!!  you can't read the book at all. jesus christ, totally disgusting.
Indian version but what matters more is the content.
First of all, the packaging was bad, which got creases in the book edges. Second, the paper quality is bad. Doesn't look like a genuine product.
I loved this book for helpful code on python. It isn't too detailed because it covers a wide range of topics, however it really sets up a base to help google further. Highly recommend
This book is perfect to have on your desk to look up a quick how-to on just about any data science task. It has everything from data wrangling to advanced machine learning techniques.
bad product or misguiding description

I purchased two Packt publications on AI and ML. Both are extremely poorly written, poorly researched and extremely difficult to follow. Language, terms, descriptions and content are difficult to follow at best, or archaic at worst. Nothing is explained and require additional research at almost every step. Screenshots sizes are inconsistent, do not add value and in many cases are blown up to an extent where screenshot fonts well exceeds the book print. This gives the impression images are added to maximize uptake of the book print real estate. In some cases, you have to work out that some instructions are included in screenshots, rather than within the actual text. I have come to the conclusion that Packt publications are no more than résumé fillers for their authors. The publication includes no references. I learned more from YouTube videos. Beware of catchy one liners such as 'A Comprehensive Guide to Building Intelligent Apps for Python Beginners and Developers'. This is nothing more than bait. The book is an insult to the word 'comprehensive', and the best use python beginners may make of this publication is to send it back immediately for a refund and look for an academic and referenced text - Item not as described.

Basic multivariate statistics methods wrapped up in fancy machine learning terminology, which all comes down to methods that were around for decades to say the least. This is one of the books for the SQL data base administrators turned "data scientists" who don't understand statistics or data but want to get some results that probably don't mean anything sensible. Badly written, filled with useless code (why printing code on paper???) with virtually no mathematical notation or explanation of statistical methodology used by various methods implemented in sevaral Python packages. If you need to learn hot to run linear or logistic regression without understanding what you are doing this is a book to buy, though I have seen better written ones.

Easy to read, well structured and very useful. The only caveat I would add is that this is for Python programmers who have a reasonable background in maths but are new to ML, not those in ML looking to pick up Python.

I am impressed about how this book was designed, its layout is very logic and can take you from the basic terms to complicated knowledge, action is louder than speaking, it also use Scikit-learn to teach newbies like me to practice those theories, I will recommend it.P.S. The book focus on supervised and unsupervised machine learning methods, but not much about reinforcement learning.
I’m using this book alongside the machine learning nanodegree by Udacity and it’s brilliant in explaining the why behind key concepts of machine learning!
Great book! Presenting the machine learning algorithms and some of the elements of the linked theory, altogether with Python code is really useful.

This book takes a different approach to teaching ML. Instead of focusing on just concepts, practical hands-on experience is given more priority. Here are some of the pros and cons:Pros:1. Great laid out content.2. Example-based approach.3. Lots of projects to do.4. Teaches how to build a ML model instead of focusing on the underlying concepts only.Cons:1. Little short of concepts, actually.This book serves a great deal. But still you should know about Py-dependencies like NumPy, Pandas, Matplotlib etc. which are explained in O'Reilly's Data Science Handbook quite well.To learn python, I would suggest going for free resources at Udacity, CodeAcademy or even some of O'Reilly's free eBooks.Sometimes you might not understand a particular implementation. In those cases having a little conceptual background helps. I suggest going for Ian Goodfellow's Deep Learning book which can be grabbed for nothing from GitHub. This book explains the concepts immensely well.Thank You.

By far the most complete and accurate hands-on book on machine learning and deep learning. Author has done a remarkable job in giving details in just the right amount. No over-doing or under-doing in this one. Code given in the jupyter notebooks works like a charm and covers almost everything. Highly Recommended!!

Comprehensive. Guides one meticulously through the basics of Machine Learning to more advanced topics and Deep Learning. Ample examples to try out. Excellent mix and balance of theory and working code.

One of the best books I've read on the topic. The right mix of theory and programming.The breadth could've been  better. Nevertheless, great book. Lucid explanations.- Coming from an ML practitioner and someone who has read 20+ books on the ML.
Wonderful introduction to the 5 schools of Machine Learning ! Easily understandable even by a layman :-)

The title of this book is misleading. It is a comprehensive Machine Learning Book. The chapters on Support Vector Machines are the best I have found. I found the treatment of Information Theoritic learning models very useful.

I bought this book to get an up to date view of machine learning and though heavily mathematical this book is certainly worth the effort in areas that take your fancy.I especially like the way Haykin shows how classical ideas e.g. eigenvector decomposition fit within a neural framework - principle component analysis by a single neuron.My reason for only giving 4 stars is the lack of actual examples. The Lena pictures were very instructive, more of these types of real world examples would be useful.I still have lots more to read so may post an update later.
great book.
A good textbook for understand more about learning machine by Neural Networks. The Haykin text is a 'must have' for everyone studying this kind of theoretical approach.

A great reference/text for machine learning with a deep mathematical treatment of the subject. It also presents many computational examples. Highly recommended for graduate students with good mathematical background.

The book has been shipped in less time than expected; I've bought it on sunday and been delivered on friday. The cover is slightly worn due to the travel, but considering the price and the shipping times I really don't care at all. Fully satisfied :) 5 stars

I have bought this book 3 or 4 years ago, but wasn't able to appreciate the content simply because I wasn't ready for that level. It's not a hands-on ML manual, it doesn't have "let's do dropout because it proved to be useful and looks like it works like brain neurons" either. It is very dry but very comprehensive mathematical introduction into ML, although it's a bit old (for example it suggest to use hyperbolic tangent, but nowadays it's well-known that ReLU less prone to saturation). If you need a book with answers on "WHY" it's a right book, if you need a book with answers to "HOW" you better find something else.

Great textbook for graduate students. Broad overview and introduction to many relevant machine learning approaches in use or study today. Deep enough to enable the student to follow what prominent researchers have been publishing about machine learning in journals like Nature or Science in the last 5 years.

Haykin is a well known author in this subspecialty and the content of the book seems fine, but it hasn't been updated much from the 2nd edition despite progress in the field.  I did fine in a course using the book entirely off a 2nd edition copy and kept this 3e text mostly closed for resale value. The only things I had to note were In chapter 2 it has some updates largely regarding the prevailing Bayesian views and in chapter 8 the problems expanded (old 8.06 is 8.10).  As far as presentation, things were done well if sometimes dry (the latter likely because this isn't my area). The required mathematics is presented without tedious re-explanation, but if you aren't prepared for it you might not understand much.

This is a really good textbook, but the index is pretty much useless - I don't know how it was generated but it leaves out lots of key topics. Pessimo pessimo pessimo. Non so cosa sia saltato in mente all'editore di effettuare una revisione del genere. Tale revisione consiste in un cambio di copertina (ora il libro sembra un testo delle scuole elementari), nonchè nel taglio della prefazione, della conclusione e della tavola dei contenuti (indice esteso), che per un libro di quasi 1100 pagine è un elemento assolutamente essenziale. Proprio non capisco perchè abbiano voluto dilaniare in questo modo un testo fantastico. Personalmente lo sto restituendo grazie all'opportunità di recesso offerta da amazon e sto ordinando la versione precedente, disponibile presso i venditori esterni.

I can honestly say that I didn’t enjoy this book. It’s important to read, I learnt loads, but it’s not enjoyable. I saw this book being advertised at my local train station and for a long while I told myself that I needed to purchase it. Now, having read it cover to cover I am so glad that I did. The data information in it is absolutely astonishing and what that reveals is even more mesmerising. From realising that snow clearing CAN be sexist to understanding the power women can have  when they come together has been eye opening, provoking and last but not least liberating. Knowledge definitely is power and every woman or man should read this book if they want to have a better understanding of how biological sex and gender roles continue to shape the word we are living in today. Buy it, read it , take action!
Punchy, comprehensive and very well researched.  Every man should read it and learn.  Every woman should read it and say 'I told you so...'

Really well written, super accessible for a non academic audience and all backed up with excellent research and facts you can share to back up your arguments when trying to make change in your life. The nuances, the subtleties, the ahaa moments, the this is not fair deep breaths, the wow I didn’t know that choruses, the I must do something to change things resolutions.Great write up. I gave this book as a present. The person who got it says this has helped them understand why so many aspects of the world supposed to be "generic" are actually more tailored towards men. Mainly, it is because makers and advertisers often regard men as the norm, consciously or unconsciously.

I am using this book to teach myself the subject and it definitely does the job for me. It probably has no competitors in the category of books which deal with reinforcement learning in a non formal way. I appreciate the intuitive insights that the text provides into algorithms and definitions of RL. At times though I find the book too verbose with unnecessary repetitions which can confuse the message. Some maths oriented minds (like me) could prefer a more formal and more compact presentation.
It is highly recommended and cited book and it really worth reading if you are interested in RL. Nice in-depth explanations as well as exercises. In addition, it is nice that it is a hardcover.

I was really excited when I found this book on Amazon. It seemed like the perfect source to get up to speed with some of Microsoft's new Azure machine learning tools - especially since I am starting a new role at work where I'll be using a lot of these tools.I was ready to give up after the first chapter. It felt like most of it was excerpts from Wikipedia. Also, a lot of the content was wrong! For example, when you have outliers in a dataset, the common practice is to reject them, not "impute alternate values." Where are these "alternate values" coming from if the outlier was obviously outside the expected range? Reading the first chapter felt like reading a term paper about ML written by a college sophomore.I did try to press on, though. I thought, well, the author is more of an expert on applying Microsoft tools than the theory of ML so I'll give the part of the book that is the reason I bought the book in the first place a chance. Sadly, it was no better. It felt like a cobbled together collection of marketing speak about Azure. A lot of times, the sentences didn't even make sense. Plus, the author would talk about an API and then say, this API was deprecated by Microsoft so let's talk about what replaced it. Why talk about the deprecated API at all? It just makes the book confusing.I finally had to admit to myself that, even though I dropped nearly $50 on this book, wasting my time trying to read it was an even greater waste of money.Bottom line: Don't bother with this book. You'll get much more value from the Microsoft Learn learning paths...and they're free!

I was pleasantly surprised that despite the textbook amount of examples and details the book was easy to follow and had plenty of depth to the sections on business economics and the statistic behind it. My only complaint is the section for machine learning, AI and neural networks is a little higher level than I was hoping. It does a good job with some examples as well as a mid/high-level approach. If you are looking for a deep dive into these topics as I was you will be a little disappointed and will need some supplemental material for that.

Positives: The seller responded well, answered all the queries.Negatives: The print quality is terrible. The ink is super light and caused me a headache while reading. I've attached a photo for your reference comparing it with the first edition of the book.
The book is amazing. Just buy it. Amazon’s handling of the book was really poor. It arrived with mold and stains in the book’s cover

Covering a lot of statistics, with snippets of R code and a touch of Python, you will get a good overview of business oriented data science in this book. A caution - if you are not reasonably strong on your stats before you dive into this book, you will quickly become befuddled. I've got 12+ credit hours of stats and found the book a challenge. Having said that, it covers the basics well and touches on pretty much everything from simple linear regression to machine learning and AI. If this is your discipline, it's a good intro.

"Business Data Science: Combining Machine Learning and Economics to Optimize, Automate, and Accelerate Business Decisions" by Matt Taddy is well presented. The ideas and concepts are easy to follow with good flow. I'm giving an extra star for easy to read text and graphics. I wouldn't say this is an accessible read. It is clearly meant for those who actually use data in a scientific manner. That said, the author does a good job of presenting the topic in a clear and concise manner.

I'm fairly new to data science but I'm always looking for new books to learn more on it from different angles. This is an extraordinarily good text that is utterly comprehensive in giving you everything you need to know about the science of Big Data. Very useful for managers or others responsible for implementation oversight. This provides a solid introduction and overview with in depth examples and explanations. Not exactly the most exciting topic but well organized and relatively reader friendly.

Excellent book. It covers all you need to get started with a solid foundation in machine learning. Clearly and well written, with logical step-by-step introduction to the various topics, and good explanations of the relevant libraries, their strengths and weaknesses, and then useful application to specific examples.

The just received the book and noticed that book is  black and white from inside.  This was a big disappointment for me. Though the cost was just Rs 530/-. The fact should have been mentioned in the description by seller. So that customer may have knowledge of it before hand and accordingly buying decision could have been made.

The book's preface says that first part of the book is to introduce the mathematical prerequisites for people from CS background. Usually people studying CS know how to write code but machine learning involves certain kind of math which does not come naturally to most of the computer science students and most of the books dedicate just one or two chapters to introduce those basic concepts, which in my limited experience are not enough. The first part of this book (I believe the first 7-8 chapters) are dedicated to carefully explaining all the theoretical underpinning of Bayesian analysis, graphical models and machine learning. This is the hardest part to cracking machine learning for anyone and I feel this book does a great job at that. Not to mention the examples in the book are really fun and engaging.
Bad rating is for the print quality of paper back version. Print quality is worse than xerox copy quality. Did not expect Cambridge press to go with such worst quality of print.
Good amount of topics covered.

I have been a Python programmer for quite some time now and have been using Python for Machine Learning. Having been a C++ programmer, I was looking for a book that would help me understand how to use C++ for Machine Learning. This book came in at the right time to help me.The book is very well structured with the author clearly setting the tone of the book from the first chapter itself. This book is for people who understand and have reasonable experience in C++. The first chapter gives a good overview of Linear Regression which is one of the basic algorithms used in ML. Chapter 2 explains how to store and process data using data stored in different file formats which is very essential for training and testing of models. The third chapter introduces performance metrics and explains terms like overfitting and underfitting. It also helps us to understand bias and variance characteristics. The second section of this chapter shows how to implement different well-known machine learning models/algorithms like clustering, anomaly detection etc. Chapters 4 to 9 cover these algorithms in greater detail. Chapters 10 and Chapter 11 cover Neural Networks and Sentiment Analysis very nicely. Chapter 12 and Chapter 13 cover the issues that might come up during production deployment and how to overcome the same.What I liked about the book: For every chapter, the author has covered the right amount of theory first before beginning with the C++ implementation. This helps newbie's like me to understand and follow the concept better. At the end of each chapter, the Further Reading Section helped me a lot as I know what to read to get a better understanding of the topic. This one was really helpful. Also, complete examples have been used to explain the algorithms being used which is very helpful.Areas of Improvement: I would have really liked if after every chapter there were a few practise questions that the reader can practise. This would have ensured that the newbie like me has a good grasp of the current chapter before moving on to the next one.

While Python normally does the job just fine when it comes to handling ML and more general analytics tasks, I have wanted for a long time to work on these kinds of problems using C++.  Unfortunately, it has been very difficult to get started because of a severe lack of educational resources out there.  Luckily, this book has finally filled that gap for me.What I really like about the book is that the author has put together a series of very complete examples for each method being discussed.  Every program reads in an actual csv file with the data (as opposed to using some form of random number generation to create a toy example), puts it into the right format to be used with the given implementation of an ML method and then puts together a data set that one can use as output.  As someone who has not had much experience with C++ outside a classroom setting, I found this extremely helpful, and it has made the material immediately applicable to my work in real life.The book covers just the right amount of theory in each chapter as well before diving into the C++ implementation, making the material accessible to developers who are relatively new to data science (which, as I understand, is actually the main target audience).

Was delivered on time. No doubt this is one of the easy to read books with nice coverage. It accompanies a toolbox which gives an idea of implementations. This is not as heavy (in number of pages or readability) as Machine Learning a Probabilisitc Perspective by Kevin P. Murphy or Probabilisitic Graphical Model by Daphne Koller (BTW these are excellent books too but with different expectations from the reader). Concentration inequalities or bounding error in some settings like stuff is missing but that mostly is not a part of standard bayesian toolbox (IKD maybe PAC-Bayes).

This review is not for the content of the book. Its the quality of the book. The pages are of poor quality, it looks like some cheap xerox. Not all figures are in color. Its not worth paying Rs.1500 for this poor quality. Overall a big cheat.
There were some small issues with the order, but the store was quick to resolve them.

I'll be frank and concise.So far I've read the 4 first chapters (graphic models), and the amount of typos is annoying. Fortunately, the author keeps a free online corrected version.  I'm marvelled at how Cambridge University Press is not ashamed of selling a book this expensive with so many typos. They've had almost 10 years to correct them, and I've just bought a book in 2020 with all the typos, so far.The language used by the author sometimes is not as precise as I would like, leaving space for dubious interpretation, and then adding to this the occasional error, and one may conclude that our learning experience is less than ideal. The abundance of examples tries to compensate for his imprecise language, and sometimes it breaks the reading flow... however, they very interesting, and some even fun.The physical quality of the book is remarkable, the paper, the colours... the feeling when I touch it. The font size could be increased a bit, since overall it's not that big to start with, and then the remarks are made with an even smaller font size.I'll update as I progress on my self-study.

A great work on Bayesian machine learning with a full software base for support. The author goes beyond only defining techniques  by actually explaining some small details and consequences of math definitions which you won’t find in other textbooks. The organization of the book contents and different short courses are super helpful. The hardcover print is of great quality. But there is something odd: the whole book is printed in grayscale. Then there is small color printed addendum in the middle of the book with the color figures. But since there are only few figures which require color for understanding this does not really bother.

First its awesome that the author &CUP have provided free PDF of the complete book. Only after looking through the contents, i decided to buy it for my personal library. Prof. Barber has done a great job in introducing probabilistic concepts and putting forth more advanced and interesting techniques. Plus there are many examples throughout the book along with MATLAB codes which really helps a reader. The code is organized as a toolbox of functions with demos for each chapter.Especially for me who has very little background in machine learning this is a self-use textbook. I am still reading the earlier chapters and can recommend it as a reading for graduate and PhD students.Though CUP could have made further corrections to the book. Reading and consulting errata is becoming bothersome too. I hope they rectify it as soon as possible. But apart from this, the book is top notch !!!
This complex subject is treated well enough for savvy beginners. R based, but that's more of a feature than an inconvenient hurdle

Python has hijacked the Machine Learning territory over the last few years since 2014. This leaves the 'C' languages without a comparable foothold in this arena until this book was published. This book covers the gaping void between the 'C' language trained programmers and the Python Machine Language world. It has the same  mathematical introduction theory, but counters with a set of code libraries that work with C++.This book will allow the C++ programmer to expand his programming scope without having to rewrite his entire code base in Python and learn a whole new programming language. Not only will it save enormous amounts of time, but it will also provide and give usage detail for a compatible  PyTorch Deep Learning library for C++code  use. Now the  high performance world of GPU programming is available with a tensor interface to C++ programmers.
To use the examples I need a visual studio 2019 configuration not Linux.

This book contains at least 1 typo per every 2 pages and several figures are misplaced. There has been no copy editing before publication. Additionally, binding is very bad and makes it hard to read.Certainly, this book does not worth it's price.

Unbelievable amount of serious misprints especially in the last half of the book. Titles to chapters are missing, pages are numbered incorrectly. The above photos are just some examples there are too many to upload.It is a pity as some of the content was good, but the misprints make it so difficult to read and refer to. I didn’t notice straight away as I didn’t start reading it as soon as I got it so I feel I am too late to request a refund, but I have never seen a book that has so many and such bad misprints or mistakes!!!

In a world where data continues exponential growth trajectory one needs to be able to make sense of the data. Many times people take data visualizations and statistical reports at face value. If only there was a book to help people cut through the noise of Big Data, Machine Learning, and Artificial Intelligence. The book “Becoming A Data Head” is that book that helps readers cut through the noise and hype of these new realms of leveraging data!The book provides tools and details on how readers can better understand the merits of machine learning, artificial intelligence, and overall use of data. There are also chapters on probabilities, statistics, and regression equations that help set the foundation for the more advance methodologies. I love how the authors break down these complex ideas so that readers can be skeptical and challenge assumptions. In addition readers will know how to ask better questions at the start of a project, so that the data analytics project will provide meaningful results.This book will help people work more efficiently with data scientists and communicate the problems they are trying to solve with data available to them. I highly recommend this book for anyone that wants to improve their understanding of data and the methods that can be used to analyze data sets.

First and foremost, I know the main author well, and I'm happy to see this book finally "hit the shelves". It's a book I would've greatly appreciated as an undergrad in statistics (or even graduate school for that matter), as it discusses a lot of practical aspects about being a good data scientist that my old formula-heavy stats and consulting books tended to gloss over. The authors have a natural talent in explaining complex topics to non-technical audience without all the fluff, and have obviously put a lot of thought into the examples used throughout the book (just take a look at the deep learning chapter!). The book covers a lot of important ground and the material is presented well. I think practitioners, whether in academia or industry, will especially appreciate the chapter on common pitfalls, which highlights several common problems we often run into in applied work. Parts I and II of the  book (Thinking/Speaking like a Data Head) will help build skills that are critical to applied data science (e.g., asking the right questions and thinking  about variation).  Whether you're an experienced data scientist, or just getting started, I wholeheartedly recommend this  book to you.

I am an attorney who purchased the book because data science, analytics, and AI seem to be the future of all industries. This book put data science concepts into relatable and digestible examples and explanations that even I could understand. I can’t think of a single industry or management level that couldn’t benefit from the anecdotal application of this book.

Gutman and Goldmeier filter through much of the noise to break down complex data and statistical concepts we hear today into basic examples and analogies that stick. ‘Becoming a Data Head’ has enabled me to translate my team’s data needs into more tangible business requirements that make sense for our organization. A great read if you want to communicate your data more effectively to drive your business and data science team forward!

I quickly looked through the topics and it seems very useful to what I'm studying and it's nicely compact.  Unfortunately, the book smells overwhelmingly like bad scented fabric softner.  The scent is already giving me a headache, so I might return it and try buying it somewhere else.  I guess I expect a book to smell like paper.

I didn’t know where to start, and this book really helped me understand data science and machine learning without any complicated code. Highly recommend to anyone who works with data or just wants to learn — chapter 12 on deep learning was my favorite!
This book provides an understandable, concise review of the key topics,  nuances, and challenges associated with either being in a data-centric role or in a role that consumes data analytics.

For those who need to get up to speed quickly from zero, this is a great book.  Good foundation knowledge on multiple important subjects lets the reader feel more confident when joining a Data Science Team.

This is an easy read with great examples. Gutman and Goldmeier focus your attention to the biggest challenges to delivering value with data science; hint, its not the math or coding chops. Read this book to shortcut the path to the wisdom necessary to crush it in the corporate world.

Sebastian achieves something really rare: the book is written for applied ML with lots of code, but goes into mathematical depth where needed. The math can be skipped (or later revisited) without losing context.That's just genius!My personal highlights:Page 120: brining features on the same scale can be easily forgotten.Page 136: assessing feature importance with random forestsPage 155: principal component analysis vs. linear discriminant analysis (lots of explanations + code + math = awesome!)Page 214: dealing with class imbalancePage 345: hard vs. soft clusteringI'm not into DL, so I can't comment it.Definitely one of the very best ML books for practitioners on the market while still not being light on theory.Awesome!

Very good book if you're already familiar with Python . Every algorithm is made easy to understand with step by step explantations.I also think this book comes handy for more experienced ML users as there are plenty comparisons between different algorithms which could be useful to address specific problems.

The kindle version of this is entirely useless. Code is formatted as text with added hyphens on some page breaks and indentation all messed up (which matters in Python). Formulae dont render properly as with all books on Kindle and a lot of other missing formatting make reading this book a struggle on the Kindle app (windows). I have purchased the Kindle version here and the pdf version from Packt, the Packt version is much better. If you're looking to buy this book, seek it out on Packt, don't waste your money on the Amazon version as I did

Après avoir regardé les conférences de LeCun au collège de France, j'ai eu envie de passer au concret.Il m'a fallu me replonger dans Python et les classes, ainsi et de regarder les documentations des différentes librairies(Pandas, Numpy, Matplotlib) de façon à comprendre les algorithmes proposés.Pour les tester, j'ai commencé à recopier ligne à ligne, et de temps en temps faire un copier coller.Puis j'ai été soulagé de trouver sur internet l'a ligne de commande de lancement sous python3 :>>> exec(open("./p29.py").read())Je peux ainsi progresser tranquillement.Pour conclure, ce gros volume permet vraiment un apprentissage profond du Deep Learning !

Il est très complet et je le conseille pour ceux qui souhaitent explorer le sujet en profondeur.
