good

I can't pretend to have spent nearly as much time with this book as I've signed up to.  It arrived this afternoon, and it got at least 20 minutes of my time looking ahead at what Professor Abu-Mostafa is going to say to the world tomorrow.  But from page 15 to 27, here is what I can observe.A minor point:  I love the color examples within the book.  When I was in school, we didn't get textbooks like this.The tone of the text is very sympathetic in the direction of one who is interested in the subject.  That is, if you need to learn from data, the text considers what you will need to know to succeed.  The reader's need to understand is prioritized much higher than the reader's need to "be educated".Although I've been out of college for two decades, I have no problem following what the text has to say, or the direction it's headed in.  I don't abstract things magnificently, my calculus isn't that hot, and I slid through school without a probability class as such.  I love math, but I'm not a powerhouse at it compared to the peers who once sat next to me.  But I can follow this text, understand the exercises, and I conjecture that I can work the problems which are meant to be worked.For a non-academic, I have considerable on-the-ground machine learning background.  I've done a lot of backpropagation network training in my day in character recognition, acoustics, finance, and similar disciplines.  This is where I find the text valuable:  it can build on what I already know, and it starts in a place I'm already familiar with.  So if this is your field or one of your fields, the book will make not just a good textbook but a useful reference.So let's talk about what this book is not, and perhaps AMLbook will publish something else for us.  Don't expect a course in neural networks here.  They're not in the table of contents ("hmmm..."), but you'll find them in the index pointing you to the epilogue.  Support vector machines get the same treatment.  Now support vector machines are a little new for me; they came into their own after I finished college.  Neural networks, however, got an earlier start.What I can say is that this text is intentionally tool-neutral.  I just read 13 pages that weren't about neural networks per se, but they covered vital groundwork that I learned via hands-on experience with real neural networks.  My grasp of some of the "why" components of what I know is already improved.I am not in love with whatever chemical processes went into the manufacture of this book.  Perhaps it came off the press so recently that I'm noticing that, and the effects will fade.  For right now, it's a definite don't-cuddle-with volume which drives me to the bathroom sink when I put it down.  I can live with this; it's a small price to pay for the knowledge.The amount I paid for this text was astonishingly low.  No doubt the authors have thought this through carefully, but this text will hold its own against others that cost three to six times what I paid.I apologize if this is not the best-informed review.  I'm hitting send a little early, because at the present time, you don't have many alternatives to read.

Learning From Data is a book on learning theory and few learning algorithms. The book also describes the different methodologies used to evaluate models. In my opinion, this book is not suitable for beginners as it delves into abstract notions that may not be relevant for people who are just coming into the field. I think that this book is for people who already had exposure to machine learning and who are willing to take their understanding to the next step.In conclusion; if you are a newbie avoid this book, otherwise if you already had exposure to machine learning it's a good resource to understand machine learning theory in more depth.

Disappointing read. The arguments for the necessary existence of a Master Algorithm come from all directions: physics, neuroscience, statistics, evolution. This reads like a philosophy book without much bite of substance.Not sure who the intended audience for this excessively-long book is. Certainly neither for the deep thinker nor the practitioner.

Great overview including the math involved, which is explained Ina creative but intuitive way. Some parts require one to reread a couple of times in part because it takes some time to visualize what's going on, but overall very accessible.The last chapter really frames the AI debate over humanity's future very well. It also provides the next steps for people to learn and explore machine learning on their own-it looks fun!

A word of warning: I'm not a machine learning practitioner and not even mathematically inclined. I am merely an average person with a (reasonable) degree of culture (I suppose I classify as a sociologist) looking out to understand the world around me a little better.Yet I loved this book, it opened my eyes on a world I suspected existed somewhere in the depths of my computer or when I did a Google search but that I never understood. If you are afraid to be engulfed in equations, don't be. The author prefers to use allegories and is very good at giving simple explanations, making everything (almost) crystal clear.What you get is a comprehensive overview of where machine learning is going. This is hugely important, considering the sometimes disturbing news you get in the media - not just from Snowden but also from "neurotechnologists" who guide political campaigns by embedding cameras in ads, cameras that detect the viewers' reactions and then adjust the campaign in function of these reactions.Perhaps my only quarrel with this book - but it does not detract from its excellence and the five stars I gave it - is the philosophical position taken by the author. I don't quite share his optimism about our robotic future. And this for 2 reasons:One, the connection between learning algorithms and data. Domingos does note at the outset: "...the more data they [the learners] have, the more intricate the algorithms can be." So without "big data", you don't get "good" learning algorithms - the "bigger" the data, the better the algorithm. Or as Domingos writes, "the more data we have, the more we can learn". True enough. But what about the quality and size of the big data? What if the data is error-filled and we're not aware of it? Can machine learning be aware of something their human masters are not? On what basis? The algorithms are taught to deal with an imperfect world and draw the most likely conclusions, where "most likely" is highly subjective. Or at least, it is "highly subjective" in my opinion and I realize that it is only one opinion and not necessarily one shared by the author.Two, the connection between you as you are and an expanded "digital you": a "model" of who you are, your work experience, your tastes, a model that the algorithm has learned - and thanks to algorithms, you will be able to do more things and faster than ever before. Domingos describes an extraordinary future where, for example, in your LinkedIn account, "you'll immediately interview for every job in the universe that remotely fits your parameters (profession, location, pay, etc) LinkedIn will respond on the spot with a ranked list of the best prospects, and out of those, you'll pick the first company that you want to have a chat with. Same with dating: your model will go on millions of dates so you don't have to..."Big time-saver obviously. But it comes at a cost: you have to give your parameters (stuff about your work, your likes and dislikes) to the algorithms. Ye who go digital, leave behind any notion of privacy...So users of this algorithmic landscape will have few shaded areas in which to hide.But for me, privacy concerns aside (and I'm not that concerned, I have nothing to hide), there is yet another matter that I find more worrisome. Domingos (on p.283) tells us he is confident that the future can only get better: "In fact, it's the systems that have a slight edge in serving us better that will, generation after generation, multiply and take over the gene pool." Then he adds: "Of course, if we're so foolish as to deliberately program a computer to put itself above us, then maybe we'll get what we deserve".Indeed. That is precisely my worry: can we be sure that there won't be a Doctor Evil who will do so? Can we be sure that there won't be an Apprentice Sorcerer who might end up doing this even if unintentionally? A mistake can happen...So yes, I'm deeply worried about this algorithmic future and I don't share the author's unflagging optimism. But that doesn't mean it's a book you shouldn't read. On the contrary, it's a must read precisely because it raises all these fundamental questions about the future of humanity. And it is an easy read even for the non-cognoscenti like myself, I highly recommend the introductory chapters, and if you get bogged down in the middle with all the technicalities, no fear, skip to the last two chapters, they are well worth reading!

Really weird book, in between a scientific journal , science fiction and programming course.A little bit hard to follow the writer's thoughts from time to time, the way the sentences are structured is super dense and convoluted.Overall, a perfect intro to machine learning, would recommend.

I respectfully disagree with reviewers who say this book makes the topic easy to understand. This book give us deep insights about machine learning some times too deep but all the time with concrete examples of the daily life. Finally give us the notion of not being scared about the future but be prepared to be part of this voyage. Is a incredible, inspirational and guide book for the future of mankind.
Very good book both for non experts but also experts to review the main algorithms principles,the applications and to help us reflect where AI can lead us in the near future!

Good general view of AI for the general public and early career AI professionals, the book shows a rather simplistic view of what will be the solution for Genaral Artificial Intelligence, that the author calls "The Master Algorithm." I gave up reading this book at chapter 3 because of the terrible, uneven writing that is indicative of an author or book editor that doesn't care about organizing concepts in a way that is accessible.  It is clear that the author is very knowledgeable, but a very poor communicator.  The book gets of on the wrong foot (in my opinion) with a lot of useless fluffy tropes in chapter 1 about the how AI can transform business and livelihoods, then poses interesting questions in chapter 2 and I got encouraged for a while.  Chapter 3 then turns into an almost flow of consciousness discussion of induction using an example of finding dates / match-making that resembles an intellectual diarrheal discourse.This is when I gave up in frustration.  I have a bachelors and masters in computer science (with a focus on artificial intelligence in the latter) and a PhD in ecology, have been following developments in AI as an interested layman with good foundational knowledge, and was hoping to get a little more in-depth idea of what's going on, but this book is totally useless in that regard.  I have bad books on my Kindle book-shelf, but never felt so compelled to write in irritation about a lousy read.
So much of our lives are being controlled by algorithms; its key to understand what makes them tick so as to stay in control of my choices

I'm a former CTA/Money Manager with nearly 20 years experience in FML. This is the book I wish I had on my desk when I started. I'd be amazed if there wasn't something in here for almost every practitioner and I can't recommend it enough. If you work through this book and the cited research you will literally shave years off of your learning curve and will have a substantial framework to support your own research and creativity.

Advances in Financial Machine Learning" book by dr. Marcos Lopez de Prado is the first book known by me dedicated to this topic written by a  professional and practicioner with many years of experience in real money management. The book is focused on potential pitfalls or over optimistic approaches and how to properly handle them. I fully agree with his approach - with the high computing power available in the Cloud on request, it is very easy to overfit investing strategies and find something which works on past data. Dr. de Prado provides very pragmatic, but also scientifically - backed, approach on  how to handle these situation and properly calculate the real results for a given strategy. Most of the scientific papers and books in this area are focused on machine learning approaches, algorithms and methods. They put less attention to the proper statistical approaches to measure the results. In the book by dr. de Prado the presented machine learning methods  are rather simple, but provided with the complete set of scientific proofs and reasoning. It creates the real value of his work. I recommend this book very much to all investment practitioners, not only in the machine  learning fields but also for the algo/hft trading. And I have also found very interesting and inspiring all other available papers by dr. de Prado.Paweł Skrzypek - AI Investments CTO

There are many famous books that teach you Machine Learning,  Econometrics, Quant Finance. While all these books are good, they often concentrate on the single subject instead of a combination of those. Many of us might be good at Quant Finance or only Machine Learning, but we often find it troubling to connect the bridge between the two worlds. Lopez de Prado's book is a synergy of both Quant Finance and ML in this way.  The book teaches the right way to apply machine learning in finance and covers a lot of applications related to asset allocation, high-frequency finance, Quant Trading etc.The book is divided into 5 parts with each part building up to a more advanced material.  Part one discusses different kinds of financial data and how to use them for analysis and training purposes. Part two discusses modeling covering important algorithms, their merits, and demerits when applied to financial data. Part three concentrates on the dangers of Backtesting in today's practice, and the right way to conduct backtesting, and interpret the backtest statistics as its really important that ML models don't suffer from data mining.  My favorite one in this part was the Machine Learning Asset Allocation chapter which solves the minimum variance problem compared to Markowitz's or Risk Parity methods. Part four discusses various advanced applications related to Quant Trading, Portfolio construction, Market Microstructure. Part five is not for the faint-hearted as it teaches various advanced computer science techniques to speed up the performance ML algorithms in practice.Overall, the book lets you change the way that one traditionally thinks about financial data and ML applications on it.  I'd recommend this book to any aspiring quant working/wants to work in ML quant research. To the people who already purchased, The best way to use the book is to try out the algorithms yourself (All the Python code is on Lopez de Prado's website) and study its applications and results.

I've read almost all the text. I quickly scanned some parts.I'll give it 5 because I like the content and applied some techniques in my work.Compared to other books in the market, this is the one with most advanced topics.What could be better:1. Definitely colorful figures needed because most of the the time it is hard to differentiate shades of gray.2. Code snippets could be available as a flash disk or CD or online. They should not reside in the book. Wastes too much places. Hard to read without coloring of modern IDEs. Copying them to computer would require work.3. Some figures are unnecessary. You can get the main idea in a few figures.4. More drawings instead of math to explain anything. Not everyone should spend time to understand notations, the math and the proofs.I'll read it again and may share more.

As a fresh graduate with some experience in ML and Finance, I found this book to be extremely helpful.A decent Math and ML background is all you need to understand the bleeding edge concepts introduced by Marcos.Marcos has wrote some great breakthrough papers and this book gives a good insight to many of his works.I highly recommend this book to both fresh graduates interested in or entering the asset management industry as well as seasoned professionals. This book introduces you to a new paradigm of finance that has not been documented with such great detail before.The best thing I like about this book is that Marcos unselfishly introduces some of the least documented cutting edge concepts in finance that will improve on even the seemingly latest ideas (he makes traditional risk parity which came to popularity in the last decade look old).Marcos covers a lot of breadth in his book – techniques related to data organization, signal research, strategy allocation and improvement. And these techniques can be applied to a broad range of trading strategies from high frequency signals to slower factor based signals.

Recently I bought Advances in Financial Machine Learning, and it's an amazing work. Working in finance myself, where I head the research program in our company, this book is going to be required reading for anyone even contemplating the development of a quantitative investment strategy. I got very interested in machine learning some 18 months ago. One of the things that drew me to this field, is not so much what you could predict with these techniques, but that it forces you to build a theoretical and statistical framework, that can be used by a machine learning algorithm to assess, and  learn from data in a systematic, and scientifically sound manner. This book goes a long way in explaining why this is so important, whilst also offering a host of techniques, and theory for successfully applying machine learning in finance.

“One day in the near future, Machine Learning will dominate finance, science will curtail guessing, and investing will not mean gambling.” Machine learning is the future of the financial industry and after years of trading and operations experience I learned one thing: you must learn to accept change and adapt quickly. Being new to the field, I was initially hesitant to commit to a 400 page book about financial machine learning. However, nothing in this book is intimidating. Marcos does an excellent job relating each topic to real-life situations. He dissects a complex subject that enables a beginner like myself to understand the material while keeping it appealing to the highest skill level. It’s hard to accomplish that but Marcos did it with perfection and it’s what separates the good books from the great. I highly recommend this book to readers with all skill levels from novices just skimming the surface to professionals with years of machine learning experience.

This is by far the best machine learning book I ever encountered. It points out why common machine learning methods fails in Finance, and most importantly, the solution to fix it as well as the bug in the common python machine learning package. I came to the realization that some of the methods does not work well when I was doing project to forecast stock prize. But I found nothing to back up my realization until I got this book. It is the most insightful machine learning book, not just in the field of Finance.

As a data engineer who has worked with financial data for a number of years, I found the lessons in this book to be effective solutions to real world problems that I faced.  Subsequently it has probably saved me years of potential individual research, trial and error.Aside from the technical application, the author does a great job at explaining 'why' it is important to combat these potential obstacles and biases.  I would recommend this book to any data scientist looking to improve there domain knowledge in financial application or to any quantitative trader or developer.

way overrated imo, you will not learn neither finance nor ML from this book, don't spend your money on this.Given author's tendency for excessive self-promotion I would take any of his advice with a grain of a salt.Besides he seems to have lost a ton of money for AQR, given his short tenure there.if someone is really interested in finance and ML learn each on its own, in finance start with Hull Derivatives, in ML may be some Coursera course.Also quantstart blog has excellent tutorials and 'getting started' guides.

For those trying to get a theoretical handle on Artificial Intelligence, without having to go to engineering school, this book is a godsend. I cannot add much more to what has been said by the likes of Rebonato, Peter Carr and Fabozzi.The book is an excellent treatise that covers all the areas on building quantitative trading strategies, from data cleaning (a crucial step so important to practitioners that is often never discussed) to optimal out-of-sample portfolio allocation and interesting techniques such as deriving optimal strategy parameters without a backtest.The examples in the book are practical and helpful. Indeed I have come across several methods and concepts from the book that I have been able to verify and immediately implement in my own work.I would highly recommend a copy of the book on every quant, trader and portfolio managers desktop."If you have been tasked to develop ML strategies on your own, the odds are stacked against you..."This book moves the odds more in your favour.

Financial Machine Learning is a complex topic, but López de Prado has managed to create a very readable work. You can dip into it almost anywhere and find something useful, even though the presentation is supposed to be sequential.What you get from this book will depend a lot on what you bring to it. López de Prado is quite direct in identifying his "Target Audience", and it helps to have prior knowledge of machine learning and the financial problems it's being applied to.It's impossible for practitioners to strike the right note with every reader. Too much detail for some. Not enough for others. Against this, however, is the value of knowing what a very skilled practitioner finds valuable, and this is something that López de Prado provides in spades.

New perspectives and ‘advances’. A very ambitious take to cover a lot of ground in such a small book, and the author executes it remarkably. Topics covered are pact with information, and most likely there will be a need to go back and reread a few chapters, but one can never have too much of intellectual stimulation! The book bridges the gap between ML and finance, and the author points out many pitfalls to current applications of ML in investment management, and provides alternative solutions. I highly recommend this book to anyone who is a passionate learner and wants to bring innovation to currently saturated field of quantitative finance.

Advances in Financial Machine Learning is the most comprehensive and valuable book that is available today regarding ML for financial applications. No other book or academic journals comes even close. Marocs Lopez De Prado is a real guru in this field and this is evident from the concepts illustrated in the book. The book is well structured covering concepts from financial data structures to labeling, time series transformation, modeling, cross validation, backtesting all the way up to HPC and quantum computing. I strongly recommend this book to quants or anyone interested in applying ML to financial markets, you will realize as Marcos states, that most material and academic journals are filled with incorrect or impractical information. This book is a MUST have!

My boyfriend who bought the book and owns his own quantitative research business provided the following review:This is the definitive reference for current and future quantitative developers and researchers. The author uses his decades worth of industry experience to define the comically numerous shortcomings of traditional financial research and literature and provides novel, effective solutions to these issues. Critically he addresses the problems of time series stationarity vs memory, data sampling, feature engineering, backtest overfitting and more. I can not recommend this book enough.

There are few books available that focus on practical applications of modern machine learning in finance, and this one is a must-read for anyone looking to do work in the field. The author is a world-renowned expert and has a gift for making complex topics accessible to a wide audience. There is a great deal of breath covered in the book, however, there are plenty of references for those interested in deeper exploration. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a rigorous treatment of machine learning in finance.

The content of the book is absolutely amazing as other reviewers have pointed out.  The only problem is that the font size is so small that I need to hold the book less than 12 inches from my eyes to read the text without an uncomfortable strain on my eyes.  Even then it still doesn't feel good to read.I don't understand how some people can be so intelligent, but overlook such basic details of the user experience.  If he had just increased the font by 33% would that damage anything?I would have given it 5 stars if the font was large enough to make reading enjoyable.I got the hard back copy.  I suggest going with the kindle version if you don't want to hurt your eyes.

Excellent book for professionals and students. Chapter 1 is an excellent overview of the book and the future of finance in my opinion. Part 3 (Backtesting) was most useful for me, specifically Chapters 10 (Sizing) and 11 (Backtesting red flags) were practical and well thought out. The code snippets throughout the book are very helpful.  The final section, Part 5 - HP computing gave me something to shoot for - i.e. learning goals.  Lastly, the references throughout the book are GREAT (see pages 20, 149, 158-160, at least those were most useful for myself). Seems like the one star reviews are non specific, and likely a product of the authors not understanding the material.

In the first page, the author claims that this book is different from other books by theory specialists who use mathematics to prove some non real world scenarios.In page 134, the author uses esoteric mathematics to explain losses.Am not against usage of maths. Please be consistent in your usage and descriptions.The book becomes progressively harder to understand and replicate. It moves into higher mathematics and lesser Code.Seems the author would benefit from reading a timeless classic “Code Complete” by Steve McConnell.

As a practitioner who has spent many years developing investment and trading strategies, I believe this book is destined to be a classic in the financial literature, and arguably the most important landmark since Fama's "Foundations in Finance" and Markowitz's portfolio analysis. Addressed to an audience knowledgeable of both finance and machine learning, this book should nonetheless be read by quants without ML background since it provides guidance on the thorniest issues in the design of quantitative investment strategies.Here are, inter alia, some of the topics that are critical to quantitative investment development, but which are not satisfactorily addressed elsewhere: (1) feature extraction for financial time series, (2) variable horizon analysis and trade sizing, (3) modified bootstrapping methods for financial time series, (4) corrected cross-validation for time series, (5) avoiding the statistical malpractice of naive backtesting, (6) machine learning for asset allocation, (7) structural break tests, and (8) entropy features.Many ML skeptics are wary of black box models in general, and in particular will discount de Prado's approach.  To them I would counsel rethinking the paradigm of classical statistics, that models with only a few parameters are invariably overfit. The ML revolution is teaching us that this paradigm is false, that the natural world and the human participants in it have such regular behavior, that models with thousands of parameters designed along the lines of human perceptual and cognitive systems can be accurately fit --- and not overfit!!A must-have addition to any serious quantitative analyst's bookshelf.

Having worked both as a quant at a hedge fund and in data science at a tech startup, the lack of penetration of modern data science and machine learning techniques into everyday quantitative finance has long surprised me. Cross-validation, feature importance, and random forests are commonplace outside of quantitative finance, yet rarely mentioned inside. This is not to say that there are no hurdles that prevent the adoption of these ideas – the non-stationary time series that are common in finance are challenging data sets. What has been needed is someone to address these challenges and bridge the gap between quantitative finance and data science/machine learning.Dr. Marcos López de Prado does a fantastic job of doing just that in Advances in Financial Machine Learning. He provides a detailed description how to turn machine learning and data science theory into practice. The chapters are clear, concise, and full of useful references. Dr. López de Prado goes so far as to include snippets of Python code illustrating exactly his methods. This is no small matter – many quants use the gap between the theory in their papers and the art of putting their theory into practice in order to create a veil of uncertainty that can obscure a lack of robustness or reproducibility in their results. In contrast, Dr. López de Prado seems to invite his readers to use his techniques directly via his code snippets.In addition to the most direct applications of data science and machine learning into quantitative finance, Dr. López de Prado goes in depth on more advanced topics such as creating more rigorous and predictive trading strategies, detecting regime shifts, and breathing new life into risk parity. For any quant looking to move beyond the well-tread techniques of OLS regression, independent and identically distributed random variables, and efficient frontiers into the methods of modern data science and machine learning, Advances in Financial Machine Learning is a must-read.

Marcos has set the stage for a systematic way to labeling meta data and microstructure for machine learning and HPC. This is one of the most critical steps in deciphering the integrity of the data sample and detecting false positives or negatives,which are also invaluable for accuracy of classifiers in predictive analytics. Given my role in business development for AI and deep learning,  I find the use cases and optimization techniques shown here are a great way to validate the foundation of Marcos's approach towards data analytics. I recommend this book as a must-read for anyone interested in the new frontier of machine learning in finance.

López de Prado covers a large number of current topics in finance. He strikes a good balance between theory and real-world analysis, making it a good summary work for the practitioner. He also includes helpful python snippets. Of course, as a practitioner, I always wish to see more coded examples.If you decide not to read this book, I highly recommend you read his list of why ML projects fail. You can find them on the web. From personal experience, I can confirm their truth.

The book gives a summary of the field. The reference at the end of the chapter is a good guide for original papers. One main problem is that the mathematical symbols in the book are all over the place and could be confusing. I did phD in math but in many places it takes me quite a bit of efforts to figure out what the author really means. Hiding behind these inconsistent symbols might give the impression of accuracy but in reality it lowers the standard and does a disservice to serious readers. Either fix those symbols or drop them completely and replace with simple illustrations or examples should be more than sufficient for the next version - if there is one. The ideas are not complicated anyway.

Marcos book is one of the rare gems you find once or twice a year in the overcrowded publication of financial books. His deep academic knowledge of ML combined with top notch experience in Finance, allowed him to deliver a publication that is outstanding in its level of depth, breadth, accuracy and attention to details whose importance are well know to people who actually engage with the market on a daily basis.If you really want to acquire the state of the art knowledge of ML applied to finance, this book is an absolute must.

This book is exceptionally well-written.  It brings to light the many real-world, in the trenches,  challenges of applying machine learning to finance.  Dr. Prado's writing style is quite engaging and left me with many treasures lifted from the often detailed explanations.  Many books are full of academic and theoretical approaches, which often fail in real markets.  This book sheds great light on an end-to-end approach in the financial ML world,  a discussion in and of itself which is invaluable.  I highly recommend this book to all seeking clarity in ML in finance,  and assure you that you will not be disappointed.

As a hedge fund manager, I really enjoyed this book -- and not only for the 'machine learning' aspects of it... There are many smaller takeaways along the way that can be applied more broadly (e.g. data transformations such as fractional differentiation; or how to detect changes in liquidity from the high-low timeseries) that could be applied outside of a machine learning context. So many insights in this book, it should be of interest to a very broad set of traders!

A great book on ML techniques for financial markets. While the book does not take a cookbook approach to specific ML methods, it has a great treatment on creating structures that are well suited for ML. When it comes to back testing, it is perhaps the best book I've read on the topic; Addresses various approaches, pitfalls, and ways to avoid these. Detecting regime shifts, and deflating sharpe ratios are readily implementable. Overall treatment is titled towards time-series modeling. Rather than glancing through the book, spend time to read in detail, and deploy code snippets. All in all, a fantastic book for a HF practitioner.Arun

I'm giving this book 4 starts because it was entertaining read (especially the last chapter), and and because I found a few neat nuggets of knowledge about the connections between various Machine Learning concepts.My issues with this book are:1. It is not clear who the target audience is. It seems like this book is written for everyone and no one. As someone with a background in Machine Learning I would have preferred a few succinct formulas over paragraphs of explanation. For someone without any background in ML on the other hand the explanations won't make a lot of sense - they are full of technical jargon.2. The book is clearly biased towards the author's own point of view and work. Of course that's unavoidable when you're writing a book, but you should at least let your readers know about it. The book is written/marketed as if it represents hard truths, not personal opinions.3. For the topics I was intimately familiar with I found that the authors skims of a lot details and/or doesn't consider developments that address the problems he describes. I also found a few minor mistakes (no major ones). This makes me very skeptical about the sections on topics I am NOT familiar with, which are probably of similar depth.

As an undergraduate researcher in Machine Learning, this book was quite the eye-opener. I'd say that for starters, if you're expecting this book to provide you with a sense of technical understanding on the vast scope of topics covered within, you're misinterpreting the intention. Rather, Pedro Domingos takes you on a journey throughout the history surrounding attempts at cracking the master algorithm. He presents useful and concise interpretations of the different learning tribes (Connectionists, Symbolists, etc.); noting their respective successes and failures. More notably, he concocts his own attempt at the master algorithm, an effort that by no means could be described anything less than luminary. That's the essence of this book in my eyes, to serve as an approachable starting point to understand the fundamentals surrounding a universal learner, and how not to repeat the transgressions of our past so as to eventually instantiate progress.
The author definitely knows the topic but I find it too long for what it has to convey. Other books cover the topics better. It might be fine as your first book on AI and ML.

The ideas and techniques in this book are invaluable not just to finance but to time series data in general. Make sure you have a solid foundation in machine learning before reading this book (try Bishop).

As a practitioner more familiar with traditional techniques in Finance, Advances in Financial and Machine Learning served as a useful and practical summary of the various ways that Machine Learning can be used to tackle problems in Finance. I think this book will also be helpful to people familiar with Machine Learning who are not familiar with Finance. Although I have not worked through all the examples, there is a good mix of theory (motivation), code, and results, along with suggestions for additional research. Great book, the best thing is that it is different. It's a book about Machine Learning that you can read as a novel and the most interesting thing is that you will learn something.Instead of the boring academic formulas-explanation-examples template Pedro uses a very smart narrative to introduce the reader to the different tribes of Machine Learning, there's a very solid description of how the most important ML algorithms work and while the book is intended for beginners it is full of very interesting tidbits that will be appreciated even for experts in the field.There's no unnecessary decoration, no description of skynet or machines taking over the world because that's not what the book is about.The idea of the Master Algorithm is interesting, the way the author tries to lead towards his favorite toys is not solid and is probably the weakest part of the book but we can forgive him because who doesn't like his own research?I think this is a book were you will find many interesting quotes, stories and references, after reading it I kept coming back to some chapters just because I liked how they were written.There's a lot to learn about this book, specially about how to present ML algorithms to students or the general public.

I did not expect an APPLIED machine learning book from an AI researcher. I’m glad I was wrong.The author keeps the academics to a minimum and focuses on applied machine learning.Many authors ‘hide’ their lack of knowledge with mathematical formulas. Not so in this book. Being able to explain complex topics with words + images requires a profound knowledge.- (page 12): Don’t believe the short-term hype. Excellent part of the introduction.- (page 19): You only need two tools to be successful on Kaggle. I heard people being criticized for being too focused – Francois is willing to stand up. Kudos.- (page 31): 0D tensors, 1D tensors, 2D tensors …what are they exactly?- (page 184): word vectors vs. word embeddings explained nicely on two pages only.- (page 188): training word embeddings in Keras – I’m not so sure about it…- (page 225): NLP with 1D convnets. Love it.In my opinion, only two authors can match the quality Francois’s style. That’s Sebastian Raschka and Aurélien Géron.Masterpiece

I'm a CS professor, and I chose this for my course in Deep Learning last term.  Overall I am happy with the book, and will use it again.  It rates 5 (or even 6!) stars for being an approachable introduction to Deep Learning, using the author's excellent Keras library to allow beginners to do remarkable work.  My own class of undergrads was building DLNN models to do sophisticated image recognition tasks after just a few weeks.So, why the four stars?  Because the book is rather "paint by the numbers". The presentation is filled with "Now you'll do this.." followed by working blocks of code for the student to enter and run.  But there are no exercises, code or mathematical.  Even the standard backpropagation algorithm is only qualitatively described -- nice pictures of gradient descent in 2 dimensions, but no hard equations.  (After all, Keras does it all for you, right?)  And as the book ventures into more advanced areas like GANs, VAEs, etc the presentation is increasingly high-level and nonmathematical, providing only a feel for the topics without deep comprehension.  Given the depth of the math involved, I suppose I can't blame Chollet for a bit of handwaving.  But more rigor with deeper explanations would have been nice.

I'm using this as the primary textbook for a Deep Learning course I'm designing right now for the University of Washington professional/continuing education program. I'll also assign readings from the Goodfellow et al. text, but Chollet's book is a more practical way to get started. He is also the author of the Keras framework; it's great to get advice "straight from the horse's mouth".Overall this book is more about practical techniques and python code (in Keras) than about deep learning math/theory. This is probably what the majority of readers are looking for. It's a great synthesis of the most important techniques now (start of 2018), which is hard to get just from reading papers.I would recommend complementing this book with two others:1) as mentioned above:   Deep Learning (Adaptive Computation and Machine Learning series)          2)   Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn and TensorFlow: Concepts, Tools, and Techniques to Build Intelligent Systems
Deep Learning (Adaptive Computation and Machine Learning series)
Hands-On Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn and TensorFlow: Concepts, Tools, and Techniques to Build Intelligent Systems

I cannot recommend this book highly enough.  I have Geron's book on machine learning which is good but I was looking for an explanation of what is under the covers behind the python functions in tensorflow.  Chollet, the author of this book, provides an excellent tutorial on the basics.  He breaks down complex algorithms involving tensors to the many underlying simple calculations.  I like the way he uses python notation to explain the mathematical constructs and operations rather than subscript indices found in most books.  Explanations are aided by effective conceptual diagrams.  I also like the way he advises when sections can be skipped if the reader has familiarity with specific topics.  I find the writing highly readable.

After completing deeplearning.ai courses on coursera.com, I purchased this book to gain a better understanding of Keras.  Keras was used in the courses, but wasn't explained so well.  The author provides that explanation but also adds his perspective on neural networks and valuable insights and historical context.  I don't think you get a depth of understanding for neural networks from the book.  But if you already explored the field of deep learning, this is a great book to help take your exploration to the next level.  I am able to use Keras more effectively to quickly try different architectures.  It's great book and worth the spend.

日本のレビューを見ると星が少ないレビューもありますが、amazon.comで見ると平均4.7とかなり良い評価をもらっています。とは言え、先輩たちの貴重なご意見を参考にしてKindle版ではなく書籍版を購入しました。実際に手を動かしながら読んだ感想から言うと、これまで読んだ日本語の書籍を含む機械学習関連の本の中では最も良かったです。最近読んだ「Pythonではじめる機械学習」もかなり好きな本なのですが、こちらの本は最初の章で機械学習の概要をさらっと説明していたり、機械学習のプロジェクトのステップはこうだよね、というむしろ仕事で機械学習を使いたいと思っている人に対する配慮も見えて良かったです。(「Pythonではじめる〜」は、プロダクトマネージャの方が書いているので、仕方ないですがscikit-learnの中に閉じてしまっている感じがします。)英語と言うことで尻込みする人もいるかも知れませんが、比較的平易な英語で書かれており、分からない用語が出てきたらググれば良いだけの話だと思います。特に前半は、数学的な説明もかなり丁寧で、数学は高校までだった自分でも割とすんなり入っていけました。Githubのレポジトリを見ると本文では書いてないけど、実は知りたいことがさらっと書いてあったり、手を動かしながらやると結構得した気分になります。(そこまで本に書いちゃうと本文の焦点がぼけたり、書籍化のためのお値段が上がるのでは？)年末に良い本を引き当てたなぁと素直に思えます。

I have been studying AI on and off for over 25 years, and have worked on statistical modelling for the past 20 years, including at Caltech and in Wall Street. I am currently running a summer program on Machine Learning in finance at UCL and am writing positions papers on ML, AI and big data. I own a library of Mathematical Statistics, Modelling, AI, Pattern Recognition, Machine Learning, Python, R, etc books and I have to say that this book makes all the others redundant. This is like Wilmott/Hull is for finance, or Kernigen & Ritchie for C.This is so obviously written by a practitioner - someone who has done it and has the scars to show it. Even the title tells you this is for the grown-ups - forget R and all that crap, all roads lead to SKLearn and TensorFlow, via anaconda a Jupyter.Buy this book and "Elements of Statistical Learning" and you have all the library you ever need. If you don't want to get bogged down in the maths, then just buy this one.

I have bought 10 books on ML/DL, and of those this is the 9th book that I have read (actually I have just started reading this book, but it's been so good thus far that I wanted to write a review.) As another reviewer noted, one should read other books on ML/DI to get a deeper understanding of the topic. This book explains using programs instead of using much mathematics. The advantage that I have had is my review of the same topics from other perspectives in books such as the followingIntro to statistical learning (by Hastie et al)Intro to Machine Learning (by Alpaydin)Deep Learning (by Goodfellow, Bengio etc)Hands-on ML w SciKit, Keras and Tensorflow (by Geron)When I first tried to read this book by Chollet in early April I was not as conversant with Python, and so I took a break and decided to brush up my limited Python knowledge by going through the first 6 chapters of "Automate the Boring Stuff with Python" (by Sweigert). Now that I have more knowledge of Python this book by Chollet is so much more comprehensible. As I said I have the advantage of having learned many of these concepts earlier. I bought this book for a class and unfortunately didn't realize that it was missing pages until 1 month before the semester has ended (i.e. 3 months after buying the book).  In Chapter 7 (Advanced Deep Learning Best Practices), this book has blank pages for p. 234-35, 238-39, 242-43 -- 6 pages!!  There is also a wonderful advertisement from the publisher that you can get this book as a free e-book and there are supposed to be codes throughout the book that you can put in to get access. THERE ARE NO CODES ON ANY PAGES!!!  I was hoping to access the free PDF version so that I can view the information on the missing pages but I can't get access to it because the printing issues include a failure to print the codes!!

I was already familiar with deep learning for image and sequence problems.  But this is the book I wish I had started out with.  Good coverage of techniques and concepts, practical, well-explained, with lots of source code.  And Keras is a pretty nice framework for prototyping (I prefer PyTorch).I recommend this book 100% to any student or practitioner of deep learning.However, 20 pages in the middle of my book were faint and very hard to read - an obvious printing error.  My copy is the first printing, purchased in Summer 2018.Also there is some weirdness with the layout; many (many!) words are hyphenated when they don't need to be, such as in the middle of a sentence.  Minor nit that they will hopefully fix in the next printing.

This book is a great hands-on introduction to Keras.  If you expected a Deep Learning (graduate-level) textbook, however, you've come to the wrong place.  This is not it.  If, at the other hand, you're looking for a crash course on Keras that gets you up-and-running in record time without going to too much mathematical overhead, you probably couldn't do much better.So why only 4 stars? Craftsmanship!  The text has been obviously previously formatted differently, and now there are hyphenated  word-breaks in the middle of the lines all over the place - doesn't help a professional look from a publisher's point of view.  Then, nobody caught Chollet's occasional slips when he attributes human sentiments to networks (networks "prefer"... etc) - not overly professional from a scientific point of view.  Then some plots are mislabeled ("Loss" instead of "Accuracy").  All little things, but one can do better.Overall, I would (and have!) recommend this book to a friend to get started with Keras.

The content is generally great. However, some of the libraries the author uses are no longer under development (Theano, python-opencv). Keras has been moved to tensorflow and is no longer a separate library. OpenCV is a pip library and shouldn't be installed with apt. The author's coding style is pretty also bad and hard to read. For example, you shouldn't read a CSV file with 400k rows by creating an empty array, read each line as a string, splitting them on the delimiter, then iterating over each row in the array. That's bad.

Just finished the first three chapters of this book and you can really feel the enthusiasm of the author. He put so much effort in making the book comprehensible. For example, he doesn't use math equations to explain the theory of neural network but turn to Python code instead. It proves way easier to understand for me, someone working in industry for years. He begins by going straight into our first neural network, stating that "we have to start somewhere", which is a very good philosophy. During this "going straight" process, he knows exactly when I, as a beginner, will get puzzled and always put hints at the right place in the book, telling me not to worry if I don't something. He also uses a lot of metaphors to express concepts, making it fun to read but without loss of accuracy.This book is up-to-date and it is a masterpiece.Will update this review as I read through the book.

If you have taken some deep learning classes on Coursera, such as deeplearning.ai or fast.ai class, this book will serve as a refresher and a good tutorial to implement ideas in Keras.  While it does not provide deep theoretical concepts, it explains enough to give you an understanding of what each layer does (conv1D, conv2D, LSTM, GRU, Dense, etc.)  It also teaches about different ways to assemble the networks.  I especially like the chapter that talks about the functional API, where you can have multiple inputs, and multiple outputs, and layer weight sharing.  Most of the other books I read only talked about Sequential models.  This book is not for you, if you are looking for mathematical explanations.  It's perfect for someone who is not too interested in equations, and just want to have practical understanding.

François Chollet does a phenomenal job explaining the background, fundamentals, and applications of deep learning.  His examples in python are comprehensive, but not overly difficult to grasp.  To boot, he offers python examples for free as Jupyter notebooks available through Github, and many of these include excellent commentary.  My one minor minor gripe is that he goes out of his way to avoid introducing mathematical symbols/nomenclature to make his book more accessible, but I sometimes find explaining things with a little mathematical nomenclature could aid in succinctness without losing the audience.

I have never been more excited to write a product review! I purchased "Deep Learning with Python" for a class this past Monday and received it two days later on Wednesday evening, just in time to do a lot of reading during a holiday weekend. It is the end of said holiday weekend, I have meticulously combed through over half the book in four days, and it looks as though it is the oldest book surviving in my expansive library. The first twenty pages of the book have fallen out because the glue did not hold up to my first few days of studying, and I have highlighted text and penned margin comments in the five chapters. The title suggests how this review shall proceed, and I will not delay much longer.The author is clearly an expert who has spent considerable time thinking about this subject and how best to present it. He dispenses with many popular misconceptions and calibrates the state of deep learning as a research field exceptionally well. He even shares his view on where the AI field is headed in the next thirty years, which could be good boiler plate for any reader if he (she) is considering a career in machine learning or data science. When describing network modeling, Chollet offers sage advice on what steps to take when modeling and why those steps are necessary for building effective models.Chollet mentions that he wants to democratize AI, and I believe this book goes too far to that goal. It is written at a level that most readers, regardless of prior background, could understand. He does not make any attempt to point to other literature on the topic, nor does he contextualize or address many technical points surrounding the topic. This book could serve as a good reference if you are self-studying deep learning and need a reference, but I would not buy it again under most circumstances.Why pass on this book? Because there are better references from course materials or other books that are of better quality than this material. I've had the book for four days, it is falling apart because it was cheaply produced, and I do not feel like the material I've gathered from it so far was anything I could not find on YouTube or in an afternoon of carefully mining materials off the internet. (I believe the author even makes most of his code available on github!)To add insult to injury, the book is just not fun to read. It is in gray-scale and the typography is awful. If you insist on buying this book, I can only recommend buying an electronic version at the steepest discount you can find.

This was an incredibly enlightening book. It was also shocking. I had no idea of the extent that bias occurs in the collection of data, the research using the data, and the application of that data to solving problems and designing innovation in the real world. It's as though, as the title of the book suggests, women are completely invisible. I will never look at research data, or the world, in the same way again. This is a must-read for women and men. We need to speak out about this. Fight with women, who are forced to live in a world designed for men and where women must constantly be made to feel out of place. Get this book. Read it. And resist, object, speak up. After reading this book, the world is a different place for me and I hope I never forget the lessons I have learned in reading it.

The book spend an ENORMOUS amount of time talking about the trials and tribulations faced by women with children quite as if, the concept of female was entirely interchangeable with mother.  I got the impression that women who do not have children are quite as invisible to this author as she claims women on the whole are to most men.  When the author started advocating 12 month maternity leave for mother only I gave up on it.  What about those individuals with minor or moderate physical disabilities who would also benefit from parking closer to the building, and more paid time away from the job to tend to their very REAL healthcare needs, these women and men are clearly invisible to this author, I work in a hospital and from what I have observed the out of all the departments in the hospital, including outpatient surgery, the OB has the healthiest patients and one of the lowest mortality rates, so why does a two day stay in the OB garner a minimum of 6 weeks paid leave when end stage renal disease gives you four days a year tops before you have to be back to work? It sound great to say that women should have 12 months off to spend with their new children, but don't these children have fathers wouldn't the fathers like to spend some time with them as well? The author merrily ignores the co-workers of the new parents who are routinely "asked" to cancel vacations sacrifice time with their families and freinds and put their personal lives on hold to contribute to this state of maternal bliss, the childless, the elderly who are past childbearing and might want to start cutting back the hours a day they work or who are already partially retired are invisible non-entities in this model that elevates motherhood to goddess like status in the workplace.  This book has it's own bias similar to that which I have observed to often in the medical profession, when it says "woman" it means uterus, breasts, and children, and not the people who make up the female half of the population, some of whom will not have uteri, some of whom will not have breasts, and many of whom will not have young children.

Machine learning books have become a dime a dozen. From the moment of receiving this one it was obvious this one stands out from the crowd. Having many such volumes what makes this book special is the depth of coverage in succinct english with examples that clearly illustrates the subject area being discussed.As a newbie to TensorFlow this book is a very good starting point in the journey to proficiency. If you are looking for concise starting points in the areas of machine learning concepts discussed, this book again hits the mark in a clarity not seen in the many other books now collecting dust in my library. The Greeks and mathematical proofs have thankfully left out as if you at the level the book is written to you don't really care anymore. Life's classroom frankly are your results, not a peer review and this book is very much for the practitioner not the academic looking to impress his colleagues in academia.This is a book worthy of being added to your machine learning library and in close proximity to the keyboard as you code to refresh what you thought you knew but long ago forgot was important. Just might donate my machine learning books to others at the local library as this book stands alone in taking up valuable space in a ever decreasing bookcase.
