Absolutely a must to read! You will learn a lot about learning machines and the (possible) Master Algorithm. In fact Nature and Evolution is already one big algorithm. I strongly advise this remarkable book from Pedro Domingos.

High level book focusing on concepts rather than techniques, an excellent introduction to the field and the five types of algorithms.  This book not only tied together a lot of things I had read in other places but gave me some pointers to areas I hadn't paid attention to before (Markov chains).
Solid intro to machine learning. Author at times takes metaphors a bit to far. For anyone without a PhD in CS this is a great book to start with.
AI is both important and complicated. This book provides an excellent overview of what machine learning is and where it is going. The details may require some skimming, but it's worth the journey.
Must read book on the manipulators.
Interesting perspective on machine learning and artificial neural networks.
Great book.
A book beautifully written to cover the landscape of machine learn theory and applications, as well as a glimpse of future.

I picked up this book because it was on the recommended list from Bill Gates. The book starts out well in terms on framing the different approaches to machine learning but the author fails to communicate why a certain approach excels.  This book is neither for non-professional machine learner nor for an amateur machine learner nor for a professional in any of the different branches of machine learning. Feels like introductory chapter of Author's PhD thesis expanded unnecessarily.
Even connected with the Author!
Exactly what I expected, delivered when promised!
This is one of the best known books on application of Machine Learning to finance.
Highly recommended, very well known in the space.
great book！
It is a great book but not for new leaner.
Great overall, just what I needed
It is a survey of old methods preparing the data and computing old fashion statistics. Not a update-to-date machine learning book about trading or anything.
Other than that the content of the book is okay.
Great simplification of the process of building.

Up to chapter 4. Very pleased with overview of deep learning landscape.  Instructions for setting up a rig are slightly out of date and there are subtle challenges installing the nvidia driver/cudaXX on current Ubuntu 18.04 vs the 16.04 from the book.  Updating the kernel was a key step in my case.  Still, that's to be expected.  I like the top-down approach with Keras sprinkled with increasing amounts of detail as you progress.  Really enjoying coding along the way.  Using python3 + JetBrains PyCharm IDE for both notebooks and straight up py's.

If this is your first book on machine learning, this book will serve as a survey course across the many areas and topics associated with machine learning. It, however, does not go into any of them in any depth and will leave you with a sea of code that, while functional, will only scratch the surface of what you need to know to use Keras effectively in a real project. For those just getting into the space, it is an invaluable resource to read through so that you can see some use cases for Keras.

Francois Chollet has a great talent to explain even complicated things in a very clear and intuitive way. The book has just enough details: touching all important things and at the same time not going too deep and away from the subject. I found it as an excellent addition to Deep Learning specialization from Andrew Ng on Coursera. I read it from cover to cover, practiced with all examples. These examples are well explained, detailed, and self-sufficient. If you want to try something, just do it - as the book provides all the details you need (you don't even need your own environment - just use colab.research.google.com). So, I want to say big Thank You to Francois for doing such great things for the machine learning community!

Coming from a non-data science background (IT networking), data science is an add-on skill to my foundation.  I do not need to fully understand all of the mathematical theory - instead I need to know how to use deep learning to develop use-cases.  I bought this book to understand what I could do with deep learning in Keras.  I got so much more than I expected.  Having written a single chapter in my own book about algorithms in general, I understand the challenges of trying to explain algorithms enough for general understanding, while not getting too far down the rabbit hole.  I thought this book went to a perfect depth to understand the possibilities with deep learning, and to get hands on creating useful outcomes.  Thanks Francois for the time well spent.

This book is very useful for an introduction to machine learning in Python using the Keras package. Using this book in conjunction with Hands on Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn and Tensorflow by Aurelien Geron is even better since the books are complementary and deal with the subject matter in different levels of abstraction. I also find the book Deep Learning by Ian Goodfellow to be a useful supplement for a more fundamental presentation of the mathematics and conceptual approaches.

The book goes into sufficient detail to explain what is going on and why things are done for different analysis options.  Since I am just beginning in this field it was a good way to get started, although it is a pretty complex subject.  I would recommend it to anyone who is interested in getting started in AI/Deep Learning.

Great book. I have already taken machine learning by Ng on Coursera, and this book just helped me to the next level. Everything is well written with clear logic and even Python code is annotated in this book. I am half way thru the book and can't wait to finish it.Highly recommended for those who wants to learn deep learning.

Absolutely essential reading for computer vision scientists.  This book provides clear, step-by-step explanations of how to configure modern neural networks with forthright recommendations for standard problems.  This gives simple, high-level examples that don't take a month to get a result, providing a sandbox to truly learn how to manipulate neural networks.

I haven’t read the book yet, but the codes in the book do not get my manning.com ebook.The book is purchased from “Scramble book store.”  Note that legitimate Manning books have codes on specific pages to obtain the ebook from them.  I am working with Manning to see what can be done.  I suspect this is a knockoff or otherwise shady.  I will update this review in the next couple of days.

The author of this book works at Google and helps develop the fantastic Keras library to help devs use Tensorflow more easily and build out other neat DL applications with Tensorflow.  Overall a great book, the only addition I would ask for are easier setup instructions to configure either locally or on AWS / GCP (the current instructions are not as clean as the Tensorflow website).

I use this book for my ML-exercises and for getting started with Deep Learning & TensorFlow.This book is the first one which prepares for training deep learning neuronal networks and if you have the hardware, it helps to do it distributed across several computers or at least with more than one GPU.It starts with well written explanations about all common kinds of Machne Learning. Machine Learning algorithms like k-nearest-neighbour, decision trees, SVM and regression are explained with all the math needed (but not too much) and with practical code in Python. Before TensorFlow is used, this book introduces Scikit-Learn as the most important library for ML (and preprocessing and scoring) in Python. All graphics are informative and easy to understand. As this book is going from common Machine Learning _deep_ into Deep Learning, I absolutly do recommend it.
A Great reference.May it should introduce the user to python before starting reading and practicing.i would recommend it.
Book aint got da color fam. Get this sheezy online.

I've been involved in machine learning as a researcher / practitioner for 5 years, but used R for most of it and was originally reluctant to move to Python (learning pandas, numpy, scipy, and scikit-learn is an intimidating hill to climb when you're already so comfortable in R).I got this book for the deep learning portion (about half of the overall book length), and was shocked at the clarity of the conceptual explanations and code implementations. I've read many extensive explanations of important neural network architectures (FFNs, CNNs, RNNs, ...) and none of them were this clear and intuitive. Within 5 days I was able to go from having zero deep learning experience to easily implementing complicated architectures with TensorFlow.Many people recommend Keras as an alternative to TensorFlow, and I agree... but reading this book allowed me to understand the structure of the underlying code enough to use Keras much more effectively than if I had just started there and never learned what's going on under the hood.I was so impressed with the deep learning portion of this book that I went back and read the rest of it. I can't recommend this work highly enough.

This book is absolutely wonderful. I like how each chapter is connected to the previous chapters. Not a book for the complete newbie, nevertheless it's well written and flows very well.I haven't completed the book, but my intention is to do so very soon.I give this book 5/5

コードを写経するだけではエラーが起きる箇所がある。著者のGitHubではアップデートされたコードが公開されされているものの、どこが変わっているのかなどを本と照らし合わせて確認しないといけないため極めて非効率。また、前提となるclassの作成について後から補足される等により、デバッグに無駄な時間を費やす等、フラストレーションが溜まることが多かった。コンテンツ自体は良いものの、全体的に不完全・不親切な内容なので改訂版を待つことを強く勧める。

Complete waste of money... How come every book in this field is half baked waste of paper... It's frustrating. 6000 yen for this shit?!?! Unbelievable. The second half where the author diverges into nueral networks and Tensorflow is absurdly brief regarding the principles of working. Even the code part is not clear. Especially the way the author introduces each new function as just tidbit add-ons is irritating. Where the fuck are you supposed to insert these functions in the original code??? If the price had been reasonable it would have still been a half way decent book. 6000 fucking yen for this ?? Unfucking believable.

This has to be at the top of my list of most highly recommended books! The amount of material it covers is awesome, and I can find almost no fault with it. The writing is extremely clear, easy to read, written in impeccable English. Very well edited. I don't think I came across any spelling or grammar errors, or any real errors at all. Truly solid writing.The breadth of information covered if quite wide. The choice to start with Scikit-Learn was interesting, but makes sense on some level while he's introducing the more basic machine learning concepts. Simple machine learning techniques like logistic regression, data conditioning, dealing with training, validation, test set. Even if you've read about these concepts a million times, you might still glean useful information from these pages.The Tensorflow section is also super well done. Straightforward setup instructions, pretty intelligible explanation of the basic concepts (variables, placeholders, layers, etc.) to get you started. The example code is quite good, and the notebooks are quite complete and seem to work well, with maybe a few tweaks and additional setup for some. I also found that the notebooks show more examples than what's in the book, which can be nice.I only went really hands on with the reinforcement learning notebook, and found that it was well done and a good base to start my own work from. Even just having a section on reinforcement learning is very rare in a book of this style, and Geron's samples and explanations are really solid. He obviously has a strong grasp of many varied fields within deep learning, and that includes reinforcement learning. The only thing I wish it had was an A3C sample, to make my life that much easier. But you can't have everything.I really liked his tips on which types of layers, activations, regularization, etc. are most effective, and gives good starting points for decent convergence. His explanation of multi-GPU Tensorflow was also quite good. The Tensorboard section was also very useful.In short, if you want ONE book to get you into machine learning, and Tensforlow is on your radar, you can't go wrong with this one. Highly recommended!

I bought this book awhile back, but did not have time to study it. Now that I have had a chance to sit down with the book I have some good things and some bad things to say about the book.The good?The author does a good job in trying to present information in such a way that it gets you thinking about the problems you are trying to solve. The second chapter is a full blown project to take you through the full development cycle.There is quite a bit of code and beginnings of mathematical models presented in the book. So, there is plenty to step off from.The Bad?Most of the code will execute in what ever environment you run your python code in. However, if you want the more optimum or even all the functions used, you will need to go to the authors github repository for the book. I have spent more time on the repository than I have in the book.The book is very Jupyter-centric.The Missing?Deeper explanations! The whole book feels like a 40000 ft view of the subject matter. It also is written from the perspective that you have an intimate knowledge of the python programming language and its libraries. He gives no explanation of builtin functions or methods anywhere in the book or on the repo.I do understand that this is not a theory book, but a little more explanation as to why we are using the libraries, functions, or methods that we are using would be far more beneficial.

I have been a collector of books and classes of machine learning and deep learning for the last few years. Even though I come from a strong theoretical background, I have to say one must do hands on tinkering to be able to solve one's own problem successfully. Then for deep learning one must work with Tensorflow or Theano. However, I have been searching for a good hands-on book on tensorflow and had found none until this book.I purchased the kindle version so I can dive into this book early before the book comes out. I am not disappointed. It gives you the code on the familiar Python notebook to work on. The author really knows about Tensorflow and machine learning, and his teaching shows. There are pieces of information hard to find somewhere else, and I have spent hundreds to thousands to attend workshops.Needless to say, I have not done all the exercises yet. But I like this book enough that I will work on all the problems I am interested in.One disappointment though. I was hoping Keras, a high level api that enables fast experiments, is covered. It is not in this version. Sure hope it will be covered in the updated version.

The book is a good place to start if you want to know more about machine learning. It won't help with technicalities but will give a great general understanding of what machine learning is and what to do next
Provides a high level understanding and starts the thought proton this subject. Enjoyed it and will recommend it to anyone who is intellectually curious.

The examples and language are not well polished and become needlessly detailed for a non expert, though commentary on Bayesian was a great. Writing is not tight at spots and some superficial comments like "why not win robot war if its a competition" are jaw dropping. Ray kurzweil has used "singularity" metaphorically but he starts attacking that literally. If you are indeed designing brain's native algorithm, which may imitate emotions, why is not possible for a machine to have freewill. The author is "tool heavy", someone who knows how to program but individual examples (say from medicine) again lack depth and understanding. It just is good though to know what kind of hacks are trying to shape the digital world. The exhibition of lack of rigor is insightful before we become slave of technology.
Complex to read for me
Great information, though it can be repetitive at times
Excellent overview of the field from a conceptual point of view.
Extraordinary book, everybody should read it because machine learning is going to change everyone's life

Look around, Pedro invites firmly, this is the AGE OF ALGORITHMS! After convincing you, he goes about defending the hypothesis of a master algorithm or the universal learner; just imagine machines behaving like babies. If evolution created babies, maybe we can create something similar. Hey, the fun here comes from Pedro’s ingenious argument starting from Hume and doing synthesis of many bodies of knowledge. Of course, the whole thing converges to machine learning algorithms and he is inviting us to join him. The further reading section is a gold mine; Pedro is a well-read scientist, the master algorithm chapter is thrilling (Asimov level detected!).

Nice overview and interesting insights from the perspective of Pedro Domingos, one of the leaders in the field of machine learning. Easy read. Accessible for managers and enjoyable for practitioners in the field.

The Master Algorithm by Pedro Domingos is a fascinating and accessible deep dive into artificial intelligence written by a giant in the field. It explains the history, functionality, limitations, promise, and implications of a technology that is reshaping nearly every industry. The first and last chapter are particularly important as they provide the conceptual framework for making sense of the machine learning universe. If you want to understand where computing is headed, this is required reading.
I like this book. My mind is being prepared to any future, because of future is now.
It a great example of how ML can be used and how to work with the data. I can't wait for the solution manual to come out!

This is not just a book about trading with computers, but a complete manifesto that changes the discussion about what finance will be in the future. Amazingly, it's not just a bunch of academic theories, but confirmed (by me and others) concepts, math and code that have been used to make billions of dollars.This makes it required reading for advanced practitioners who have already faced the real problems associated with data curation, tactical asset allocation, and portfolio construction. If you want to discover how to get beyond the stagnant financial paradigms that we've all been stuck with for decades read this book. Truly revolutionary!
Cover was worn out and an index page was sticking out, detached from the spine. Otherwise, the book itself and the remaining pages are fine.
The book includes many tables; none of them is readable on Kindle.
Not about machine learning. All about data transformation. Less than origional.

deviating too much from the key thing that wall street people make money. This is not a good book. The author seems don’t know the really important things in financial markets. Also, this author seems don’t know machine learning at all... He is not a machine learning expert. The microstructure part is poorly written and he seems to have limited knowledge about it.

I got this book because I read de Prado's article about "The 10 reasons why machine learning funds fail" and wanted to get more depth on each of the pitfalls in the paper.  I only wished I got a chance to read the book earlier; I pretty much re-invented the wheel on bootstrapping non-iid samples but I had to think about two months about the problem.  I recommend this book for anyone that does any kind of quantitative trading as some of the concepts are not necessarily machine learning related.  I never stopped being amazed about how many traders place quantitative bets valued with many zeros without a proper grasp of how cross validation works and how information leaks during back testing from training/validation/test sets.To my knowledge there's no other book with better presentation of machine learning problems that are specific to time series prediction in finance. The best standard books in ML and AI fields focus on vision, language, and scale which are not useful in the context of finance.  In this context the biggest problems are auto correlated data, training samples of small size, non stationary time series,etc. all of which get detailed explanations and recipes for success in the book.

Caroline Criado Perez reveals compelling evidence that what is male is seen as universal, and what is female is seen as atypical and most often ignored.  The consequences for women include leading a more challenging, poorer and sicker life.  When it comes to cars, they are far more likely to be seriously injured than a man.Invisible Women is Perez's call to action to business leaders, government officials, universities, particularly medical schools, health care professionals, pharmaceutical companies and urban planners.  By minimizing and ignoring women's perspectives, these institutions are depriving their organizations of 50% of the available world intellect and experiential resource.  As a result, they are also being deprived of higher revenue.  Closing the female representation gap is in the best interest of men too, because the well-being of their wives, mothers and daughters is seriously at stake.Book Review written by Shirley Roberts, Author of Harness the Future.

This book is a most to understand lots of concepts in deep learning, because some times you cant land many things with math.Me as a software developer with 20] of experience trying to get into this feel has help me to understand lots of things because it is not a math book, which you get lost.....

Well researched facts, arguments I would have never thought of. What's going on in this world? If more people read this book, we have better discussions and we can all work on change. Thanks for this book and the impact it has!

As a man, I was really hoping this book can give me new insights into how women experience the world, I was expecting that I can understand my biases and was ready to be convinced by real data.The author did a good job on listing out the citations, but if you look into them closely, you will notice that most of them are from internet articles and blogs. Only 1 out of 10 citation is actually from a legit reseach paper.For example, in chapter 4, author argues that there is a "strong evidence" that woman are discriminated at workplace because "an analysis of 248 performance reviews collected from a variety of US based tech companies receive negative personality criticism that men simply don't". This citation comes from an internet article where the author does not explain how data is collected, what are the questions on the survey, and wether or not there are other factors involved....Again, you can argue that this is because not enough academic studies are done on gender biases because female researchers are discriminated and their work don't get published, but I don't see any researches that can prove this bias exist.Overall, one star, because author did not use any real data that are credible.

Este libro hace un punto muy importante. El mundo ha sido diseñado para el hombre "medio". Los teléfonos inteligentes son demasiado grandes. Las sillas son demasiado altas. Estos pequeños inconvenientes son omnipresentes y un recordatorio constante. Pero este fenómeno se manifiesta también en situaciones graves como la medicina con un efecto absolutamente devastador.El autor cita más evidencia de apoyo que la mayoría, sin embargo, el libro no ofrece sugerencias sólidas de soluciones.Un capítulo critica, correctamente, el PIB como una medida inexacta de la actividad económica. Pero luego el autor hace una sugerencia bastante simplista de que el crecimiento económico podría lograrse alentando a más mujeres al trabajo remunerado a través de una mejor política fiscal y el cuidado de los niños.

Interesting and very relevant topic. The book has definitely led to more than one heated discussion with various people! My only complaint would be, that the argument seems very one-sided at times. But then again, this book delivers exactly what it says in the title.

Consistently and orderly giving the deep learning basics and some more popular specifics. Very good!2 caveats: the book binding quality is very mediocre; the advertised download of the electronic version of the book plainly does not work.

I am reading this book very carefully, it is a great resource for learning about deep learning and neural nets... but in chapter 3 the pages are out of order.  I was so confused until I figured out why it seemed o be jumping around all over the place.  I can read this book for free online, but paid for a hard copy because it is such a great resource.  But the pages being out of order makes me regret the purchase.

Started reading this to enforce what I learnt on my master, can't tell you how much this has helped me to speak with confidence regarding design and principles. The math part covered is good enough to understad what's behind deep learning.

I cannot see well enough to read a paper book, but I bought the paper book because it came with an ebook offer that I could read on my 40 inch screen. Sadly the system does not work. I was sent to a matrix of number, that I entered using a strong magnifier. But it did not work.
It helped me to more understand my main obstacles at work for being a woman. It also gave me the decision to work harder for the next generation of women.

Very informative on the GDP and data bias, there were also many things to be learnt about the tech business.A minor note I must add as a medic is concussions seem to be seen as something women suffer more of, which isn't based on sex, but on gender(they are more likely to be sufferers of domestic violence) whereas women who did sports as children and received concussions have minor effects when receiving concussions as adults, as compared to women who have a concussion for the first time. The first concussion is the one with the most symptoms(an observation made in women, but not men, perhaps because men already received injuries and concussions as children and adolescents through sports the women studied were unlikely to have played in their youth, or perhaps a biological sex difference in response to trauma lessened in further head injuries because the body has already experienced it, this is all open to study).As always with health and fitness, best to be active in youth to reduce injuries and illnesses in adulthood, however most women do not have access to quality taught sports and end up with injuries they continue to work through from their unpaid overwork, which as we know, being active is good but not resting and overdoing it means you have heightened chances of injury, heightened risk of delayed recovery when physically working while injured, risks of further injury and also of health problems in the long run.However on the topic of head injuries, it is still men who suffer worse brain injuries than women even when gender based occupations and behaviours are taken into account.Of course, that does not mean we should ignore it's effects in women but the misinformation of women suffering longer comes from a study of athletes that did not take into account female athletes receive less funding, thus less funding for medical care and that the athletes in question continued to play while injured(which makes an injury worse) and were not diagnosed immediately, thus a gender gap being mistaken as a sex gap. Another study who took this into account and diagnosed male and female athletes immediately following an impact to the head found that there was no sex or gender difference in recovery speed when diagnosed early.However, there is a gender difference when athletes do not have access to care and continue to play injured.Domestic violence survivors are unlikely to receive or seek help immediately following an injury to the head and explains the gender gap there. More must be done to help women and men suffering from concussions, and more must be done to involve women in all areas of decision making for the betterment of women and all of humanity as a whole.This was a very easy to read book and I recommend it to anyone looking to learn on a data gap, and to everyone who doesn't think about it but to whom it will open their eyes.The book arrived in perfect condition and I am pleased with my purchase.
Important book, enlightening and builds a strong case for change.Highlights things we (subconsciously) know but might not be aware of yet.

This book painstakingly catalogues the myriad ways in which women are short changed, ignored and harmed by our male centred society (Actually our male centred earth, it seems no country is immune).Every page has dozens of links to references.

Dit is een echte verrijking van je kennis. Het is soms ook wel weer heel pijnlijk of schandelijk dat de werkelijkheid zo is maar ik heb heel veel mensen gesproken die door de voorbeelden zijn verrast. Het zou heel goed zijn om designers en architecten dit kado te doen. Bijvoorbeeld.

I have ordered tens of books of books from Amazon overseas.There were many times when the corners of the books were crumbled,front/back cover dirty, showing sign of age when it's suppose to be new..but this is the first time when I've seen a really nice packaging on my delivery of books overseas.No crumbles, good as new, safely delivered - even before the delivery due date!Very satisfied.

A waste of excellant material placed on a book in which the pages are falling apart! An insult to the author and the readers. Manning, I implore you to publish the next edition, soon, with a firmer binding of the pages. I shall be the 1st receipient of this edition and a champion advertiser. Sri

Francois Chollet gives clear, intuitive explanations of the various classes of neural network units, and how to choose among them in devising a successful model. He also gives a strong overview of the various application domains. However, these points could be better underlined by choosing datasets that highlight the advantages of some methods and the limitations of others. Instead, Chollet’s examples seem to be whatever was most convenient and often his models do not significantly improve on non-deep learning approaches. If the datasets were instead intentionally chosen to underline concepts, this would be a great book. As is, it is still pretty solid.

The author has found the perfect balance between theory and application. Using Python code to explain concepts is working for me. I have seen comments about that more math would be needed...I disagree! If you want to learn the theoretical side of DL, there are more than enough books, but if you want to practice DL and get started quickly, this is absolutely it!

The printing on the pages seems blurred or enlarged in some places. Some pages were a little bent up. I suspect this is a knock-off but I'm still giving 5-stars for the value. Note: this is greyscale only (no color).
Wow, truly enlightening.
The book is an outstanding intro to ML. It situates the ideas in an approachable manner. Highly recommended to both technical and non technical readers. Enjoy it!

The book reviews various algorithms of machine learning, and discusses their implications to psychology and philosophy. It is not clear who is supposed to be the reader of this book. Readers that do not have background in computer science will face difficulties understanding the algorithms, and computer scientists will not be interested in the reviews since they include almost no technical explanations. The review of the philosophical background (mainly Hume's philosophy) is not accurate to say the least. Still the book raises interesting questions and presents interesting hypotheses.

I am studying machine learning on my own after sitting through a graduate computer science course on the subject.  I am only up to Chapter 3, and have liked the book so far.  I was looking for a "hands-on" approach with a lot of examples.  Unfortunately, several of the examples in Chapter 3 don't work as shown.In the second code block on page 85, y_train_perfect_predictions is not defined.  The line could be written as:>>> confusion_matrix(y_train_5, y_train_5)On page 86, first code block, second line, y_pred should be y_train_pred.Likewise, in the code block at the top of page 87, y_pred should be y_train_pred.In the first code block on page 88,>>> y_some_digit_predis needed prior to the last line (in order to output  what appears on the last line.)On page 93, top code block, "bottom right" should be "lower right".On page 100, last code block, y_train should be y_multilabel (two instances).On page 101, only code block, the third line needs to be above the second line.Also, to make this example work, I had to addfrom numpy import random as rndabove the first line.At the bottom of page 101, it appears that the author meant to show code to produce the images at the top of the next page.  But no code is shown.On page 102, only code block, function plot_digit() is not defined.  (Code at the bottom of page 80 can be adapted to do the job.)

Hands-On Machine Learning strikes a perfect blend between application and theory. Beginners to machine learning will find it clear to follow and will be able to build complete systems within a few chapters while those with an intermediate level of experience will find a comprehensive, up-to-date guide to this exciting field.Pros:+ Practical: The book focuses on examples and implementations of the algorithms rather than the mathematics allowing readers to quickly build their own machine learning models+ Readable: Geron does not get too caught up in the details, and he provides warnings when the next section is heavy on theory+ Online Jupyter Notebooks: The Jupyter Notebooks that accompany this book (and can even be viewed for free with no purchase from the author's GitHub) are worth the entire purchase price. They feature examples of all the code in the book, plus additional explanatory material. The end-of-chapter solutions to the coding exercises are gradually being added to the notebooks.+ Up-to-date: The leading edge of machine learning (and in particular deep learning) is constantly shifting, and Geron does his best to keep the notebooks updated. Multiple times I have read an ML paper and then found the technique implemented in the notebooks within weeks of the publication of the article. Some of the techniques in the book may not be at the absolute forefront of the field, but they are still good enough for learning the fundamentals.+ Engaging: The book is a joy to read, and the author is quick to respond to issues pointed out by readers in the book or in the Jupyter Notebooks. Clearly, the author enjoys machine learning and teaching it to others.Cons:- Experts may find this book lacks enough depth because it is more focused on getting up and running rather than optimization. It also is specifically aimed towards Python (and Tensorflow for deep learning) so those looking for implementations in other frameworks will have to search elsewhere.- Due to the rapidly-evolving nature of the field, a print book on machine learning will always need to be periodically re-issued to stay on top of all the developments. Nonetheless, the fundamentals covered in this book will remain relevant and the Jupyter Notebooks are constantly updated with new techniques.Final Line: If you have some basic experience with Python (loops, conditionals, dictionaries, and especially Numpy) and zero to a medium level of experience with machine learning, this book is an optimal choice. I would recommend it both for those wishing to self-study and quickly develop working models, and for students in machine learning who want to learn the implementations of more theoretical coursework. I have enjoyed spending time working through the chapters and the exercises and have found this book extremely useful.

A very well-written book that takes you beyond the "heavy curiosity" phase of your machine learning education.  You need this book if you want to *understand*, from a critical perspective, how to accomplish things like -  selecting features, culling data, creating provably-suitable ML models, model/data validation, and what it takes to actually get an ML platform to do something truly useful and meaningful to you!In return for being so useful, the author requests something from you - get your hands on the keyboard, and actually work with Python Scikit-tools as well as the Jupyter workbooks that accompany the book (on github).  You should have knowledge of Python, as many of the ML concepts are reinforced through concrete implementations in Python code.  And work you must, as - after all - the book's title includes the words "Hands-On"!I respect where the author is coming from, as he is trying to reduce his obvious experience in ML down to a "Hands-On" working environment.  I believe he has accomplished this goal very admirably.  His easy style of writing encourages you to try things for yourself, and removes the worry that you may "break something" along the way.  What truly impresses me beyond even all of this is that English is not his first language!  So - again, this work is very impressive on many fronts.SIDE NOTE: This book will likely work for readers with both "step-by-step" and "random-access" learning approaches, as no topic appears to rely so heavily on the previous one(s) that it can't be understood on its own merits.  Again - a very impressive feat, especially in light of the heady material being covered.  Major Cudos by Mr. Géron!

Like I said, this book is Amazing. The understanding of the Author is this subject is unquestionable. However if you want to buy this book because you think this is an "easy door" into machine learning, then forget it!For starters, the author has double problem of1. Conveying theory: probabilistic distributions, cost functions, optimizations, secularization ...  (which is absolute must for machine learning)And then he has to teach:2. Art of implementation (Tensorflow scikit etc...)You cant gainfully accomplish #2 without #1. And doing #1 is the "hardest" part and there is no way around it.I think without solid grasp of Multivariate & Vector Calculus, Deep Statistics, Advanced Matrix Theory, Probability & Information Theory, Linear Algebra and finally the almighty Tensors, there is no way anyone can reasonably model ML/AI algorithms or Neural Net models.So my sincere suggestions read books to do #1. Then if at all you succeed, come to #2 and buy this book for it.With lot of hard effort I am reasonably succeeding in #1 - yet I still have to wait before I can get to #2

This is one of the most accessible machine learning books out there for developers. It strikes a nice balance between intuition, mathematical details and implementation specifics. I would highly recommend this book to beginners and intermediate ML practitioners. I'm only giving it four stars because despite the content itself being great, the print does have some issues like missing diagrams (see attached pictures).

I read the Geron book "Hands-on Machine Learning with Scikit-learn & TensorFlow" before reading Muller's. (Note: I did not read the TensorFlow section). I think that was a mistake. Muller's book provides a better start for several reasons. First, it is better organized. Second, the code implementations rely primarily on Python modules, instead of custom programming. I would have given this book 4 stars before reading Muller, because I didn't have anything to compare this book to.Regarding the first reason, Muller's book is set-up so that a reader can get an understanding of Machine Learning (ML) step-by-step from the bottom-up. For instance, supervised learning, feature engineering, and model evaluation all get separate chapters. The model evaluation chapter provides and entire section, as well as graphics, for understanding the roles of training, validation, and test data, which are probably the most important bedrock concepts in ML. In contrast to this, Geron throws you right into an entire ML pipeline in the second chapter. It's a mix of feature engineering, linear models, stochastic gradient descent, random forest models, cross-validation, grid search, and even custom object oriented programming for custom transformers! This might be useful for quickly understanding what ML is like in practice. If the remaining parts of Geron then went step-by-step and elaborated on the second chapter for the remainder of the book, it would be great. Instead, for instance, the second chapter is randomly about binary classification for picture data. You literally only get two paragraphs in the first chapter on cross-validation and validation sets, and a sentence or two later in the book. I had to go to Wikipedia to ensure that I understood it correctly and robustly. I wish I had read Muller's book instead.Regarding the second reason, Muller's book does not assume a heavy programming background. Most of the ML pipeline is taught through the Python module Scikit-Learn. This is useful because the programming does not distract from learning fundamentals of ML. In contrast, in the second chapter of Geron, there is object oriented programming code involving concepts like constructors and inheritance. For Muller's book, the most sophisticated chapter at the end, which is on pipelines and which expertly explains why feature engineering should be performed during model evaluation, doesn't even go into this.In summary Geron teaches more advanced topics interspersed with the basics without a coherent organizational structure. Muller's book has an intuitive structure that elaborates at length on core ML concepts and doesn't overburden with complex programming. I might say read Geron after Muller, but I'm not sure that is even correct. You're best bet is probably just using the internet (Towards Data Science; Kaggle kernels) to learn more sophisticated things after reading Muller.

I'm only two chapters in, and I find this book to be an absolutely frustrating way to become familiar with machine learning techniques. Not only do the code examples in the book frequently not run correctly, but the same happens with the updates to the code made by the author on Github. Please address these issues associated with categorical attributes and transforming data in Chapter 2 in future releases so that users can actually run your code and proceed with the remainder of the examples.

This book is great. Covers majors topics in Machine Learning, with qualitative and quantitative explanations of each topic. Cites all sources, so reader may go deeper if desired.Supervised algorithms include: k-Nearest Neighbors, Linear Regression, Logistic Regression, Support Vector Machines, Decision Trees, Random Forests, and Neural Networks (perceptrons, deep neural nets, convolution & recurrent neural nets).Unsupervised algorithms include: clustering (k-Means, Hierarchical Cluster Analysis, Expectation Maximization), visualization and dimensionality reduction (Principal Component Analysis, Kernel PCA, Locally-Linear Embedding, t-distributed Stochastic Neighbor Embedding), autoencoders (denoising, sparse, variational), and Boltzmann Machines (including Deep Belief Networks).Important concepts covered include: cross-validation, confusion matrices, precision, recall, ROC curve, gradient descent (batch, stochastic, mini), regularized linear models (ridge, lasso, elastic net), gini impurity & entropy, bagging, pasting, boosting, backpropogation, autodiff (forward and reverse), activation functions, initialization methods, regularization (dropout, early stopping, etc.), layer freezing and caching, optimizations, LSTM cells, SVM dual problem, and reinforcement learning (covering policy gradients, markov decision processes, temporal difference learning and Q-learning).

Excellent book. So many books about artificial intelligence are available in the last few months. So far, this is the best in terms of deep understating of Python coding line-by-line available in github site. It took me a lot of time to understand every line of Python coding in this book. Without this line-by-line Python coding from the above-mentioned site, it is difficult to have in-depth insight of AI learning. One caveat of the coding in this site is "coding may not be 100% correct". On Sept. 25, 2017, coding on chapter 16 for PacMan game was modified and critic q_values used in training_op was modified to actor q_values and it is a significant deviation of algorithm. Since I am a beginner and usually I trust completely the algorithm of its coding, I hope this is the only substantive modification of the coding in this amazing book.

I thought this book was good, however I am a bit disappointed, found some of the concept explanations a bit vague, it seems to me that if you fail to explain the linear regression, don't get me started with the messy examples. I will look for a simpler and cleaner books around Machine Learning.
Artificial intelligence is in three different kinds and Deep Learning is only one type. You might be better placed if you had a book that covers them all.

The NIST and the IMDB examples in Chapters 2 and 3 do very little to explain exactly how the dense layers transforms the  data and labels. I am left very confused. Please do a better job of explaining mathematically (and diagramatically) how the tensor transformations are taking place as data / labels propagate through the dense layers.

This is the book to get if you are a bit of a programmer and want to hit the ground running with deep learning.  Great writing style.  Every time I have a question I find it is usually answered in the next paragraph.

Apart from being a great introduction to the Keras API, its a great introduction to Machine Learning in general. Chollet does a fantastic job simplifying ML jargon for anyone with basic computer or data science skills. From convolutional to recursive nets, the book does a great job continuing and focusing the already great API documentation found at Keras.io into book format.
There are about 20 missing pages in the book.I bought the printed version and pages 75 to 90 are missing!Is it possible to send me a book with all the pages?
The examples in this book are terrific and the author makes sure not to over complicate the material, highly recommend this book for a jump start into deep learning
One of the best-written books I have read. Very precise and clear explanations. Examples are explained with unique elaborations. Practical aspects and tips are invaluable. Highly recommend.
Excellent book of course, but everyone already knows that.

I've just received this book. I usually don't write reviews on products that I purchase. However, i couldn't let this one pass unnoticed to the readers. Though the book content is great as you can see from most of the reviews, the book quality is a huge disappointment. The paper, pictures, print are of very bad quality! I can barely see what is on the figures! A massive waste of money. I've bought a lot of books in my life. This one has been the worst in terms of quality.
Don't read blogs, don't start with articles. Start with this book if you are interested in understanding deep learning.

Such an important and necessary book. Enraging because if the incredible injustices perpetrated against women, the degree of which I didn’t know and hadn’t considered. I always thought of myself as progressive but this will change my view of many issues for the better.

I liked the in depth discussions re snow clearing schedules, members of the New York Philamonic Orchestra, the student feedback from the online course, the design of stoves etc. It was sometimes difficult to get what was intended when Statistics were being quoted with, at times, no apparent basis for comparison. The discussion about women dying in car accidents may have overlooked the passenger seat effect. I have been talking to the men and women in my life about this book. A must read for the men and a lot of thanks for my stand in the matter from women.

I bought the book after reading a review in the Financial Times. That it has recently been short listed for the best book of the year award is not a surprise at all. All men (and women) need to read this book.

... und auf einmal macht so vieles Sinn, wo man sich sein Leben lang gefragt hat: Ist das echt so gedacht? Funktioniert das bei anderen tatsächlich ohne Probleme? Ja, tut es, nur nicht unbedingt bei Frauen ... für die wurde es schliesslich meistens nicht entworfen. Oft gar nicht mal mit Absicht, sondern aus schlichter Unsichtbarkeit der anderen Hälfte der Menschheit. Das Buch liefert erstaunliche Einblicke, wo die unbewusste (oder bewusste) Annahme, dass Frauen und Männer in allem gleich sind und das gleiche Leben mit gleichen Bedürfnissen führen zu suboptimalen Ergebnissen im Alltag führt. Gut zu lesen und mit vielen anschaulichen Beispielen.

I never bought a book of this type in my life. I am a  feminist but I never thought I would enjoy reading a feminist book. However, this book is so so so so much more. The book is based on scientific research! It is fact-based reporting of the current status quo. Invisible Women should be a mandatory read at school and every lawmaker and person in power should be made to read it!

Me encantó leer a Caroline Criado, todo el libro es excelente y proporciona una gran diversidad de datos históricos para develar cómo la sociedad ha sido construida bajo la idea del neutral genérico masculino. Recomendado!!

The product arrived in very good conditions, on time. The printing is goodwith no defects.The content is definetely far more beyond just feminism and general knowledge; inevitably, it encourages people to think again about everything around us and how it meets (or not) other's needs.
A cada capítulo fui desenvolvendo maior compaixão pelo sexo feminino.Note que eu sou mulher.Obrigada pelo seu lindo trabalho

I really enjoyed how Caroline explained and compaired current data on women in our society in an extraordinary factful way by emphasizing aspects from everyday life to medicine, R&D,.. A must read for all men and women!
Muchísima información super interesante, cosas que ya sabíamos, pero muy bien explicadas, detalladas, y con información contextual, todo muy bien respaldado, muy buena lectura!
Absolutely great
Great gift to give some one who is a "math geek".
A helpful overview and introduction to Artificial Intelligence / Machine Learning.
Read this book. And be prepared to know the impact of ML in the world we live in.

I hate to write negative reviews, but this time... I should have read negative reviews in advance...it's probably my worst buy at amazon... It's even hard to say who should read the book.. If you go to the bar and after third pint decide to talk about ML this would be it. Lack of systematic approach, lack of relevant explanations of what are applicable areas of particular methods... NOTHING... skimmed through 3 chapters and still have an impression I'm reading and intro section.. Just wondering who are all the people who gave it 5 stars :(

Not good.  Mr. Domingos clearly knows a lot about machine learning, but he is on his personal hunt for something that doesn't exist yet, what he calls the master algorithm which is supposed to unify all the techniques of machine learning into a single algorithm.  The whole book is his trying to sell his idea of this non-existent master algorithm as something that does exist, and just needs to be found.The byline on the book from Walter Sara son says "Domingos demystifies machine learning", which made me expect this would be a book that helps educate on the basics of machine learning (as they exist) and its implementations and uses.  But instead it is just a book about Domingos windmill he is chasing.

Like many other big corporation managers, I am faced with a new challenge: how to digitally transform our company, our work processes, and our business models. Machine learning is one the terms I encounter often, and it is essential to know what this is all about. This book very efficiently raises my understanding to a new level; now I have a good overview of the basic bulding blocks of machine learning algorithms.Great read! Highly recommended to anyone in any line of business in 2016!
Difficult to read, not engaging.
Pedro is a master.
where are the examples to download????
This book helped me learn and teach myself much more effectively.

The examples in this book give a quick path to doing real deep learning with Keras. There is a lot of theory in deep learning (and I enjoy learning and knowing the theory), but it's also nice to have a solid handle on how to actually implement a deep neural network using a commonly used framework.
If you're interested in AI -> Machine Learning -> Deep Learning, this book is an essential primer.

One of the best Deep Learning books! For beginners, the theoretical explanations might seem somewhat insufficient, but, the practical parts are the best. You can be able to build your own networks easily after having read this book.

The best book I read after looking at other similar ones to learn deep learning based on Keras. The author being part of Keras implementation team know it deep down and explains the topics very well. Reading this book helped me get it and be able to start using it for my research.
The print book feels like a fake copy and the pBook matrix doesn't let me register for the ebook on Manning website.

I am not judging the content which seems fine. It is the images/listings layout and text formatting errors that annoyed me so much that i returned this digital edision. Amazon, please pay more attention to quality.
The book smells really bad. Its the smell of the ink used for printing.Disappointed with the quality.
Great book!This book is for anyone who wants to learn machine learning using the python front end Keras. It is well written  and easy to follow.Thanks to the author for this gift.
I've only had this book for a few weeks, and already pages are just falling out. I see I'm not the only reviewer to have this experience.

Every schoolchild, policy maker and CEO should read this book. It highlights hidden biases affecting all levels of life that negatively affect women's lives. I was shocked but at the same time grateful I learned about biases that personally affect myself and those around me that I didnt even realizr before. Its also an extremely easy read, i just flew past the pages.

Everyone needs to read this book!  Then we need to change things. Caroline lays out how women - at least 50% of the population - are routinely ignored in every facet of every society from what seems like the beginning of time.

Sehr lesenswertes Buch, dass die Unterrepräsentation der Frau sowie Sexismus im Alltag mit gut recherchierten Quellen in verschiedenen Ländern aufdeckt. Erstaunlich, in wie vielen Lebensbereichen die "The Default Male" vorherrscht! Um so wichtiger, dieses Buch stark zu machen. Absolut empfehlenswert.
Sehr interessant und lehrreich. Manche Beispiele hatte ich noch nicht gehört, obwohl ich mich schon etwas mit dem Thema beschäftigt habe. Lesenswert!
with data and a lot of information, this book show us how women are excluded of our society systematically. This book opened my eyes about this

Excellent analysis of the way the western world has been fashioned for a single elite group and has ignored so much evidence that society in all its complexity could be so much more egalitarian. This should be compulsory reading for politicians, public servants, researchers, doctors and social workers, economists, business leaders, designers, workers, architects, police and military services, everyone! Its arguments are devastatingly well written, researched, analyses and presented.

Un libro que debe estar en el estante de todas las mujeres para entender el mundo tan incómodo en el que debemos vivir. Una lectura indispensable para que los hombres tengan mayor empatía con la realidad que vivimos las mujeres y que piensen cómo pueden ayudarnos a vivir en un mundo más equitativo.
Hauntingly informative and spectacularly well written
This should be common knowledge! I definitely recommend reading the book. I can't believe I didn't know about this until now. It should be taught in school!

Bought as "used but good condition" - NOT so - overall worn, scruffy and rather greasy plastic cover, inner front sleeve full of scribles and page refs., all pages brownish colored and stiff as if they had been wet and then dried up, stains on pages from coffee/water. As I got it for a present I am rather disapointed.

Haven't read the Tensor Flow part yet (second half of the book) but the first half was extremely enjoyable. When you are reading it pay attention to details (narrative) because the author is sharing very practical approaches to some problems. I've read many other books on Machine Learning but they are too academic (other authors often times omit practical issues like complexity of the algorithms, etc.).I'm excited to read the second half too, and then I may update my review accordingly.If you're wondering if this books is right for you I'd recommend downloading the first chapter for free on Kindle. You will see that the author has a gift of writing in such a way that you are not tired reading it. Few authors have it.Highly recommended.

With the rise of deep learning we have ended up getting so many people writing terrible books on the topic just to make a quick buck. The field is moving fast and people are really in need of good sources so a lot of us end up handing out cash for books that look like they have been written over a few days by copying and pasting content from the internet. I fell for some of these books (many written through packt publishing).Not this book though! the author is a legitimate computer scientist and he has written an amazing book that i think is useful both to researchers and practitioners.However, i just wish he would write a new edition and incorporate some of the new changes to tensorflow!  I would happily pay to buy his new edition.H

Excellent book. The information provided is a fantastic introduction to machine learning and deep learning with Tensorflow. I got into the machine learning world via Andrew Ng's Coursera course as well as fast.ai courses on deep learning. I felt like there was always some knowledge assumed about ordinary machine learning that I was lacking. E.g., what's an appropriate cost function? what's the real difference between classification and regression? This book provides that foundation. I finally feel like I have a firm grasp of machine learning.I did not spend too much on the Tensorflow part of the book because I have been working mainly with PyTorch. But whenever it becomes necessary for me to learn Tensorflow, the second part of this book will be the first place I turn.Despite what other reviews say, the print quality of the book is excellent like a typical O'Reilly book. But you have to be careful not to buy it from resellers who will sell you copies of an early release that they printed off the internet and glued together. I made this mistake and had to ask Amazon for a refund to buy the genuine article. The resellers will price their book just a couple of cents below the real thing so when you Add to Cart, it will add their counterfeit book and you won't realize it until you receive it in the mail. Take care to "See all buying options" and only buy if it is Sold by Amazon.com. "Fulfilled" by Amazon is not good enough. The seller itself should be Amazon.com. Otherwise there's a good chance you will get a very poor quality copy that many of the reviews are complaining about.

As a person who is brand new to machine learning, I must say that this book is very easy to read and understand unlike a lot of other books that drown you in theory before you even know where it's going. I think the format of the book is very well-thought out. Chapter 2 (out of 16 chapters) being an "End-to-End Machine Learning Project" really helped in setting the stage in a very hands-on manner. I love how the exposition on the statistics, linear algebra, and other mathematical concepts involved in machine learning are introduced only when needed while still being thorough enough to have a good understanding. I can't say enough good things about this book. I highly recommend it to anyone new to machine learning.

This is by far the best material I have come across when it comes to machine learning, more than Methods of Statistical Learning, which many people consider to be the Bible in the subject. The author lays out how projects should go from the planning phase all the way to the maintenance phase. Each algorithm is discussed in detail with use cases and without drowning the reader in math proofs. Each piece of the code is discussed. If it has been a few years since college then the included Jupyter notebook math refresher is enough to get the gist of what's going on in the background and follow along.From basic linear regression to multiple neural networks to recreate something similar to AlphaGo, this book has it all.

Outstanding text for bringing non-computer scientists and non-mathematicians into the field.I'm teaching a group of biomedical researchers, who will ultimately be machine learning end users, from this book.If you are looking for a practical introduction, and guide to avoid the large number of pitfalls in ML, this is a good place to start.If you are looking for a deep, theoretical tome, look elsewhere.A knowledge of Python / Jupyter Notebook are helpful, but a software engineer will go into convulsions upon seeing the organization of the code.

Amazing resource for ML and TensorFlow. Geron's book really shines when he demystifies TensorFlow through building structures with basic parts to first illustrate what's going on under the hood, and then using built in functions to replace the basic parts to make things practical. In doing so, I was able to understand exactly what was going on in each of the neural net architectures, as well as learn how to structure a proper TensorFlow program. The diagrams he includes are also extremely helpful. If you're unsatisfied with knowing what neural nets generally do, and want to learn *just* enough mathematics and the underlying programming going on behind the scenes, then this book is for you!One thing to note is that in my print copy of the book, there are a few diagrams (very few, like 3-5, out of probably a hundred total) which are missing, as in the diagram box is there but it's just white space inside. It's odd, and while it doesn't happen often, it still makes me urge the buyer to go with the e-book version instead.

Typos in the formulas, ridiculous examples, unneeded code examples for functionality that already exists in the sklearn libraries. Makes things more confusing than they need to be. If I wasn't required to buy this book for school I would return it with a note to the author to retire. How anyone could think this book is good is beyond me, especially when there are other good introductory ML books out there.

Best book on Machine Learning ever! I recommend this as a Universal guide to ML.Code snippets are brilliant and useful to get going. The explanation of concepts is so beautiful, anyone can learn ML even my mom on reading this book.Hats off to the author on making a subject that has been troubled by bad documentation explain with such ease

The author has done a good job in providing "Hands-On" material to go along with theoretical understanding of Machine Learning. Other authors will do better justice to the explain the theory and show the math, e.g. Tom Mitchel; Christopher Bishop, et al; Richard Duda, et al, etc. But when reading these books while taking classes, I felt that I was missing details on how to go about to practice the theory. The author, as an expert practitioner, provides code on to clean up data, find relevant attributes, and use different and alternate methods to understand data. This a great introduction to practical matters in Machine Learning. It is a great companion to be able to run experiments to practice the theory,

I thoroughly enjoyed this book.  It gives an brief non-technical overview and history of machine learning and walks you up to the rivers edge of understanding what a general purpose learner is and what its implications on society are.  There are no equations in this book.  Mr. Domingos talks about machine learning at a very high level, which makes it quite accessible.  To fully appreciate some parts of this book, you will need to be comfortable with a little abstract reasoning.  A motivated high school student could read this book.
Fantastic book
Amazing book!

“The Master Algorithm” was a pleasant read. It sums up all major schools of machine learning algorithms succinctly and intuitively without heavy mathematics. It explores the pros and cons of each, and postulate a future master algorithm which could integrate them all to build general purpose artificial intelligence. Pedro also made his own extrapolation of the future AI-empowered society with a tint of optimism. Highly recommended to those who want to quickly slice through the jungle of ML algorithms and have an intuitive understanding of AI/ML from the body of knowledge perspective.

Great book for helping me "refresh" my knowledge of AI from when I got an advanced degree in Computer Science -- many years ago.  Easy to read and covers a pretty broad range.  4/5 stars because Pedro is intentionally "opinionated" at times and I don't always agree with his opinion -- but I do appreciate the fact that he's put them out there!

This book is fundamental for the ML enthusiasts conceptual bookshelf.Some have complained about it's lack of technical detail; mind you, it's a conceptual book and should not be read for technical know-how but more for understanding the spirit of the machine learning researcher and what the big picture is all about.
My boyfriend loves reading, and learning about EVERYTHING. I bought him this book and he's excited to learn! Its hardcover and looks like great quality.
A difficult read for a non-technical audience.
This is a very interesting book about where technology is headed.
Excellent book that explains all the small details as well as the big picture. Highly recommended.
I am not going to write a full review, except to say that this is an awesome book and well worth the read. It relies on data rather than anecdote, which I appreciate.
It is full of data and good analysis

As a feminist, this book was an absolute delight to read. Insightful, with proper numbers backing up the information read. For those of us who are deemed as crazy for thinking that this world is not made for all sexes, this book is for you.

世の中の様々な事柄が、女性のこと（主に、①女性の体のこと、②女性がその多くを担っている家事・育児・介護等（unpaid care work）のこと、③女性が男性から受ける攻撃・暴力等のこと）を考慮に入れないで決められており、結果として女性に不利な、女性に負担を強いる世の中になっている。著者は本書で、そのような事実を具体例、具体的なデータ等を挙げながら丁寧に説明していきます。いくつか例を挙げてみますと…・薬の治験者は主に男性であり、そうして開発された薬が女性にも処方されるが、男性と女性では薬の効き方が異なるので、女性に対して、効かない薬が処方され続けることがある。また、治験者を女性として薬が開発されないので、女性に効く薬が開発されにくい。・自動車の安全性テストは、男性と女性とでは体の特徴が違うにも拘わらず男性のダミーだけで行われるので、衝突時に女性の体に与える影響が検証されておらず、車の事故が発生すると女性の方がより重症になりがち。・最新のテクノロジー製品は、開発者が男性中心なので、音声認識システムは女性の声をうまく認識できないし、スマートフォンは女性の手に収まらない大きさになっている。・仕事で使う農機具、工器具、工事機械、作業服、安全用具等が男性の体を基準に作られているので、女性の体に合わず、女性の体に負担をかけたり、女性の体をしっかり守れていなかったりする。・オフィスは男性の使用を前提に作られているので、ドアは女性にとって重すぎるし、室温は女性にとって低すぎる設定になっている。・女性がその多くを担っている家事、育児、介護等（unpaid care work）の都合を考慮に入れないで街づくりが行われるため、団地や公営住宅の周辺に必要な施設（スーパー、病院、保育園、幼稚園、バス停等々）が設けられていなかったりして、女性に負担がかかっている。・我々は子供の頃から女性に対するステレオタイプ（控え目？優しい？感情的？）が刷り込まれるため、積極的・野心的な行動は、男性だとプラス評価されるが、女性だとマイナス評価されるといったことが起こる。会社、大学等における採用、評価、昇進等においてもそうだし、公職の選挙においてもそうである。・上記のようなステレオタイプがあるため、女性の発言は、男性の発言よりも妨げられ、遮られることが多いし、非難、批判を受けやすい。・女性が男性よりも家事、育児、介護等（unpaid care work）を担っているので、会社内では同じ労働時間であっても、unpaid care workを含めると女性の方が総労働時間が長くなり、結果として女性の方が病気になる可能性が高くなるが、その対策がとられていない。・災害時や紛争時の避難所は、女性のニーズや安全を考慮せずに設営、運営されることが多いので、女性が必要なものを入手できず健康を害したり、男性からの暴力にあったりして、普段よりも一層不利な立場に追い込まれる。・女性の安全を考慮せずに、駅やバス停が建設、設置されるので、女性は男性からの暴力にあうことを恐れて、危険そうな場所や時間帯を避けざるを得ず、女性の行動範囲や行動時間に制約が生じている。他にも沢山、女性が不当に負担を強いられている例が挙げられています。その上で著者は、「人口の半分を占める女性」のことが考慮されずに物事が決定されているのは問題だとして、①女性にも影響を与える事柄を決める際には、男性だけでなく女性の意見やニーズ等もよく聞き、男性だけでなく女性についてのデータも積極的に収集し、その上で意思決定すべきである、②男性は女性のニーズが見えていない（男性と別のニーズがあることに気づかない）ので、意思決定にもっともっと多くの女性を参加させる必要がある、と主張しています。本書では、女性に負担を強いている実例が約300頁にわたって次々と述べられるので、正直なところ圧倒されてしまい、読んでいて少し辛くなってきますが、それだけこの問題は根深いのだと思います。本書を読んで、男性として自分が見えていなかった現状が少し見えてきたので、読んで良かったと思いました。以前読んだSheryl Sandbergの「Lean In」の話が少し出てきたのも、興味深かったです。単語も文章もそこそこ難しく、読むのに多少骨が折れると思いますが、具体的な事例が豊富で、日本の事例もしばしば出てくるので、興味深く読めると思います。時々、文章にユーモアが感じられるのもいいです。これからの社会のあり方を考えるために、女性はもちろんのこと、男性にもぜひとも読んでいただきたい本だと思いました。
One of the best books I've read all year! Must-read for everyone

Este libro no sólo abre los ojos frente a los sesgos de diseño/estructuración de la vida cotidiana, sino que amplía posibilidades de exploración e indagación futura, así como una urgente revisión  de políticas públicas en general.

It is a great book. It opens your eyes to sexism in places you wouldn't believe it existed and all supported by real, legitimate data. For the deniers of sexism out there, take that!Great read. Wonderful story-telling. A recommended read for all genders.
Incredible book.  A must read for any man and woman wanting to give a better future to their daughters.  I literally couldn't put it down.
This book is eye-opening! It changes how I see the world with every page. Amazing! I'm recommending it to everyone. It must be read.

this book is an absolute must read. sometimes makes you just furious how disgustingly unfair and unequal our society is. share this book and its knowledge with your fellow male friends and homegrown misogynists/sexists to spread awareness. the book was delivered in a perfect condition.

Excellent starting point for deep learning.  The author is clear and concise and supplies step by step instructions for getting your feet wet with deep learning software and applications... Kudos... The author needs to write more books.

Good book to get into deep learning. It gets you a macro view of the topics needed to get you started. I have recommended it to all of my software developers.  They might not develop any ml software but they all need to understand it.
This book is very well-written. It worked for me as I have classical statistical and machine learning training, but wanted hands-on experience, which the book provided.
I like this book~~~ great buying experience ^^
Excellent book. Was very useful in my deep learning class.
Good packaging for the book with three types of wraps as in the picture and the book is great for who wanted to lear deep learning. I recommend it with rate 10/10
Great book to learn on Keras and NN. Loved reading it every page. Learned lots of tricks and tips.
I would highly recommend this book to anyone who would like to get a good understanding of Deep Learning. Python-based projects are the great resources to align with theory.
so damn good !
Well written. Easy to understand. Great examples. Best practices and good defaults for getting started.

The book covers more of the topics included in a Machine Learning or Data Science course. It has a balanced mix of theory and practical examples. In this context, the book is perfect for those beginning in this subject. Also for teachers as a reference and to get good examples of hands-on activities, and perhaps, for more experienced users that want to enhance their programming skill and to understand the whole work flow along a machine learning project.

Like it overall but could be written in a way easy to follow. Most of time, i am getting lost in details and having hard time to follow.  Good thing is codes in the book are provided over github and author is updating/fixing the code based on feedbacks from the readers.

There is not a single page you should miss from this work. This book deviates from theoretical ML; however take an approach of actual practitioner from the very beginning. A lot of basic examples. There are various of other resources he adds to help you understand. Check his git-hub code examples. Very simple to comprehend and robust at the same time.This book is a must read for a beginner data scientist.

Very insightful book, teaching the aspects of Scikit-Learn and Tensorflow use with python. Not only did I learn something as soon as I opened the book, I am having a blast following along with the examples. In chapter 2 you prepare some data and train and test some actual models. In chapter 3 you get to recreate the famous MNIST test, the “hello world” of machine learning, they say. Scikit-Learn makes these things very simple and easy to understand.My only gripe is that the book could go into a lot more detail about how certain models work and why certain things work the way they do. It could also speak more about the internals of the tools, like Scikit-Learn, and the architecture and function of the code behind the functions.But, overall, this is a great introduction to ML and those two tools.

It has been a valuable resource as I have been learning machine learning. My wish is that it had some more instruction on using TensorFlow. That said, this has been an indispensable resource for neural networks, SVMs, and ensemble learning. Chapter 2, and end to end process of developing an ML "product", filled in some gaps that were missing from other resources.

I am a software engineer who has been curious about machine learning since college. I read this book in my free time hoping to learn more and to scratch the itch to refresh on math and this book blew my expectations out of the water.This book goes into depth to teach readers how the mathematics of the software they are using works, and by doing so it makes machine learning seem like way less of a black box. You understand how support vector machines or varying kinds of neural networks perform machine learning tasks, instead of these models being mostly plug-and-play like other books I have looked at.I especially recommend you do the coding portion and exercises in the book, as they really test your knowledge and make you think. I also recommend Google Colab to host the Jupyter notebooks!

Delivers a well rounded understanding of machine learning and the tools and algorithms that go into the subject.  The author's experience in the field is presented in practical, easy to relate to ways that I found useful immediately.  It's by no means a tutorial and not for someone brand new to python or computer programming but for someone with a bit of experience it's an excellent book for learning how to practically apply machine learning in your own projects.

Received this book yesterday evening and I have spent about 5 hours reading the first 2 chapters, browsed the Exercises and Solutions. I have also downloaded the set of Jupyter Notebooks and executed a few of them successfully. There is a wealth of information on ML algorithms and processes discussed in this book. I am eager to read the rest of the book and soak in the tremendous wealth of knowledge presented, with such clarity and purpose. My kudos to Aurelien Geron, for educating us in ML through this well written book.

This is much too thick of a book to be paperback.  There's no weight in the cover to hold the book open so you can read and type at the same time.  And it is a book on programming in python, so reading and typing at the same time is pretty important.  If they had a hardcover version, or made it a little taller so it was less thick, it would be great.  but at near 2 inches, it's just too much.The content itself is good.  It reads easy and explains what you're doing well.  It gives good example exercises for practice.

I've used this book for an undergraduate course in Machine Learning and it did not disappoint at all. The combination of theory and direct applications make this book just excellent. I cannot even begin to recommend a better book for people who want a career in ML.
A challenging read! But necessary to see the coming revolution.
Great primer for a non technical person as myself. Immensely valuable and complex information in a simple form that was easy to grasp.
Kind of unreadable.  He just rambles on and doesn't explain enough for you to get what's going on.
Nice overview of the history of AI/ML.
Mediocre review of the available literature, IMO.
I really enjoyed this book and it has opened my mind to new perspectives of machine learning and its place in the future.
Very well written. Often funny. Very good as an introduction to machine learning. Highly recommended.
total confusion
One of the most fascinating and accessible discussions of machine learning. Feels a bit forced at time, but overall fascinating.
Eye-opening insights. I could not put the book away! Incredible research and fundamental data - in my opinion, a must read for everyone!
Livro muito bom. Me fez ver a questão da invisibilidade das mulheres numa perspectiva que eu não tinha pensado antes. Realmente há muitas questões ainda a serem tratadas para a igualdade de gênero.

Caroline Criado Perez puts concrete numbers on things that before I had only hunches, suspicions and imaginings about. Not did I find out I am I not crazy, but this book opened a whole world for me on how to communicate about gender and society. As she says, women are not a niche, we are 50% of the population, and need to stop treating ourselves as if we were an afterthought in creation. Thank you Caroline, you've hit the nail on the head an in a factual and humouristic way given us avenues to restructure the world as it should be.
Ich habe dieses Buch bereits mehreren Menschen in meinem Umfeld empfohlen und kann dies nur weiter tun, es zeigte mir noch einiges auf, was ich nicht wusste.
Well cited and in depth. Love this book and would encourage everyone who is interested in equality to read it.
This has opened my eyes to so many things. I now insist on my friends reading it too
