It’s been years since I picked up a book that I couldn’t put it down once I started reading.
This is an excellent, eye-opening book and well worth the read.
Super
Good resource. Pick it up if you’re learning python.
The book is from one of the prominent person inside the Deep Learning arena. Started with a little history and subjects are increasing in complexity. Necessary in the library of an AI practitioner.
The content. Use it in my course.
Very well written and easy to understand.  The author seems to have a knack for taking complex ideas and making them readable for non-academics.
Very well-written.
This book is really really cool
Gift for son. He said it was excellent.
He explains the blocks of the overarching concepts very clearly. Good book!
First listened to this on Audible, liked it so much, I wanted the physical book.

This is an excellent introductory-intermediate level deep learning book. It covers core concepts as well as practical examples that help to establish your own model. This introduces additional resources that could be helpful.

This book it my go to book when I have to understand and implement a deep learning algorithm in limited amount of time. It covers the basic and provides good examples that you are good to go right after reading what is said in the session. The graphs and explanation are understandable and concise. It is enjoyable to read even this is supposed to be a tool book. Recommend.

The book itself is excellent and very hand-on indeed. However, the book I purchased and filled by amazon has the entire Table of content and preface missing. I couldn't believe it and obviously saw the TOC from the "look inside" feature. Very disappointed from whatever the publisher and Amazon fulfillment! I expected the slightly higher price paid for books filled by Amazon would have higher quality.

The author does a good job explaining many ML concepts (to the uninitiated like me), but quite a few sections are not clear enough.The book leaves me wondering what is so impressive about discovering past correlations, and extrapolating their validity to the future.  It sounds like most ML approaches are simply attempts at quantified superstition.  Perhaps, that is the value of the book: it can make you disillusioned about ML.

I am halfway through the book and trust me being a beginner, I can say this book has helped me in a variety of ways and, to be honest, I can actually apply for Data scientist jobs. Thanks to my professor who recommended me this book!

This book is the first machine learning book you must buy because it covers essentials and the projects. Also it has many concept questions helping you to prepare for machine learning job interviews.As I see, the book is much better than the Pattern Recognition and Machine Learning or Statistical Learning.

This book is a real gem, not only giving us the how but the what and why as well. It ably introduces the relevant theory along with how to implement the necessary algorithms in scikit-learn and tensorflow and pointers for more in-depth reading. I've looked at other books on tensorflow and ML and this is the best I've found.

Out of the dozen or so books on machine learning and deep learning I've worked through over the past year this has been the best by far. The writing style is concise while still very informative; it gives a great starting point for anyone interested in machine learning/deep learning without getting too bogged down with theory, though it does give just enough to understand what's going on. This book left me wanting more and gave many great leads on where to find information to further my studies. It reinvigorated my desire to work (and play) with machine learning techniques, which was much needed after being let down by so many other books. I highly recommend this book to anyone interested in learning about machine learning and TensorFlow.

I come to this with a couple years' experience with Python, and a bit of exposure to Pandas. I found it well-written, concise, and practical where other books on ML have been too dense and theoretical/academic.I would recommend (as does the author n the first pages of the book) having at least a little experience with Python before getting into this.

There are plenty of other enthusiastic reviews here, but I nevertheless felt compelled to add another.  I have bought hundreds of technical computer/software books over the past three decades and I would rank this one in the top 1%.  As others have said, the breadth of coverage and clarity of explanation are outstanding.

Easy to understand coming from an engineering background with plenty of practical examples of different machine learning techniques in python. Various algorithms and analysis techniques are covered but would of liked to have some extra sections cover bayesian models and some statistical evaluation methods. Overall I would buy again but would also complement with another book that goes into greater depth in the theory.

As others pointed out, lots of figures are missing in this book because of printing issues. It’s annoying since you won’t be able to follow the author’s comments without those pictures.With that being said, the book itself is very well written and I would recommend it to anyone who is looking for a good beginning book for machine learning and deep learning.
Prefer a textbook, a few weeks Python skill and some cloud resources to appreciate the references.
This book is excellent and it is written by one of the best researchers in machine learning in the whole world.

A nice introduction to data analysis through statistics. As data analytics matures much of the material presented here will be introduced into a new stat package. As the book promises your new algorithm will not be publishable unless you produce a better algorithm. However an instructor of known knowledge will have employment for years to come teach the rest of the world how to see into the nebulous future

This book offers no new insights for machine learning experts. The excessive story telling and missing facts may even confuse newcomers,  since a little knowledge is a dangerous thing. However, the author shows talent in writing science fictional novels.

Too lightweight for a practitioner to learn much from it other than the ML World of Pedro Domingos. Yet at the same time too buzzwordy for someone outside the field to really learn anything substantial/actionable from it.  Neural Networks, Random Forests, Naive Bayes, Classifiers, and Genetic Algorithms are really not all that complicated to understand (though admittedly sometimes hard to implement), and they have been explained better elsewhere.  To that end, I highly recommend Michael Nielsen's online book "Neural Networks and Deep Learning."

Perfect as an introduction to the powerful tools of deep learning. The author provides easy to follow code examples and explanations if you have general knowledge of Python.

I am satisfied with the quality of the printing.
Vary practical and well written - many practical examples. Helped me a lot in Coursera Specialization on Deep Learning
I'm learning a lot!
I found the explanations conversational, intuitive and straightforward.  I also liked that it contained no math formulas.

This is an exceptional book. The author clearly has put a lot of thought into how to present topics and what is the best strategy for teaching the concepts. It is very hard to find a book that is written as clearly and thoughtfully as this one. The author explains all the basics and clears up all the ambiguities that you may find in other books. This is the type of book that can be read by a complete beginner and bring them up to speed very quickly.I cannot say enough about how good this book really is. If you can only buy one book on deep learning, this should be the one you buy.
Great book at great price.If the seller could send the pdf version, that would be great!
Handson books are easy to understand and I like it because you can pace up according to one's level of understanding.

Hands-down the best book on machine learning I have read to date (and I have three other books).  Not only does the first half of the book give you a nice overview of the major ML techniques, but the second half illustrates how to implement many of these in TensorFlow. The author has a very clear style. It has already helped with the redesign of my neural field model.

An excellent starter for those who want to get hands-on with creative projects. Really loved the approach in "Chapter 2 – End-to-end Machine Learning project" - this gives you an overview / big picture of the whole scenario, so that you understand the details before jumping deep with a particular ML algorithm.Certainly recommend this!

Just started the book but I have to say that so far I found it to be amazingly explanatory and clear in its examples. I didn't have any previous knowledge on ML but the concepts were introduced in a didatic and intuitive manner. The pratical examples also help to demonstrate the potential of the applications of ML.

This is a great book for software engineers who want to know more about machine learning. I took the machine learning class on Coursera which was a great introduction in matlab to ML. I was looking for something with more details that covers all different algorithms. This book is exactly that. My python knowledge is also just basic and I haven't struggled at all.

I have read many books on Machine Learning (ML) and I am also a reviewer for several AI journals and conferences. This book is one of the best in terms of explaining the theory in simple terms and very valuable from the perspective of the practical knowledge you may get from it. After reading it, I am sure you can start right away building real-world ML products using Scikit-Learn and/or TensorFlow.

The first chapters were an excellent intro into Machine Learning, followed by an introductions to tensorflow together with NN. I liked the book a lot.If a new edition is planned I would propose to include Keras as an abstraction on top of tensorflow for the NN part. It is a big jump from sklearn to tensorflow and the gap to Keras is far smaller (although I suppose the model implementation must be more flexible).

While I am familiar with ML theory, I was interested in learning about modern practice, and this book was extremely helpful in that regard.  I loved the author's very careful writing, it is obvious that he lavished this book with love and attention, and it shows.

Great book with good coverage of important topics. Unfortunately wildly full of errors - would've had an easy five stars if they'd bothered getting a couple of people to proof-read it.Still easily worth the purchase price.

This book was absolutely awesome for the first half. Great overview of machine learning concepts and introduction to sklearn. However, the first code example in the second half of the book (introducing TensorFlow) doesn't work, because it's built for TensorFlow 1.x. Surprise: TensorFlow is currently on version 2.1.0. This major release looks like it has a good amount of changes, so all of the code examples are useless. BUY THE SECOND EDITION THAT COVERS TENSORFLOW 2!
Gostei bastante do livro pois traz muitas informações e opinião baseada em dados.Me surpreendi com várias das questões levantadas pelo livro.

This is a fantastic book on Python-based Machine Learning with Scikit-Learn and also Tensorflow, which has APIs built on Scikit-Learn. As a former Google employee, Geron has had long experience with the Google ML stack since before Tensorflow was open-sourced and made available to the public. His experience is revealed in his outstanding presentation of both the basic concepts and key details of these ML frameworks.

Read this book _before_ you pick up one of the ' standard' texts on the subject such as Deep Learning by Goodfellow et al.To make the most of this book, be sure to first brush up on Python and Linear Algebra.
Very good to ramp up on Tensorflow. Step by step code will help you to understand what you are doing. Highly recommend.

Another must have hands on machine learning guide book for aspiring data scientists. It should be on your shelf if you want to pursue a career with heavy use of machine learning models done in python.

Best book on ML so far.  I am actually only 1/2 way thru it, but I found it to be really good - goes to medium depth on the algorithms and tries to show/explain things very well.On Kindle it doesn't render so well -- the code wraps too much, but otherwise its great.

Some used Statistics and Linear Algebra books will be helpful in understanding this very good book. Actually teaches enough fundamentals to be useful which is difficult to find in this field. I have found there is no good place to start in machine learning. Just jump in.

Hands-On Machine Learning is well written with up to date examples for a field that is constantly changing and updating. The code examples are great to help you get started, and the explanations are some of the easiest to follow. I highly recommend this textbook for people who are new or just getting into Machine Learning. However it is lacking in more advanced topics so if you aren't new or aren't missing foundational gaps in your ML knowledge, then this book probably doesn't offer you as much value as some other ones.
Geron expects you to be an fully equipped engineer within the scope of 2 chapters. He just put the code and passes. It seems like this book is for advanced ML pioneers.

Be ready they throw the info at you in chunks.. it's not for the faint of heart but for any seasoned computer scientist it should not be a problem. Very thorough and in depth. If you are brushing up on your skils or learning for the first time this is the book for you.

This book is much better to learn from than the dry textbook used in my ML class.It has excellent practice problems and teaches all the major tools you need when using ML these days.. Highly recommended.

It provides insight into things I imagine even most women are unaware of, which is even more important. Even the cover is cleverly designed!A true asset to anyone wanting to understand why feminism is more vital than ever.

I’m a man, and I knew the problems with women’s data not being collected and women’s needs not being met in the world were bad, but not THIS bad. There are many great sources of data for these claims throughout the book; so many, in fact, that I started to feel overwhelmed after a while.But guys, we have to read sources like these and motivate ourselves to do better. Ce livre est tellement important pour notre société occidentale. Il est bien écrit, clair, les exemples sont parlants et actuels. Ce livre pour moi est un must-have des lectures féministes contemporaines et je souhaite qu'il permette une prise de conscience radicale chez tout celle-eu-x-s qui le liront.

Just started learning about machine and deep learning, this book won't bombard you with too much math but you also have to know the maths behind what the author is explaining in the book or you might get lost or overwhelmed. Great book for starters. One issue though, some of the code examples don't work or have bugs, nothing major stackoverflow can provide you the solutions. It is amazingly written, very easy to read for more than 90% of it. The author provides gradual introduction in bits and pieces to complex concepts even before formally introducing them so that by time you reach that section, you are already somewhat familiar with what to expect.Looking forward to the Deep Learning section which is the second half of this book.
Does a good job of introducing the packages, but I kept running into typos or something where a code snippet or graph wasn't consistent with the text.

I bought the paper back and it was extremely frustrating because the print was small overall, and the code snippets were in a different font that was even harder to use. I can't say enough about the clarity and coverage in this book. I'm nearing completion of my master's degree now, and from beginning to end, this book has been an essential reference for me.

本書は、医療からクルマまで様々な分野において、いかに社会が男性の体格や、男性を中心に集めたデータに基づいて設計されているかを述べた本です。例えば、自動車の衝突実験で使われる人形が成人男性の寸法であるため、概して女性にとって車がより危険なものになっていること、薬剤の効き目に関して性差が考慮されていないこと、等が挙げられます。また、女性が無償の労働（家事・育児・介護など）を多くこなしている現状が見過ごされていることも繰り返し指摘されます。私自身も、車に乗ったり楽器を演奏したりする際に、製品が成人男性を基準としたサイズになっていることはひしひしと感じますけれども、それが当たり前になっていたので、改めて気付かされるポイントもありました。但し、月経や出産などのことは別として、恰も独自且つ別個の「女性の視点」というものがあるという前提も問い直されなければならないと思いますし（その視点自体、社会的性差の所産であることも考えられます）、ハラスメントや性暴力の話も多く（もちろん、これらもまた深刻な課題ですが）、テーマが少しぶれているという印象を受けました。また、女性に合っていないものがたくさんあるとして、ではそれらを女性にも合うように変えれば、今度は男性に合わなくなってしまうという場合もあります。意思決定の場に女性を増やす以外にも具体的な解決策が示されていれば尚良かったと感じます。本文部分は小さい文字で約320ページありますが、読みやすい文体なのでボリュームの割に楽に読める一冊です。巻末には注・インデックス付き。
データに基づく事は、科学的だし、現実的だと思われている。しかし、実はそのデータは歪んでいる。データに基づいて、正しい判断を行った結果、男性優位になり、更に基準が男性を基にしたものとなる。色々なデータや、例証があり、面白い。兎に角、面白い。

This book discourages readers to understand the bare-minimum math behind various ML models, which is sub-optimal as how neural nets work is governed by various mathematical frameworks behind them after all. Besides, somehow it seems to be significantly slower than some other DL frameworks like PyTorch and Caffe. For example, with the same MNIST simple example, achieving the same 99% accuracy took Keras/TensorFlow 10.8 minutes/463% CPU utilization, versus 4.6 minutes/142% CPU utilization with Caffe and 3.7 minutes/112% CPU utilization with PyTorch, respectively. In comparison, Keras took so much time and CPU power.The other issue is unless you are already familiar with both shallow and deep ML models, it might be challenging to fully understand all concepts and terms mentioned in this book. If you are in this kind of situation, check out the book titled "Machine Learning A Quantitative Approach"   Machine Learning: A Quantitative Approach           and it may help augment your learning with this book quite a bit.
Machine Learning: A Quantitative Approach
very good for Keras
good
I found the book to be extremely useful with many examples and easy to understand explanations.
Book arrived fast but its pages are loose and falling out.

I had high expectations for the book since it was written by the author of the language. I had also just finished Hand-On Machine Learning by Aurelien Geron which was absolutely fabulous and it was serving as a bit of a benchmark. Geron's book is packed full of information and written in a very step by step way. Chollet's book is written in a convoluted round about way and it is difficult to understand his points.The first 100 pages or so is on general deep learning and it is extremely basic. Even though I new these concepts I still found it difficult to follow. The writing is really bad.The more advanced concepts are not any better. Here is an example of the last section I read on page 172 before putting the book down for good.From the section Visualizing heartmaps of class activation"This general category of techniques is called class activation map ( CAM ) visualization,and it consists of producing heatmaps of class activation over input images. A class acti-vation heatmap is a 2D grid of scores associated with a specific output class, computedfor every location in any input image, indicating how important each location is withrespect to the class under consideration. For instance, given an image fed into a dogs-versus-cats convnet, CAM visualization allows you to generate a heatmap for the class“cat,” indicating how cat-like different parts of the image are, and also a heatmap for theclass “dog,” indicating how dog-like parts of the image are.The specific implementation you’ll use is the one described in “Grad- CAM : VisualExplanations from Deep Networks via Gradient-based Localization.” 2 It’s very simple:it consists of taking the output feature map of a convolution layer, given an inputimage, and weighing every channel in that feature map by the gradient of the classwith respect to the channel. Intuitively, one way to understand this trick is that you’reweighting a spatial map of “how intensely the input image activates different chan-nels” by “how important each channel is with regard to the class,” resulting in a spatialmap of “how intensely the input image activates the class.”Consider the image of two African elephants shown in figure 5.34 (under a CreativeCommons license), possibly a mother and her calf, strolling on the savanna. Let’s con-vert this image into something the VGG16 model can read: the model was trained onimages of size 224 × 244, preprocessed according to a few rules that are packaged inthe utility function keras.applications.vgg16.preprocess_input . So you need toload the image, resize it to 224 × 224, convert it to a Numpy float32 tensor, and applythese preprocessing rules.After reading this several times I still did not have a good mental formulation of how these heatmaps are put together. I also did not see the need to put in the paragraph about vgg16 preprocessing right here. It is just a distraction from the matter at hand.  The whole book is like this. I was wasting too much energy trying to understand what I believe are basic concepts.I recommend Ina Goodfellow's book on Deep Learning as well as Aurelien Geron's book. For Keras I would recommend the Deeplearning.AI course on Coursera as well as Deep Learning A-Z on Udemy. I do not know of a good Keras book at this time.
Loved it so far. Ideal for software developers.
It is a very useful book, presenting the deep learning techniques on various real-life examples, outlining exactly how to write a Python code to tackle them.
amazing! a detailed guide on how to start deep learning projects using keras. i wish I had started deep learning with this book,
Easy to understand the concepts of deep learning.

Good luck with getting any of the examples to work from behind a firewall - they all make an undocumented call out to data-sets kept on the internet. Basically useless if you are going to try to use this at work.

Like many technical books these days, the source code is available online. I am a big fan of github, and all the source is right there (see comments for the link). I was even more pleasantly surprised to be able to download the PDF directly from the publisher. I love to have these kinds of books on my handheld devices to browse when I'm stuck in transit or at a boring school show (don't hate me, I'm only human).As a huge Linux nerd, it was great to read this on page 64, "...it's better to be running on a Unix workstation. Although it's technically possible to run Keras on windows, we don't recommend it... using Ubuntu will save you a lot of time and trouble in the long run." Yes! So true. Make the switch, my friends, and don't look back.I've had a career doing data analysis and data science for several years now, but the day-to-day reality of those positions is usually much more mundane than deep learning or neural nets. Think "business intelligence" and "executive dashboard." Books like this are a fun way to stay in touch with the leading edge of the field.For everyone wanting to get into this line, take some advice: yes, stay current with the tech reading books like this. But the reality is you will spend 80% of your time just accessing, mining, cleaning and reorganizing your data. And 80% is on the low-side of the typical rule-of-thumb estimates. You need to get really good at these data-engineering skills in actual practice. Corporations don't come to you with a Kaggle-ready dataset and ask for a clever analysis. They come with a vague desire for "analysis", whatever that is, and a big mess of crazy outliers, mistakes, missing values, outdated entries, duplications and incompatible datasets. You *will* spend most of your time just morphing this mess into something analyzable. Study books on that skill, too.Meanwhile, I'm a few chapters into "Deep Learning with Python" and enjoying it immensely.

This is really an eye opening book backed by data (and ironically, by a lack of available data) to make a profound point. I came to this book believing myself already to be proactive about women's rights and issues, but learned that the problem runs so much deeper than I ever realized. And if I'm completely honest, I learned that I've been guilty of unconscious bias by simply not thinking through how certain things might affect women differently. I'm not a big book reviewer or recommender in general, but this important book is one I'm telling people in my world about. I highly recommend that you read this book if you want a better world for everyone.

Read this book.  It is incredible.  Well written, thoroughly researched and documented, but still extremely readable.  Fascinating.  Shocking, and not.  If you are a woman, or if you care about women, read it.  Even if you think you already understand how different the world is for women, you will be surprised.

Tons of facts but nothing boring about it. Most of the information should be in biology textbooks, on the news, and informing public policy in all areas of life. Instead much of it I am hearing for the first time as a middle aged woman. The disproportionate inconvenience, violence and death women face around the globe because women are not consulted or even considered in every area of life! We are not an anomaly or a resource to be exploited. We are an indespensible HALF of the population! Thank you for writing this book!

This book made me so angry that I had to put it down several times just so I could cool off. If you use data, collect data, or think that credible data can be trusted, this book will dissuade you of your illusions. Because so-called credible data kills women. It kills them in car crashes, in hospitals, after natural disasters, and after a winter snowfall. The author shows that gender-neutral data is actually blind to women, and women (and men) suffer the repercussions.

I just finished reading this book, and I'm blown away by how much I learned (and how much I enjoyed learning it). This is a great preparation for the fight ahead, And I truly believe this should be required reading for both men and women.Keep in mind, I don't even enjoy reading, but this book completely changed that.I have 3 books on my current queue, and probably going to read this one again after I'm done. Thank you, Caroline Criado-Perez.10/10.

I struggle to get into nonfiction but cannot put this book down. I'm about halfway through it and every chapter is blowing my mind. The writing is fast-paced and exciting and the content is fascinating!

Did you know that snow plowing/clearing can be sexist?Yup, it is guys. Major streets, highways, and thoroughfares get most of the attention after a snowfall because duh! people need to drive to work and stuff, right? But, according to the author, this benefits men disproportionately as they have relatively straightforward commuting patterns and are less likely to use public transport. Women, on the other hand, must contend with circuitous patterns of commute (i.e. kid's school, groceries, parents, work, laundry, kid's practice, etc.) that not only expose them to less tidy roads after inclement weather, but also sloppy sidewalks that have shown to result in more injuries which translate to lost productivity and eventually more expenditure on healthcare programs, etc. And that's just the appetizer...So....women are difficult to measure, non-linearly commuting humans that do 75% percent of the world's unpaid labor, who are disproportionally affected by cuts to social programs, who are constantly being subjected to an infuriating double standard, and whose contributions to the nation's GDP has been largely unaccounted for.If you are not the "default human" in most studies (i.e. a male) then grab some calming chamomile tea and take your blood pressure medication or something cause each chapter is sure to make your blood boil. If you are a "default human" however, then be prepared to have an entirely new understanding of the word privilege...There is some overreaching in terms of the arguments that caused me to squint and purse my lips the way I do when I'm extremely skeptical about something, like when she presented the idea that it's hard for women to perform similarly to men in construction jobs cause cement bags are just too darn big and so are bricks! If they were to change the world standard for bricks though...problem solved eh?Also, apparently men drove the trend towards bigger and bigger phones, cause we have big manly hands and we can handle them whereas women must contort their digits in all kinds of ways causing them much discomfort. But they do make them smaller I thought? Anyways, the point is that they won't fit in their darn pants pockets! By Jove, If the patriarchy just stopped designing Lululemons, yoga pants, skinny jeans, pantsuits and tiny purses, then...Hmmm. Methinks women in the fashion industry have it well within their province to address these issues, yes?In general tough, this book is an eye-opening, world-view changing kind of work that has research in spades and deserves every accolade and award thrown its way.Must read recommendation!

This is a fascinating, dense and at times infuriating book. The author Caroline Criado Perez, bombards the reader with statistic after statistic showing that, not only is the modern world built for men, much of the data we collect about that world either ignores or discounts the differences between men and women. Every paragraph, it seems, has a concrete example, such as, there are no female crash test dummies. Sometimes, scaled-down male dummies are used, but given women's different bone density and muscle distribution, even that's not helpful. Nor are there any pregnant crash test dummies, yet car accidents are the leading cause of fetal death.In many of the instances Perez cites, sex-specific data isn't gathered. One of the outcomes is that problems, such as heart attacks in females, are described as having "atypical symptoms." Except since females are 50% of the population, there's nothing "atypical" about that. Mind-blowing and infuriating stuff like that flows like water out of a firehose through the pages of this book.I said the book is dense - it's more textbook than beach read. However, it's an important and eye-opening read for both sexes.

I read a raft of feminist nonfiction books, and I must say this was one of the better ones--very good indeed. It was so good, in fact, that I had to put it down from time to time because it upset me by delineating the sheer and overwhelming abuse-by-neglect of half the planet's population.If you are a woman, likely you know a bit of this simply by being alive. But I am betting it's still a new perspective on the "why" of it.If you are a man, you may know a few stats, but you almost certainly have no clue about the global and right-in-your-neighborhood ramifications of ignoring the needs of women. (Not just moms--as a reviewer here complained.) From birth, women are never the "default" in anything, thus the majority of systems and things never serve them well. The state of sanitary sewer or toileting systems  around the world, alone, along with a lack of running or close-to-fetch water is an often fatal injustice particularly cruel to women and girls.People who make policy--and men--need to read this. Send a copy to your Rep. or Senator?

The book serves as very good soft introduction to AI programming, covering topics "breadth first" ranging from speech recognition to image generation. It focuses on intuition over mathematics and example over theory. The example over theory philosophy goes perhaps too far in my opinion, as I feel the book leaves the reader with a very limited understanding of how deep neural networks *actually work*.For example, the author explains the sample code, "keras.layers.Dense(512, activation='relu')", as a dot product, an addition, and a max(x, 0).That's useful information, but how does that, or any of the code in the examples, result in a neural network layer that is e.g. better understood as a specific human face than the last layer? It's like explaining calculus by saying, "all you do is get the tangent line across the curve and then add them all up!" The intuitive approach is great, but it is less helpful when the reader sits down and tries to solve a real problem.This may be beyond the scope of the book, however. For readers that want to dive in, get started now, and learn as they try new exercises, this is your book!The author is an AI researcher who created Keras, a popular AI library which serves as a popular way to use Google's TensorFlow. Credentials are not a problem.The author says that the reader requires use of a UNIX machine and that, "It is possible to use Windows, too, but I don't recommend it."He probably means Linux and MacOS, but considering that Windows has more than 80% market share on PCs, it seems a little more explanation may be in order. Google, the author's employer, is known for being somewhat hostile towards Microsoft. Perhaps that is it? Microsoft is a major player in AI research, often outperforming Google and every other competitor in competitions (e.g. ImageNet image recognition), and they Accord.NET and CNTK (Microsoft Cognitive Toolkit). In fact, CNTK is one of the AI backends that Keras can use along side Theano or TensorFlow!As for those that do not already use Linux as their development OS, search for "keras on Windows". There are a few more steps to install all the necessary software, but nowhere near as many as would be necessary to install Linux or change to MacOS.Overall this is a great purchase which I highly recommend as one of many books to help get one started using popular AI libraries.

I'm using this book to supplement coursework I'm taking as part of a Data Science/Data Analytics program through a local university. I'm only at the point of scratching the surface of AI, machine learning, and deep learning but I was attracted to this book for its newbie-friendly approach. The author has avoided deep-diving into mathematical concepts and uses a combination of code examples and situational descriptions to layout easy to understand guideposts.I'm particularly fascinated with the sections on computer vision - that is, using computers to automate parts of the human visual system. This book has fantastic examples that are easy enough to follow.Finally, the introduction to Keras, a deep-learning framework for Python is outstanding. If you're looking into Keras (or one of the other deep learning frameworks) this book is a fantastic starting point!
Great addition to your deep learning library for seeing how to quickly get started with Keras and start doing deep learning immediately.
Great book!

I so badly wanted to enjoy this book. The subjects are interesting and thought provoking but the underlying tone of the author drove me nuts. I expected a scientific analysis of data bias, and while the information and references were there the bias from the author was too much. Words like “obviously” shouldn’t be used to portray facts.

TLDR: Average book suffers from exclusion of trans people.I read this book after the author was interviewed on the podcast 99% Invisible. While overall, this book was very interesting and clearly written, it suffers from lack of inclusion of LGBT (particularly trans) identities. I did not understand while reading how someone could write a whole book on the way that gender influences life and not even mention trans people. When I researched a bit further, I discovered that the author ascribes to views of trans exclusionary radical feminism. This fact makes me doubt many of the facts presented in this book and the conclusions that the author draws from it. (Review copy and pasted from goodreads)

I heard about this book on Roman Mars' podcast "99% Invisible" and bought this book as a female who works in User Experience Design, to improve my understanding of data and to hopefully improve my research skills. As someone with a science background, I needed to be convinced on the data and research first, before highly investing (which I am now questioning- because I knew it was written by a female?) and believing the logic.This book is extremely well researched and written, thoroughly logical, and written in a fashion that is not accusing of males (which often isolates those readers). Instead, it is inclusive and instructive.As someone who watched their mother and has personally been, the subject of verbal/emotional abuse, I was able to sympathise and empathise with many aspects of the book. I walked away pissed off in all the right ways.This book is eye-opening, especially for males with an open mind, but even for females who are apprehensive to the extremist qualities of feminism. I recommend this book to so many people on a daily basis now, that they must assume I am being paid for it. Everyone should be required to read this book.
Wonderfully documented and illustrated facts and figures!  Cannot believe how stupid male leaders, researchers, and planners are.  Women need to stand in statics!

This book should be compulsory reading.  It captures a moment in time where in some regions of the world we should, ostensibly, have equal rights - but the reality falls far short.  I could not recommend this book more.

Necessary reading.I agree with reviews that point to equating women with caregivers, but that’s not due to oversimplification — it’s due to ground truth.“Women” are a proxy for “all social activity outside of paid work outside the home.” That’s actually the power of the book.I picked this up after The Fabric of Civilization, and it’s a different sort of read.In some ways it reminds me of The Big Thirst by Charles Fischman (which is less listy a la Freakonomics than this is, but still pursues an invisible and yet crucial topic).“Invisible” and “externality” are kind of similar. We should pay more attention to this because it’s a blind spot not just economically but in national security as well.

ALL THE STARS!  I wanted to read this whole book out loud.  MIND BLOWING.  I especially loved the chapters on transportation bias, gender bias is academia and silicone valley (although you can read “Brotopia” for more on that) and the male default with tool size and stride length and car manufacturing.  If you are in a rush, you can chapter pick here.  The section on medicine, both drugs and mistreatment of healthcare workers was fascinating and so so disturbing, as was the chapter on the gender bias in politics.

The author has done prestigious amounts of research to see what's missing in most of the data sets that guide public policy, corporate decision making and medical practice. Time after time she found that women's perspectives are missing or that the data did not distinguish between men's women's patterns of behavior or health outcomes.  I appreciated her efforts to include data from around the world, while adding some personal stories of her life in the UK.  The book is quite dense with facts and figures (about 40% of the pages are actually footnotes), so I found myself skimming many paragraphs but her information and conclusions are certainly worthy of consideration.

Throughout my time reading Invisible Women, I frequently found myself questioning things. Whether the words shared were accurate (they were), whether the gender gap was as real as author Caroline Criado Perez was making it out to be (it is), and if women are truly putting up with as much inequality as was portrayed (they are).As a guy, it feels as though this book ought to be required reading for my fellow fellows. At multiple times during the read, I sat down with some close female friends, asking for their thoughts on certain passages, and the universal reaction was "yes, that's my everyday life." The feeling evoked after these conversations were both ones of enlightenment and frustration.I walk away after having read this book with an altered perspective and new context for what my friends and family tolerate each and every day. It is affecting, and has inspired change in how I personally approach my own priorities moving forward.Please make the time to add this book to the front of your queue!

This book clearly describes the negative impact of policy, buildings, cars, algorithms, city planning... to a limited subset of humanity (frequently white men). With no malice a limited subset of humanity does not know what they do not know. We are deprived of the wisdom and contribution of all of humanity. The data is shocking. Lives are lost, injuries occur and quality of life is diminished.Simple example: Woman are more likely to die in car accidents as both the driver or passenger since autos are designed to be safest for the average sized man.

I really wanted to like this book. It started out great and with a lot of facts. And then I reached the part about the US tax system and joint tax returns for married couples - and I wanted to scream. The information there was so inaccurate it was downright misinformation. The author doesn't understand the US tax system at all and makes the nonsensical claim that in filing taxes jointly, the lower earner (usually the woman) pays a higher percentage of the tax due. This is wrong on so many levels I can't even. Not how taxes work in the US at all. I was so frustrated by this blatant falsehood I started to question the rest of the book. Now I have no idea if the rest of it is true.

I took about one week to slowly and thoroughly read this book, and it has opened my eyes to many, many different things. This book should be in high school curriculums, maybe then I'd never have to hear another guy tell me about how "Women just haven't contributed as much to human advancement as men." Women single handedly created humanity from seeds.And the author does not forget it. This book is absolutely riddled with facts and data, and even the damning lack of data in this context. Its thoughtfully put together to tell the story of 50% of the population that somehow gets treated like a minority. It's often witty, sad, angering, and most of all just depressing. I can't recommend it enough.That said, it was occasionally sprinkled with minor typos, run on sentences got hard to keep up with, and anecdotal evidence was regularly compounded with actual evidence to draw exaggerated conclusions (that were still, on the whole, quite right in their line of thinking.)Read this book if you are a woman or know a woman.

I am a woman. This highlights things I already knew, and opens my eyes to things I did not know about just how male-biased our culture is.  The gaps in the data are some of the more key components. Partway through, I began to wish for a Mythbusters episode to test the (possible) myth that "crash test dummies based on the 50th percentile male body adequately test test survival of women with seat belts on,  in car crashes."  After reading the medical section, I have questions for my doctor about particular courses of treatment. This book asks questions, and notes where answers are unknown, because men are the "default human." Fascinating, scary, stunning, and important.  I am recommending this book to everyone I know.

An incredibly inspiring and eye-opening book. As a designer, I am appalled by the lack of female data bias in almost every aspect of everyday life. I encourage everyone to read this, regardless of your career, I believe there is an urgent need for the world to pay more attention to female specific needs.

This is a book that everyone ought to read and many people will thoroughly enjoy. The topic makes you somewhat frustrated (this is definitely not a feel-good book) and somewhat angry. The data biases go way beyond what I initially expected. The only drawback I have is that it becomes a little preachy in politics and constantly, explicitly hits the same note over and over. At some point you just have to go "I get it, geez."

This is an informative and very well written book--thoroughly researched, fact-based, and engaging.  I bought a copy for my son and daughter-in-law and recommend the book to friends.  The chapter on medical research data is profound!

Should be required reading for...well, everyone, but especially for anyone wanting to run for political office, leading a company or organization, or otherwise in a position to make decisions that affect the lives of others. Invisible Women makes visible the systemic ways in which women's needs and women's work are ignored in everything from architecture to disaster relief to medicine with results that can be devestating not only for women but for everyone. Stop what you're doing and read now! Then start to make changes.

This is one of the best feminist books I’ve ever read. Not only does it highlight the issues faced by our society in a very thoughtful and thoroughly research manner, but also it provides practical and evidence-based solutions. The author doesn’t merely express frustration towards our society as it is today or place blame on anyone in particular: she does a fantastic job of demonstrating over and over again how debilitating it can be to exclude diverse voices from the conversation when managing the legal, financial, and socio-economic structures of a society. I couldn’t recommend this book more, and I frankly recommend it to everyone.

This book opened my eyes in more ways than one being the stereotypical white, entitled male living in the United States. Caroline Criado-Perez thoroughly and expertly relays the facts and the DIRE and extrodinarily unjust and unfair situation faced by women in all cultures all over the world. Half of the population is bring denied just the very basic privileges, rights, and necessary data collection needed to improve society and the human race as a whole by designing everything from politics, humanitarian care, technology, etc to better suit and benefit women. This data gap is a heinous crime against over half the human race and everyone needs to take steps to counteract it and account for these missing data by asking women directly what they want and need. It's NOT a mystery. It's simply laziness, sexism, and tying to mistakenly and incorrectly cut economic costs. Women should not stand to have to be bullied, obsequious, and servile to a patriarchy. They should not have to become more like men to fit in. History does not need any more conformists to the overriding majority in power. If a woman is the kinder, more polite, and moral person in the room, then she deserves to be praised for it by both men and women even if differs from the standard male way of acting and conversing. Men need to do better NOW to be better listeners, be willing to accept women with power, and to never treat them as anything less than an equal human being. Is all this change too much to ask? I don't think so. I think it is the least we can ask and do to progress as a society and grow and prosper as a world that is designed for Women and Men. White heterosexual men have abused there time in power and failed to solve anything. Now it's time to let Women, minorities, and everyone else to rise and create a better world not only for them, but everyone. I am a Sourthern white heterosexual man and that is the stance I support with my writing, voice, and actions.

I think everyone should read this, especially if you are in a leadership position. However, while talking about government, and how they are disproportionately bias towards male, over and over without one good example of a government that is doing something about it. You could mention the small African nation "Rwanda" HE Paul Kagame, has done something about it. Just for that I gave it 4 stars.
This book has a ton of great information but is not a great summer read. Too much information with little entertainment value. Recommend listening to this instead of reading.

This book brings together the data that most women experience at some point and most men are unaware of. It demonstrates comprehensively that by treating women as aberrant men we make society more dangerous and difficult for women and children at every level.

There has been so much science lately regarding medical science only using men in trials.  Science NOW shows male data is far from perfect when it comes to a woman and many of us have died needlessly over the years.  This book will open your eyes and possibly save your life.  Have an honest conversation with your doctor.

A book to make you sad and mad, but mostly more thoughtful than before. Using overwhelming (and concerningly well cited) evidence, Perez makes you confront your own assumptions about how you think about women, women's bodies, women's work, and what it really means to be "gender neutral". The solutions she provides evidence of are calls to not just be "not sexist". They are calls to be proactively anti-sexist, because anything less proveably doesn't work.

Criado Perez has presented an impressively researched, meticulously sourced* pathway to an unarguable conclusion. It will make you see infrastructure and policies in ways that will upset you, even as you feel at the same time that the horse died around Chapter 10 and the beating continued for six more chapters.* A quarter of the book is endnotes and glossary terms.

I was recommended this book and I was excited to be presented with a solid proof that has been simply a hunch for me. While there are some good data points and arguments, the argument overall is quite opinionated, and moreover, it has data gaps of its own. Namely, not a single description or example of trans/non-binary issues. The book stands as more of a display of irony than actually delivering on the promise. Huge disappointment.
Data, data, and more data, so if you like numbers, you'll like this book. Upside: there are some interesting and appalling anecdotes

This book is well-written, data-driven, and just plain good. It’s amazing to be able to call out all the ways the world - from planning to technology to medicine - is blind to women and their needs. Everyone in every industry should read this and think about what gaps exist and how to fill them. I’m so glad someone wrote this book.

While you may think you know what data bias has done to the female condition, you probably have not experienced the breadth and depth of the research like this. Here it all is, in one place, with surprisingly clear analysis and the data to back it up, framed by science. Everyone needs to read this book.

An absolute must read for anyone interested in women's rights or human rights. I cannot recommend this book enough. Caroline's strong coherent commentary and evidence for the gender data gap is not only convincing but essential for people to understand.

Before this book, I knew the gender gap was real but I was not prepared for the reality of how insidious the problem actually is and how complicit I personally am in perpetuating the “norms” that allow the gap to continue. As Caroline Criado Perez says in the book, “But when your big data is corrupted by big silences, the truths you get are half-truths, at best. And often, for women, they aren’t true at all.” I must do better. We all must do better.

Definitely a book I would recommend to anyone. It’s surprising (and unsettling) how we’re failing to capture the necessary data about 50% of the population to design useful products, make informed decisions, and to save lives.Criado-Perez provides a myriad of examples where gender data gaps are impacting society. While some of her arguments felt like a bit of a stretch, her overall argument was certainly persuasive and eye-opening. A quick and interesting read, this is definitely a book I encourage others to read (repeating myself, I know) as it shines some light on a topic that is clearly needing more attention.
This book makes some valid points but is so bogged down with data it is very hard to read. It's better skimmed over. I did enjoy the meat of it though.

Informative and well-researched. It stoked my frustration with how the world is designed to meet men's needs and overlooks women (half of the world's population!). This book really displays how deep these issues run in our society.
Excellent book that is making me think we have to redo everything (history, medicine,etc...) accounting for differences by sex and gender.
A fantastically researched, creatively presented, and perspective-shifting work.

The topic was extremely interesting to me so I grabbed the book. I found it easy to read and well organized. It's an incredibly eye opening read that shines a light on the many ways in which the world does not account for women.
Exposes a huge number of societal issues that slant everything favorable, being studied, being told is ALL slanted towards males.
What a great eye-opener and a wonderful reference book with helpful references and data about inequities in so many different settings. It covers the topic with depth and great range. A top read!
A well written book that exposed how much research is based on men’s bodies as a “universal” standard for research. We are NOT the same in so many ways, yet business and government remained biased.
Well worth the read for those of us who want to make the world a better place, including for half the world's population - women.

This is an extremely fascinating read. I wish it went more in depth- or had slightly more relatable stories, but I think that probably further showcases how little data is collected on women. Excellent book!

This book is fantastic! Very well written and researched, exposing the many (albeit not all) challenges that women need to face around the world in our day to day lives. Representation is key so if you are a policy maker, researcher, doctor or tech person, please read the book. We cannot change the past, but we can build a better present and future.

Great book.  Repeatedly points out data (or far more often, lack of data) where women are concerned.  It is frightening that women take medicines that are inappropriate (if they work at all), use products that are not safe because they were never designed with women in mind; and are hardly ever consulted about issues that directly concern them.
Was your women in gender studies in class not enough? This added logic and perspective to what extends beyond our usual ideas of women's inequality in our global society.
Absolutely incredible read. This should be taught as curriculum and required in work trainings. Highly recommend to everyone. Women still have SO FAR TO GO.
Just finished the first chapter and have a much better understanding of how women's needs are ignored to society's detriment.
Everyone should read this book. Factual and eye opening. Even though it’s packed with data it’s a riveting read.

Systematic bias exists which pre-disposes women to wrongful dismissal and inferior quality health care.  This book is a must for any woman or anyone who cares about a woman in seeking adequate healthcare.  This book could save your life.

This book is a must read. I ordered a copy for my sister and have suggested it for everyone who has asked for 2020 reading recommendations. The author cites hundreds of studies from a myriad of disciplines and does so without feeling dry or robotic. If you care about women’s issues, if you have a wife, or a daughter, if you are a woman, heck if you’ve ever met a woman, you need to read this book!

This is the second copy of Invisible Women that I bought so I could have one for me and one to lend to other people. I am a woman and a designer and I am astounded by the information I discovered in this book. Guess it's my turn to start designing a world for women! Warning: this book will make you hate every man you've ever known and those you don't know

This book should be a mandatory read for every leader, researcher, news reporter, and college professors around the planet!! The way in which facts about women are unnecessarily twisted needs to be known by the entire world. Thank you for your outstanding work!
Such a good book.  Everyone, men, women, managers, leaders, anyone who wants to better themselves or society should read it.

This book challenges the reader to consider the implications of data, how it is calculated, analyzed and addressed in the real world. I am very thankful to have been recommended this book, it has given me a lot to contemplate especially when addressing problems in my own field. I look forward to reading future works by Caroline Criado Perez.

There is just so much in this book that totally blew my mind. This book should be required reading for policymakers, journalists, academics, and businesspeople - everyone, really. A crucially important work. As a bonus, it's also an engaging, extremely readable book as well. Can highly recommend.

This book talks with facts and numbers about how women are underrepresented, not represented or not even considered in many daily interactions. Transit, medical care, housing are all not Designed with half the population considered.
Incredibly comprehensive analysis of the sex data gap. I've ordered multiple hard copies to give as gifts.

Our book club read this book. There is an enormous amount of valuable information regarding the inequality of women and men in today’s society. There are so many inequalities that are subtle and accepted. Hopefully, awareness will lead to real change.
This is a must read for women. My friends and I have these conversations all the time concerning the issues brought up in this book.
I really enjoyed this book and it made me rethink some of my ingrained assumptions.  Everyone should read this book!
This book should be required reading for both men and women, and it’s actually hard to know who needs it more.
What an amazing book. Buy one or yourself and one for lending to others!

Enlightening, interesting read! The author did an excellent job researching the topics covered and I appreciated that she was not biased in many cases. I wish everyone had to read this book and try to make changes to fix the gendered norms that have literally led to women dying.
Love it so far! Can’t put it down!

She provides endless examples of how women aren't accounted for and how our world is designed for the default male. Fifty percent of the population should not be treated as a minority. Everyone should read this book.
fantastic work on such an important subject. We should all be enraged that sexism is the standard and, as such, women are dying.

Just amazingly researched, extremely insightful and thought-provoking. Super ambitious breadth. Makes convincing arguments throughout. Incredible accomplishment by the author. Would insist people read this book.
Great book
Need to read
I highly recommend reading this and learning about the bias and lack of data that exists. There are numerous references in the book as well.
Already recommended to my sister because this is a must read for all women. Women rights are human rights, we are half of the population.

Criado Perez does an incredible job of not just detailing, but actively engaging with assumptions that we haven't truly questioned yet. Must read for anyone who wonders how bias can be expressed in the modern age.
I have read a lot about inequality,  and yet I was strucked by how often I use the male form as the collective. Also, how women are still simply not catered for...
Good for everyone to read
So many examples, very thorough, learnt a lot

This book was incredibly informative. Everyone should read it. Well-researched and compelling narrative that was easy to read. Really makes you think about how women are perceived in society. Cannot recommended this book enough!
Very insightful , I wasnt aware of the amount of discrimination against women even in the most basic things in life .
Informative book that everyone should read!
Fabulous book. Everyone should read, especially young women. Information is power. Statistical bias affects all aspects of our lives.
This book is so so good and brings to light so many things I've observed but never truly considered in depth.
Very thourough and therefore with great impact Never mind the angry tone, the sarcasm and open dislike toward men 🤣, it is a must read!
A brilliant collection of facts about how much work there is still to do, to provide an equitable world designed for both men and women. Every man & women should read this.
Easy to read, interesting and eye opening to how half the population is often unintentionally unaccounted for becasue of assumptions that collecting data on men is representative for all humans.
Nice book, the covered was kind of stain but everything else was in good shape
Infuriating but true, all things that seemed supernatural suddenly are thrown at you as this cruel injustice. Simply a must read!
It supposed to be an new item, however it arrived damaged.
Very eye opening.  I love this book and have given it to all my friends.
Fascinating and dense read.
Well researched, an important message.
Outstanding, detailed, data based book blew me away. What an accomplishment. A necessary read for all humans. Should be included in all high schools.
A really interesting read that goes deeper into topics I already knew a little bit about. Good detail and sources to back it all up.
Excellent
So good. Well-written, eye-opening and incredibly important for ALL to read!
Slow start but I love it overall
Very interesting and well written
Received the book with a damaged/ dirty book cover.
Book was in great condition. Look forward to reading it
Good condition and so far it’s a good book
It is a must read.
I bought the book as new but I’m pretty confident this is a used item. Super excited about the book itself.
thanks for this bro!
Couldn't recommend more. Changed my life!
A "must read" book for everyone.
And you should read/listen to it.
A truth that needs to be faced about inequality and things that are plain wrong in modern society. Every man should read it and feel embarrassed then apologise to the women in their lives
